Mr. Saffery gave me his address at Cookham—I have a note of my conversation with him which I took the same or the next day; probably the next day, in the ordinary course of my business—I cannot tell the precise time—I pledge my oath it was within forty-eight hours—I took it at my office from memory.

Re-examined. My usual course is to take a note of a matter the same or the next day while the matter is fresh in my mind—Mr. Saffery said he was astonished the committee should want any further particulars about the purchase, as it was all perfectly regular and bonafide—I pressed him to tell me some of the details connected with it—he said he had no details, as he had no books of entries of the transactions, as they were of a private nature and beside his ordinary business—he said that the amounts he received were not retained by him, but divided amongst several persons whose names he declined to give—then he said what I have said before about his denying that any officer had received a farthing, and so on—on my pressing him whether he had not some papers or memoranda, and the reason why he had not, he said that there was another person interested with him who took a more active interest in it than he did—I pressed him for his name, and he afterwards gave me the name of Spence—he objected at first to give me his address, but he ultimately did—on my pressing Saffery to see me again he said that he could not do 60 without coining to town specially, and he would not do that unless his expenses were paid—I asked him whether he was going for a long dis
tance—he said he was going to Cookham, near Maidenhead, on the 10th—the civil proceedings were taken some time after the criminal proceed
ings.

By MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. This note is my clerk's writing, to whom I dictated it—he is here—all my business is conducted in that way—I do not write—the interview with Saffery took place in the lobby of the House of Commons, where Mr. Saffery came, as I had written for an appointment—I did not tell him I had not much time to spare, or any
thing
of the kind—I did not walk arm-in-arm with him up and down the lobby.

Cross-examined by MR. WILLIS. My nephew, who is my managing clerk saw Mr. Walton; I did not—I saw all the directors previous to the prosecution—I saw Dr. Langley the day Swindlehurst was arrested at the Company's offices, where there was an interview between the directors and the committee—I had no suspicion then of Dr. Langley having received any money—I never asked him for any personal explanation.

SIR HENRY JAMES
submitted that there was no evidence of the money being the property of the Company as laid in the indictment, in accordance with the words of the Statute 24 and 25 Vic., cap. 96, and that there was no evidence of "taking and applying" the same. As to the charge of conspiracy, the only evidence was the fact of the receipt of the money after the contracts were entered into, which was not sufficient to support the charge; nor was there any evidence of any false pretence.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE and MR. WILLIS urged the same points, and it was further urged by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE that Saffery could hate no knowledge of the modus operandi of the officers of the Company; all he had done tea simply to avail himself of the opportunity of making a good bargain. Can referred to, "Kingsford v. Merry," 25, Law Journal (Exchequer Cases 166),

MR. BOWEN, referring to "Storey on the Law of Agents" contended that according to the words of the statute, the indictment correctly alleged the money to belong to the Company, and as to the conspiracy, that there was ample evidence to go to the jury that each defendant was cognisant of the other's proceedings, the result of their joint action being to put the money into their own pockets.

p.hi: was of opinion that there was sufficient evidence for the jury us to the conspiracy—the other points, if necessary, could be reserved.

div1.p:
GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the jury and prosecution. The Attorney General asked for judgment on the conspiracy counts only.
SWINDLEHURST— and LANGLEY—
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.
SAFFERY—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

762.
ANNE DOHERTY (33)
, Feloniously attempting to set fire to a house, and thereby to kill and murder
Patrick Doherty, other counts for setting fire to the dwelling-house of
Patrick Doherty, he being therein.

p.hi: stated that the prosecutor being the prisoner's husband, he could only be a witness against her upon the first count, and as the evidence was not sufficient to sustain that count he withdrew from the prosecution.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

763.
HENRY LEACH (57)
, Feloniously setting fire to the dwelling-house of
Thomas Lintott, persons being therein.
THOMAS LINTOTT . I lodge at 24, Red Lion Street, and am a packer employed at Covent Garden Market—I occupy the front kitchen with my wife and two children—on 3rd October I left home with my wife, my

children were at school; my wife locked the room, leaving nobody there—she put the key in her pocket—I left her, and went to Covent Garden Market, and about 12.50 she came and told me something—I went home and found the door burst open, and the room in great disorder—the bed was in one place, and the mattress in another, and I could see that there had been a fire; it had been put out—the bed and mattress had been burnt; we had no bedstead—there was very little fire burning when I left, only as much as you could put in your hand, and no gas—the bed was usually rolled up and put in a corner, but on that day it was not rolled up, because we wanted to go out, and it was huddled up in a corner, where a spark could not get to it—when I got back the bed was dis
tributed all over the kitchen, it had been removed out of the corner, and torn to pieces to put the fire out—I also found part of the sheets—the walls are wood, they were not burnt at all, but the floor was burnt close to where the bed was, and under the mantelpiece it was all charred—the prisoner was formerly landlord—I cannot say whether he was then—his sister used to come for the rent—he did not live in the house—I have heard Mm say a great many times that sooner than lose the house through not being able to pay the rent he would burn it, and all the b——people in it—when he gave way to drink he always said so, but not when he was in his sober senses—I went to the fire brigade station, and gave information to the police—the value of my things was 4s. or 5s.

Cross-examined. I heard him threaten so often that I never thought he intended to do it—I believe he rents the house from some person; I do not know who—he told me that he paid 60l. a year from it, but I do not know what profit he makes, or what the other people pay him—I live rent free for seeing to the house—the bed lies flat on the floor.

SARAH TURNER . I occupy the back kitchen of this house in the base
ment, there are only two rooms down there, mine and Lintott's—on 3rd October I heard the prisoner come down the kitchen stairs—I did not see him, but I heard him speak, and knew his voice—he knocked at Lintott's door two or three times, and I heard him say "Open the b——door"—I heard him burst it open, and he was in the room a quarter of an hour; he then came out and shut the door very violently, and came upstairs—about five minutes after that a child came down to go into the kitchen, and screamed out "Mrs. Turner, our house is on fire"—I then went into lintott's kitchen and saw the bed on fire, near the fireplace, and the flames were blazing very high—the kitchen is rather dark, but it was a fine day, and a person going there would not require a light—I screamed to Mrs. Clark to bring some water, and ran upstairs and called Mr. Eady—after the flames were got down a little I went to the street door, and saw the prisoner walking up and down outside, while the fire was still burning—I said "You wicked old man, you have set the house alight"—he abused me, and said that I did not pay my way—I did not owe him anything—I then went back, and the fire was pretty well got out—I saw shavings and flock burning on the floor, which were from the mattress and bed—I have heard the prisoner say several times that he would burn the——house down, and all that were in it—he was sometimes drunk and sometimes sober when he said that—I do not know what the occasion was, but I believe he got into difficulties—he was not sober on 3rd October, but he was accountable for his actions—he had been drinking the day before.

Cross-examined. He was not walking up and down the pavement when I spoke to him—he was sitting in Mr. Healey's shop while the fire was burning, but Mr. Healey turned him out and locked the door he did not run away.
By the Court. There was just a spark in the grate when the bed was burning, you could not say that it was a fire, it was so very low.

CATHERINE CRASK . I am married, and live at 26, Eagle Street—on 3rd October I was working for Mrs. Turner, and heard the prisoner come downstairs—I know him and know his voice—he went to the door several tunes and said "Open the b——door"—he pushed it and went into the room, and we heard him walk across the floor—he stayed in the room a quarter of an hour, and then I heard him go upstairs, and my attention was then called to smoke coming out of the room, and a little girl came and called out, and I took some pails of water and threw over the fire—the bed was all piled up in a heap by the fireplace and blazing—there was a little fire in the grate but very small, not enough to have caused the bed to catch fire—it was a dead fire, merely a few cinders—the floor was burnt where the bed was, and also part of the fireplace, the wainscoting.

JOHN HEALEY . I am a bootmaker, of 24, Red Lion Street—the prisoner is my landlord—on 3rd October he came into my shop a little before 12 o'clock and stopped there some time until he saw Mr. and Mrs. Lintott go out, and then within a minute he went towards the kitchen, and was absent about a quarter of an hour, and came back and eat down in my shop again, but said nothing till some people passing saw smoke coming from the front kitchen, and I said, "It looks as if the house was on fire, Leach"—he said, "It does"—Lintott's little girl then went through, and came back and halloed out, "Oh, Mr. Leach, the house is on tire"—he said nothing, but sat there till the alarm was given, and then I told him to go out, and I locked my shop door and went down to the kitchen and found the door open and a great smoke and a blaze—I could hardly get in for the smoke, and I told the women to fetch some water—thu mattress and bedding were all piled up against the fireplace, level with the mantelpiece—I soused water over it and turned it over—there was a bundle of wood between the mattress and the floor; not the whole bundle, it was opened and it was burning with the mattress—there was a mass of blaze altogether—the floor was burnt and part of the mantel-piece and the wainscoting—after I put the fixe out I came upstairs and saw Leach standing on the threshold, where some people were accusing him of it, and he said "I mean to burn the b——lot out," and with that he went away—he has been in the habit of drinking on and off all the time I have known him, about eight months—I can't say that he was drunk on this day.

Cross-examined. It was a day "off," but he was suffering from the effects of a day "on"—he certainly understood that the house was on fire—he could see it; he knew what he was about—I was quite friendly with him, the best of friends—my workshop is at the top of the place—if the shop had been burnt I should have been burnt out too—he sat in my shop for about five minutes, till the fire was found out—he had not said anything to me about going to search for anything before he went down into the kitchen—he said nothing about going to search for a waistcoat or a purse—he had no candle with him or any wood—I believe the owner

of the house is a lady in Jersey, according to "what the prisoner has told me he rents the house from her agent, who collects the rents—I believe be pays 60l. a year, besides rates and taxes—I suppose the house brings in about 150l.

JOHN HOOPER (Policeman E 223). On the evening of 3rd October, about 5.30, I took the prisoner into custody—he was perfectly sober—I told him it was for setting fire to a bed at 24, Red Lion Street—he said that he had done it, but accidentally, that he had missed a purse and something else the day before, and he went to look for it, and acci
dentally dropped a match on the bed.
Cross-examined. He was searched at the station, nothing was found on him but two or three coppers and an old knife, no matches.

THOMAS LINTOTT (re-examined). I was at home the day before—the prisoner did not come to my room that day—I never heard of his having lost a purse—he had not been in my place for six or seven weeks—I had a bundle of wood on the hob in the kitchen to dry—when I went in again it was gone from there and was partly burnt under the bed.
MRS. LINTOTT. I was at home the day before the fire—the prisoner was not in the kitchen that day, I am quite sure—I did not hear of his having lost a purse.

GUILTY —
Five Tears' Penal Servitude.

764.
PETER JOHN BARLOW (68), and
ISABELLA HARPER (47),
PLEADED GUILTY
to forging and uttering a transfer of a share and interest in the Bank of England annuities, standing in the name of.
Hannah Barlow, with intent to defraud—
One Week's Imprisonment.

765.
WILLIAM DREW (40)
[Pleaded guilty: see original trial image]
, to endorsing an order for payment of money with intent to defraud—
Four Months' Imprisonment.

766.
ELIZA JONES (56)
, Forging an order for the payment of 4l. lbs. with intent to defraud.

MARY ANN SMITH . I live at 28, Rutland Street—I am the wife of Charles Smith—about last Saturday month the prisoner came into our shop and said, "Will you sign the name of Mary Ann White for me on the back of this cheque, as I cannot write?"—I did so—that is the cheque (produced), and that is my writing—she was a customer.
Cross-examined. My husband saw her afterwards—she lived in the same street—she was in the shop about five minutes.

PETER HIGHTMAN . I live at 20. Christian Street, and am a publican—on 3rd August prisoner came and asked me to cash this check for her—she did not say how she got it—she said it belonged to a woman she was housekeeping for—I do not remember her giving any name—the second name on the back is mine—the endorsement, "Mary Ann White," was on it when I cashed it.
Cross-examined. I knew her before—she lived in the same street and was a customer—she was in my service some years ago.

MARY ANN WHITE . I lived at 8, North-East Passage, before the time in question—I came out of prison on the last day of August, and asked the prisoner if a letter had been for me, and she said "Yes"—I asked her

if my money had come, and she said "Yes, I opened your letters and have drawn your money"—I had given her no authority to do so—I had told her to mind my place till I came out of prison, for which I would pay her—the writing on the cheque, Mary Ann White, is not mine.

Cross-examined. I was in prison for a month for being tipsy—nothing more—it was not for assaulting the police—I told the prisoner if there was not sufficient in the house she could pawn my things to keep herself—I sent her the message—I came out on the Friday, the last day of August—she came to meet me—she said she had spent 2l. 10s. for counsel for her son—she gave me 10s. out of the money—I did not give the prisoner into custody at once because I was waiting to see Mrs. Smith—I know this son of hers, "Bob"—I have slept with him but never lived with him—I felt no interest in him—I would have had him locked up.
NOT GUILTY .

767.
GEORGE TILKE,
CHARLES BROOKS , and
FREDERICK JOHN PRIOR , Unlawfully
conspiring by false pretences to cheat and defraud the Metropolitan District Railway Company.

WILLIAM EDWARD SOAK . I live at 5, Wyndham Villas, Acton, and am assistant clerk in the accountant's office of the Metropolitan District Railway at Westminster—I am thoroughly conversant with the practice as regards issuing tickets on the Metropolitan Railway—the ticket col
lectors are stationed at each of the stations for the purpose of collecting tickets, which it is their duty to put into a bag provided for the purpose, and return the bag by train at distances of three to four hours to the ticket department, Blackfriars—trains of the Metropolitan Railway run on the Metropolitan District Railway, and trains of the London and North-Western Railway—the tickets are sorted into stations at the chief ticket office, Blackfriars, and checked by the returns from the stations, in order to see that they are properly accounted for—they are kept for three weeks, after which it is the practice to destroy them—the practice is the same with the Metropolitan tickets—the practice is different with regard to the mixed tickets issued by the Great Western Railway and the London and North-Western Railway—in the case of the latter it is the practice, after having examined them at our office, to forward them to the Railway Clearance House month by month—with the Great Western it is also the same practice, with a few exceptions, those exceptions being tickets issued from Addison Road, Uxbridge Road, Latimer Road, Notting Hill, Westbourne Park, and Bishop's Road, which tickets are dealt with in the same way as those of the Metropolitan and Metropolitan District tickets.

CHARLES HENRY FINCH . I am a ticket examiner stationed at Gloucester Road station, employed jointly by the Metropolitan and Metropolitan District Railway Companies—in the course of my duties my attention was called to Tilke at the end of June at the Gloucester Road station, and I consequently watched him day by day—I have a book in which I entered the times at which I saw him, and the places, day by day—he was travelling by the Metropolitan Railway—it would be within my duty to examine the ticket with which he was travelling—I have the book (produced)—I have an entry in his

of the 30th June, when Tilke arrived at Gloucester Road with a second-class ticket from Uxbridge Road, by the 9.50 a.m. train—it was a Hammersmith train, and would not stop at Uxbridge Road; it goes a different way—on July 3rd he arrived by the 9.31 North-Western train with a ticket from Uxbridge Road to South Kensington—that stops at Uxbridge Road—I am not sure whether it was a return ticket—on the same day he returned by the 9.55 train with a half ticket from Sloane Square to Hammer
smith—it was the forward half—he delivered it up at the station—he travelled third class—the fare between Gloucester Road and Earl's Court is, single ticket, 1 1/2 d., and return 2 1/2 d.—the third single from Sloane Square to Hammersmith is 3d., return 4 1/2 d.—I did not see Tilke any more on the 3rd—the next date is the 5th July, when he arrived by the 11.50 train from West Kensington (late North End) to Gloucester Road—I am not sure what ticket he had—he returned by the 12.17 with a forward half from Victoria to Earl's Court, getting into a train again at Gloucester Road—the fare between Victoria and Earl's Court is single 3d., and return 4 1/2 d.—the next occasion was the 6th July, when he arrived at Gloucester Road by the 11l. London and North-Western train, giving up a ticket from Uxbridge Road to Gloucester Road, a forward half, and returned by the 11.38, forward half, from Charing Cross to Earl's Court—the fare between those stations and is 4d. single, and 6d. return—on the 7th July he arrived by the 10.17, with" a proper ticket that day, and returned by the 11.4 Sloane Square to Earl's Court, backward half—the next occasion was July 9th, when he arrived by the 10.50—he had no ticket, and I charged him the third-class fare from Earl's Court, 1 1/2 d.—I next saw him on the 10th, by the 11.50 North End to Gloucester Road, Hammersmith train, which was the right one—he returned with an ordinary parliamentary ticket from Gloucester Road to Earl's Court—the next occasion was July 11th, when I saw him get out of a second-class carriage, walk up the platform into a third, and go on towards the Mansion House—on the 12th he came by the 11.50 with a Hammersmith ticket to Gloucester Road, forward half—he did not use the return half that day—it would be only available for one day—on the 13th I saw him arrive with a single ticket from Westbourne Park to South Kensington, by a London and North-Western train—those trains do not call at West-bourne Park—the fare is the same between Westbourne Park and Gloucester Road as between Westbourne Park and South Kensington, id. single and 6d. return—on the 14th July he arrived at 10.8, by the Richmond train, with the first or forward half of a return ticket from Uxbridge Road to Gloucester Road—the Richmond trains neither pass through nor stop at Uxbridge Road—he returned at 10.25 with a single ticket from Gloucester Road to Earl's Court, so that he did not use the second or backward half of the ticket he had used early in the day—the same day he arrived a second time at Gloucester Road with a single ticket from South Kensington to Earl's Court at 12.45, which ticket was cancelled at South Kensington—he was travelling towards Earl's Court—on the 17th July he arrived at Gloucester Road by the 12.17 train with a proper single ticket—I saw him return that day at 12.47, and he came down the ordinary exit staircase—he did not go to the booking office; he could not get to it that way—he passed straight to the platform without showing his ticket to any inspector—I did not see what ticket he had in his possession at that time—on the 18th July I saw him arrive by

the 12.1 train with the first half of a ticket from Uxbridge Road to Gloucester Road—the return half he didn't use that day—on the 19th July he arrived by the 11.47 Groat Western train, with the first half of a return ticket from Hammersmith to Gloucester Road—the Great Western trains do not pass through or stop at Hammersmith—at 12.3 he returned with a ticket from South Kensington to West Kensington—he entered the train at Gloucester Road, and did not use on that day the return half of the ticket he had used in the morning from Hammersmith to Gloucester Road—the third-class fare from South Kensington to West Kensington is 2d. single and 3d. return—the third return from Hammersmith to Gloucester Road is 3d. and 2d. single—going to the 24th July, he arrived at 9 47 a.m. at Gloucester Road, by a Great Western train, with the first half of a return ticket, Hammersmith to Gloucester Road, which ticket was cancelled at Hammersmith—he was not seen to use the return half—the same day he arrived at Gloucester Road by the 11.29 Hammer
smith train with the forward half of a return ticket, Hammersmith to Gloucester Road, cancelled at Hammersmith—I am not sure whether he used the return half—he returned that day by the 12.34—on the 25th July he arrived at Gloucester Road by the 10.38 a.m. Richmond train, with the first half of a return ticket from Kentish Town to Gloucester Road—the Richmond trains do not start from Kentish Town, and the return half he did not use—the third-class fare would be, return 8d., single 5d.—on the 28th July he returned by the 11.10 train, Gloucester Road to Earl's Court, backward half, cancelled, not having used the first half—he did not arrive that day—during the entire month of July, down to the 11th August, I continued to watch him, during which time he was generally travelling with tickets which passed beyond the stations at which he alighted—he never returned with the corresponding half of the tickets, but with tickets taken at a station before that at which he entered the train.

Cross-examined. I am ticket-examiner at the Gloucester Road station—my hours are from 8 a.m. till 8 a.m.—I go off an hour to dinner—I occasionally hand over my work to some one to assist me—I am supposed to only receive half the trains throughout the day—the Richmond trains do not pass Kentish Town, but it would be possible for a person to get out, and for some purpose of his own take the next train that came up, that train having come from another quarter—he would not be allowed to go out of the intermediate station—he might have come from Kentish Town though he arrived at Gloucester Road in the Richmond train—that could happen at Earl's Court and at the branch stations, but not on the main line from South Kensington to the Mansion House—Richmond trains go to the Mansion House, and he could arrive there though he came from the Edgware Road—it is possible to take a ticket at Kentish Town and travel up to Earl's Court, and then get into another train and arrive at Gloucester Road, not Uxbridge Road—it is not a privilege at some stations to come in by the exit door—it depends on circumstances whether a passenger can say, "I am coming back presently," and not be required to give up his ticket.

Re-examined. The rules and directions are that no passenger is to go away from the station without delivering up his ticket, and that is universally followed—I find it very seldom that a person alights at any station and waits for the next train.

GEORGE BLYTH . I am a ticket-collector at Gloucester Road, in the service of the Metropolitan District Railway Company, and was on duty on the 17th July last, when my attention was called to Tilke, who entered the station by the usual exit and passed direct to the platform without showing his ticket to a collector—I followed him on to the Hammersmith platform, and asked to see his ticket, which he showed me—it was a return half from Sloane Square to Earl's Court already cancelled—it should be cancelled at Sloane Square, that is snipping it—the wrong half might be cut by mistake—I cannot say what it would convey to my mind—I ex
amined his ticket and gave it to him back—when I went back I made a com
munication to Osborne—Finch had drawn my attention to him—on the 30th I again saw Tilke at Gloucester Road, when he arrived by the 11.38 train with the first half of a return ticket from Hammersmith to Gloucester Road—I did not see the return half of the. ticket on that day—on the 31st July he arrived by the 1.1 North-Western train, and gave me a ticket from Hammersmith to Gloucester Road, first half—I did not see him use the return half—on the 30th August something similar happened—I have seen him frequently at Gloucester Road, and have had my attention called to irregularities connected with him.
Cross-examined. I have seen him at the station in his butcher's clothes—the clipper may in a hurry clip the wrong half of a ticket—it does not happen very often.

JAMES HICKS OSBORNE . I am inquiry inspector in the service of the Metropolitan District Railway Company—on the 17th July from informa tion that came to me I watched Tilke, who is employed by Mr. Scarlett, a butcher, of the Earl's Court Road, from his master's shop about 12.5—he was carrying some meat in a butcher's tray—when he arrived at Earl's Court Brooks was the collector on duty—Tilke went up to him and put his tray down on the desk alongside of him, and entered into conversation with him—I could not hear what was said, but I was sufficiently near to see Brooks and to be seen by him—I am known to Brooks—I saw him look towards me, and make signs with his eyes to Tilke, and saw his lips moving, though I could not hear what was said—Tilke became confused directly, and rushed from Brooks towards where I was standing, passed me, and went to the urinal—I could see a small paper parcel in one of his hands as he passed me—he first went inside the door of the urinal, but was not there long enough for any necessary purpose, and returned again immediately, again going past me, still carrying the parcel—the tray had in the meantime remained on the table—he again went to Brooks and passed him, and went outside the station out of my sight for Half a minute, or perhaps a minute, and returned again—I could not see the parcel then—he had had some private conversation with Brooks—from there he went to the booking-office and threw down a penny and asked for a ticket to Gloucester Road—the ordinary fare is 1 1/2 d., but the parliamentary 1d.—he passed on to the platform with that ticket, and I followed him—I saw him get into the train, and I got into the same—I travelled to Gloucester Road and got out, and saw him do so—I followed him—he passed out of the station, giving up the ticket he had taken at Earl's Court—he went to a house in Queen's Gate and delivered some meat there and returned—I still followed him to the Gloucester Road station—he entered by the exit without going to the booking-office or passing any ticket-collector, and went straight on to the Hammersmith plat
form

—I spoke to Blyth, who had spoken to Kim, he told me—Blyth made a communication to me—Tilke went by the next train, and I went by the same—we alighted at Earl's Court, and I followed him upstairs—Brooks was still the collector—Tilke appeared to give him a ticket in the ordinary way—it would be the ordinary duty of Brooks to collect a ticket from a passenger going away—he should allow no one to pass without—Gloucester Road is next to Earl's Court—a person going east, finding himself at Earl's Court, might get out there—tickets are fre
quently given up short of their destination.

Cross-examined. A great many passengers take tickets to places to which they do not actually go—they may have appointments made, and get out at particular platforms, and those cases may happen—the paper parcel Tilke had may have been meat—I don't think he knew me; he knew Brooks—he walked sharply; people usually do walk sharply at railway stations—Earl's Court Gardens is close to the railway station—when Tilke went out of the station with the paper parcel he was not away long enough to go to Earl's Court Gardens—he was gone long enough to get rid of the parcel.

JAMES JOHN PATTERSON . I live at 32, Palace Road, Lambeth, and am a pensioned police sergeant—in July I was employed by the prosecuting company, and on the 19th I watched Tilke and saw him leave his employer's shop at about 11am. and go to Earl's Court—he carried a basket in his hand, in which there was a paper parcel—Brooks was acting as collector at the station—I saw Tilke put his basket down near where Brooks was standing—I remained at the door and watched them—neither of them knew me—I saw Tilke go from Brooks to the urinal, and come out in a short time and return to where his basket was—I then passed into the station and asked for a ticket for Gloucester Road—while standing at the ticket office people were intervening between me and the defen
dants Tilke and Brooks, so that I could not see exactly what passed, but I saw a mutual morion of the arms as though something was passing from one to the other—Tilke left the station—I passed on to the platform to Brooks with my ticket to examine and nip, and went to Gloucester Road and remained there on the platform—by the next train arriving at Gloucester Road Tilke came and gave something, presumably a ticket, to examiner Finch—I followed him to a house in Queen's Gate, and re
turned after him to Gloucester Road—when nearly opposite the station he took a green ticket from his pocket and looked at it—he then went into the station at Gloucester Road and gave a ticket to Finch, who nipped it and allowed him to go on the platform—he took no ticket at the book
ing office of either station, I am certain—he came by the following train—I am certain on the return journey he took no ticket at Gloucester Road—I thought the green ticket was a return ticket—I saw one of the edges was rough—I got into the train which he did, which took us back to Earl's Court—I followed him up the steps and saw him give up a ticket and leave the station—on the 20th July I again watched him. when he left his master's shop with his basket as before and went to Earl's Court station—Brooks was again the collector—he again placed his basket on the table and he and Brooks leant over it—I then saw Brooks standing a little way off' him—he had a leathern bag in his hand such as ticket collectors use for putting collected tickets into—he took some out, looked at them, and returned them—Brooks looked up

and saw me watching him and put down the bag and went to the head of the stairs—Tilke was then standing at the door—I went by the train and waited at the Gloucester Road station some time and saw him come and go to a house in Queen's Gate—then I gave up watching for that day—on the 24th July I again watched him and saw him leave the same place with the same basket and go to the same station—Prior was on duty at that time—Tilke held his basket under his arm when he got to the station—he went near to Prior, and Prior gave him a ticket or tickets—I was standing at the window of the booking-office some few paces off and saw the tickets pass—to the best of my belief there were two tickets—they might have spoken, but I was too far off to hear what they said—Tilke passed to the platform without going to the booking-office to get a ticket—I followed him down and went in the same train as he did to Gloucester Road, where he appeared to give up a ticket—he passed something to a collector—I followed him to the house in Queen's Gate, but saw him no more that day—on the 26th July I again watched him—Prior was on duty, and Tilke passed direct to the platform without taking a ticket, and at Gloucester Road he gave up what was presumably a ticket which I had never seen him take—I watched him to Queen's Gate and he returned to Gloucester Road—he passed to the Hammersmith platform without going to the booking office—he travelled back to Earl's Court and gave up a ticket—neither going nor returning did he take a ticket—on the 27th July I again we watched him, and exactly the same thing occurred—Prior was collector that day—on the 28th July he was again collector—Tilke arrived at the Earl's Court station—I saw Prior go to his ticket table and remove a newspaper, under which there were two tickets—he removed one and took it to Tilke on the platform without going to the booking office—I went to Gloucester Road with the object of watching Tilke again—he did not get out at Gloucester Road that day, but I believe went on to South Kensington—I watched him return from the direction of Queen's Gate—he went to Gloucester Road, I following him—I don't know whether be showed a ticket at Earl's Court—he made a motion to Prior—at Gloucester Road he showed a ticket to Finch and passed on to the platform without going to the booking office—I watched him back to Earl's Court—I fol
lowed him from the station to a public-house, where he remained a few minutes, and left—directly he had left Prior arrived and went into the public-house, and after a short time came and looked out of the door as though looking for some one—he then went in and remained.

Cross-examined. When I watched Tilke I went to the place of business, Mr. Scarlett's—I never lost sight of him—his taking a ticket was the exception—I don't recollect any other occasion than I have given—on that occasion I saw him speaking to Brooks, and then he left the station—I went in the train and he followed by the next—he might have taken a ticket in the interval, and if so it would be necessary for him to take one on his return journey—sometimes there is a good deal of traffic at Earl's Court, and sometimes it is quite clear—he could not have obtained a ticket except on the one occasion without my seeing him—I have seen him carrying meat in the ordinary course of business and deliver it at the house in Queen's Gate.
Re-examined. I was instructed to watch.

GUILTY . TILKE
received a good character and was recommended to mercy by the Company as being the instrument of the Collectors.—
Six Months' im
prisonment each.

768.
ALFRED LEVYSON (19)
, Forging an acceptance of a bill of exchange for 17l. 5s. 6d. with intent to defraud; also for obtaining from
Henry Ashway forty yards of cloth with intent to defraud.

MR. HUMPHREYS for the Prosecution offered no evidence—
NOT GUILTY .

769.
SAMUEL JACOBI (44)
, Obtaining by false pretences from
Arthur Gye an order for the delivery of 576 bottles of wine, with intent to defraud.

The Prosecutor did not appear—
NOT GUILTY .

770.
HENRY BARBER (30)
PLEADED GUILTY
to feloniously killing and slaying
William Jackson.

hi.rs: He received a good character.—Six Months' Imprisonment.

div1.p:
771.
EDWARD BEALE (18)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
William Taylor with intent to murder him.
The prisoner having said in the hearing of the jury that he was guilty of unlawfully wounding, they found that verdict.—
Three Months' Imprisonment.

772.
JOHN SALE (27)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Eliza Tripp with intent to murder her.

ANN ELIZABETH COOPER . I am a widow, and occupy the front top room at 15, St. Helena Place, Clerkenwell—the prisoner occupied the back room on the same floor with Eliza Tripp—they were cohabiting as man and wife—on the morning of 11th September I was awoke between three and four o'clock by a noise in their room, and heard the woman say "You are killing me, Jack, don't hit me again"—I went to the door, knocked three times, and called to him to leave the girl alone, but no one answered—a policeman then came up and knocked at the door two or three times—there was no answer—the woman cried for help, and said, "You are killing me," and he burst the door open—I heard the word "murder" in a female voice, and the prosecutrix, entirely naked, ran under the policeman's arms into my room—she was covered with blood, and I saw a wound in her throat—I remained in the room about half an hour, and she was bleeding more or less the whole of that time—a doctor was fetched, and came directly—she was removed into her own room, where the prisoner was getting ready to go away with the constable, but he only remained a few minutes.

CHARLES SHADDOCK (Policeman G 165). About 8.15 in the morning I heard cries of murder and police in a female's voice; went up to the top floor of the house and heard blows, and a female crying, "Jack, don't kill me"—the door was locked, and I forced it open with my truncheon, and saw the prisoner, with a female laid across two chairs in front of the fireplace holding her by the throat with both hands—I pulled him off of her, and then saw that she had a wound in her throat—she was naked, and covered with blood—she rushed into the next room, saying in the prisoner's presence that he had cut her throat with a knife—he made no

reply—I took him in custody—he said "All right, I have done it now, I will go quietly with you"—164 G came upstairs—I gave the prisoner into his charge, and sent for a surgeon—the prisoner and prosecutrix were both sober.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. She had not hold of you by your hair—you did say "I have done it, now I am satisfied."

ROBERT BOULTBEE (Policeman G 164). On 11th September about a quarter to four o'clock I was called to the prisoner's room, and found it all over blood—the prosecutrix was in the next room—I took the prisoner to the station, and on the way he said, "I have made a pretty job of it now, but she aggravated me to it. I came home at 11 o'clock, and she did not get home till 2; the child was very cross, and I could not keep it quiet; she would not get into bed, and this is what it has come to"—he also said that he supposed she had taken a little too much whisky—the girl had nothing on, and was covered with blood, and he only had on a bit of his shirt sleeve—he put his wife's shift on to go to the station—the child was in bed in Mrs. Cooper's room—I found these tongs by the fireplace covered with fresh blood, and on some rags in a wooden chest under the bed this table-knife with blood running from it—the lid had been lifted up and the knife dropped under.

ELIZA TRIPP . Last September I was living with the prisoner as his wife—on 11th September I came home between 1.30 and 2 in the morn
ing, and found the prisoner going to bed—I had had a drop too much drink, but he had had nothing at all—he asked where I had been—I told him I would not tell him, he must find out—he went to bed—I did not undress myself—he said that if I told him where I had been he would not touch me—I told him he could do what he liked, I should not tell him—I then went to bed too, and he asked me again, but I would not tell him, so he got out of bed, and hit me on the head with the tongs—I was not in bed then; I jumped out at the same time that he did, and after he hit me I got a knife—I always run to the knife when I am in a temper—I got out of bed because I knew he was going to hit me—I tried to stab him for hitting me—I never cried out, I only said, "Oh, Jack, don't hit me"—I never used the word "murder" all the time we were quarrelling, but I believe people in the nest room called out "murder" when they heard I was being knocked about—the prisoner tried to pull the knife out of my hand, and my thumb got cut in the struggle—I tried to stab him with it on the back of his neck, when he put his head down and I bit him, and we fell on the floor together, and he got the knife from me, and cut my thumb in getting it—he had struck me two blows on the head with the tongs, but not heavy blows—I did not feel them much at the time—I believe he got the knife from me, but I do not know anything more till the policeman came in—I was not lying on any chairs, there was not room for them where we were—he has only hit me once before, but I have stabbed him twice—I ran out of the room with my petticoat round me—I do not remember how my throat was cut—I was not taken to Mrs. Cooper's room; I went there.

By THE COURT. I said before the magistrate that I thought he tried to cut my throat—it was done—I remember the surgeon coming and ex
amining my wounds.
Cross-examined. I took the knife from the table and stabbed you on the back of the neck—I do not know whether I made that scar which
you have there in my temper—I know I have stabbed you twice before—I do not think it was your intention to murder me.

HEBER CHAMBERS , M. R. C. S. I live at 1, Wilmington Square, Clerk
enwell—I was called to St. Helena Place, and found the prosecutrix in the front room, crouched on the floor, and covered with blood from head to foot—she Lad a flannel petticoat round her, but not on—I removed her to the next room, and found on the front of her head a contused wound about an inch long, not very deep, and immediately behind that a star-shaped wound, under which was a dent in the bone, that was from a more severe blow—I do not think they were done with the knob at the end of these tongs, but with the centre knob—a blow from this end would make a much broader cut—there was also a small contused wound one third of an inch deep, at the back of her head, which might have been produced by striking against something—there were scratches of a knife on her hands, and on her throat a wound about three inches long, going from right to left, and jagged at one end—it went down to the wind
pipe and touched the cartilages and muscles, but it did not open the windpipe—it could be done with this knife—it was jagged, showing that the knife had been drawn across two or three times, and had grazed the skin, but the knife need not have been taken from the original wound to do that—it was only serious from the loss of blood—injury to the windpipe might have led to inflammation of the lungs, but the cut would have had to go considerably deeper than it did, to touch any of the main vessels—there was also a cut between her left thumb and forefinger three-quarters of an inch long, and rather deep, and a cor
responding cut on the finger, as if she had had the knife thus—it was as you would expect to find when one person was wresting a knife from another—there were a great many small cuts on both hands—she went into the hospital the next day as there was no one to nurse her.
ROBERT BOULTBEE (re-examined). The prisoner did not complain of a wound on his neck when I took him to the station, this is the first I have heard of it.
CHARLES SHADDOCK (re-examined). The prisoner never complained to me of a wound in his neck.

Prisoner's Defence. At the House of Detention, before I had my bath, I told the man to look at my neck, it was fresh at the time and bleeding—I had been stabbed by her previously, and was compelled to force the knife from her—it was not my intention to murder her—as we lay in bed together she spat in my face, and she said, "Jack, if you don't think I am true to you, I will bury this in you," and took the knife to me—I took it from her and struck her, but not with the intention of knocking her brains in or of murdering her.

rs.hi: of intent to do grievous bodily harm—

div1.p:
773.
THOMAS PRATT (27), was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Elizabeth Frances Brockington.

CAROLINE BALL . I am a French polisher, living at 48, Golden Lane—I was going home about one o'clock on the morning of 14th September, when I saw the prisoner and another man and woman in Golden Lane—tho prisoner was showing his arm to a police constable—the woman went

into the police station in Old Street, while the prisoner waited at the bottom—in the hearing of the prisoner, she said to the policeman, "What can I do with that young man, for he won't let me go neither one way nor the other? I would rather you lock me up than I go with hum"—the policeman said, "You go your way, and he will go his"—the prisoner went towards Whitecross Street, and 1 and the woman went down Wilderness Row, which are in different directions—when we got down Wilderness Bow some distance, I saw the prisoner, who ran across the road to us—we tried to avoid him, but he caught us up—he ran in front of the woman, and made a blow at her, saying, "Liz, I have done for you now, I will do my drag for you"—the woman screamed, "Oh!" and I caught hold of her to assist her—the prisoner said, "I'd as lieve stick a knife into you as look at you"—I tried to assist her across the road, but she fell back in the middle of the road, and I was obliged to let go—a policeman came up, and she was conveyed to the station—I saw the prisoner with the policeman, and heard him say, "I'll hang for her"—he gave the policeman a knife, and said, "I have dune it; I will swing for her!"—as far as I saw, the woman gave him no pro
vocation.

Cross-examined. Before he struck the blow I did not hear him say any
thing to her—I said before the Coroner, "He got in front of her, and said, 'I'll do for you,' and then struck her in the breast"—I cannot say if it was the same constable at the police-station door that the prisoner was showing his arm to in Golden Lane—he had some bandages round his arm,—while he was showing his arm, the woman crossed over to the police Station—I also crossed over, and the prisoner stood listening, but did not say anything—the policeman refused to let her in, saying she had done nothing wrong—it was all in a minute or two after we commenced going in opposite directions that the prisoner rejoined us—the woman asked me to go home and sleep with her, saying he would not touch her if anybody was with her—I had been sleeping in a common lodging-house, and I gave the 6d. I should have to pay for my lodging there, to the woman.

GEORGE EUGENE YAREOW . I am surgeon to the G division of police—on the morning of 13th September, about one, I was called to the Old Street station, and found a woman lying on one of the benches in a state of unconsciousness from which she never recovered—she died in about ten minutes—the front of her clothing was saturated with blood—there was a punctured wound about five-eighths of an inch in length over the left breast, from which the blood was flowing—at that time I was only able to trace it about an inch downwards, but I afterwards made post-mortem examination—the knife (produced) corresponds with the wound—it had penetrated the bony substance of the third rib, and gone into the left ventricle of the heart—considerable violence must have been used—she died from the effects of that wound.

Cross-examined. There was extensive adhesion of the left lung, the result of which was to throw the heart considerably forward on the wall of the chest—with the heart in that abnormal condition it would require a wound of lesser depth and force to penetrate it than under ordinary circumstances—the wound went into the cavity of the heart.

Re-examined. Considerable violence must have been used, because the knife penetrated the bone—as a rule, when the rib is struck it yields, or breaks, or the substance is struck off, but in this case it
went directly through the bone—had the heart not been displaced the wound would have penetrated the lung—that would not necessarily have been fatal.

JAMES CROCKFORD (Policeman G 192). I was on duty in Wilderness Row about 1 o'clock on the morning of the 14th September, and saw the deceased in the road with the witness Ball—I spoke to the prisoner—he gave me the knife (produced)—he said, "I have done it, and I will swing for it"—I assisted to take the woman to the station.
Cross-examined. I do not know the meaning of the term "I'll do a drag for you"—I have never heard the phrase.

HENRY FEEK (Policeman G 235). I was on duty in "Wilderness Row at 1 o'clock on the morning of 14th September—I heard a scream, and saw two women struggling in the middle of the road—I saw the prisoner cross over towards Goswell Street, and arrested him; he said, "I am the one who done it; I am sorry for it, she drove me to it; I worked hard for that girl till I could not get any more work, and I went thieving for her: I was three months in the House of Correc
tion for her, it is done, and it cannot be helped, I must suffer for it"—he said he loved her as he loved his own life—I told him he would be charged with stabbing her, and he was taken to the station.
Cross-examined. "Drag" is a low word meaning "hanging."

THOMAS WILLIAM SCARFE . I am superintendent of the Shoeblacks' Home, 241, Marylebone Lane, formerly master of the Union Jack brigade, Limehouse—about nine years ago prisoner was under my charge in the shoeblack brigade for four years—at first he was a great trouble, of a morose, sullen disposition, and sometimes seemed unable to learn his lessons, while at others he could do them very well—we taught him the big drum music, and he would sometimes play the time and tune well, while sometimes he could not keep them at all, and we had to tap on his shoulders the time—sometimes he understood punishment, and at others would appear quite unconcerned.

p.hi: The Court considered the evidence too remote to affect the case, unless it could he proved that the prisoner was net responsible for his acts.

div1.p:
THOMAS PRATT , the prisoner's father, being totally deaf, was sworn by the oath' being written in pencil on a slate. MR. KELLY then wrote the ques
tions he desired to put to the witness also on the slate, and handed them to the Court, who ruled that the proposed evidence was too remote to affect the case.

HENRY PRATT . I am no relative of the prisoner—on the 13th, from 6 a.m. till 4 p.m., I was at work with him on board ship by the side of Millwall Docks—we were working amongst strong turpentine down the hold, where if you remained a quarter of an hour you were just as if you were drunk—we were obliged frequently to come up from the hold, and were not allowed to remain down more than a quarter of an hour—when I got home my wife thought I was drunk—I could not walk straight.

WILLIAM MELTON . I live at Midland Street, Ratcliffe Highway—I went out for a walk with the prisoner between five and six in the evening of the 13th—at Whitechapel Church we had a pot of ale—we then went to the City Road, where we had half a pint of beer each with a pennyworth of gin in it—we then walked down the City Road,

and about half-past nine as we were going home we met deceased—they loft me about half an hour, and went into a public-house—I remained outside, and was afterwards called in by the prisoner—we remained till about half-past twelve, and we had three quarterns of rum and three pints of cooper—the deceased drank the greater portion of the rum—the prisoner wet his lips, and I had none—we re
mained till closing time—then we went on to Golden Lane, she walk
ing with him and I behind them.

GUILTY —Sentence
DEATH .

774.
NICHOLAS SEIZE (48), was indicted
for a rape upon
Elizabeth Lavinia Beasley.
NOT GUILTY .

775.
JAMES SMITH (39)
PLEADED GUILTY
to forging and uttering an order for the payment of 14l. 10s. with intent to defraud—
Three Months' Imprisonment.

776.
HENRY PRESTON (40)
[Pleaded guilty: see original trial image]
, to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Fruin Bravington with intent to steal there-in—
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

777.
JAMES HENRY WHIPP (14)
, to stealing 9l. 18s. 5d. of the moneys of
Wm. Burford, his master—
[Pleaded guilty: see original trial image]
Judg
ment Respited.

778.
GEORGE WOOD (21)
, stealing 6l. of
George Baxter Smith and another, his masters, and unlawfully making a false entry in a book of account belonging to his said masters, with intent to defraud. The Prisoner

PLEADED GUILTY to the falsification of the account,
and MR. BESLEY, for the prosecution, did not proceed with the larceny—
Six Months' Imprisonment.

779.
WILLIAM JAMES MORRIS
(), Feloniously wounding
James Cox, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

JAMES COX . I live at 2, Great Windmill Street, New Cut, Lambeth—on the 22nd September, at about 8 o'clock p.m., I was at the Sea Lion public-house, Cornwall Road—I was quite sober—my brother was with me, and some one insulted him, and the man and my brother went out to fight—my brother beat him, and the man ran away—another man then came up to fight my brother—I said, "One dog, one bone"—my brother was then on the top of another man outside the public-house—I was going to pick my brother up, and when I was stooping down I felt a dig come at my forehead just above the temple—I dropped my brother and said, "Joe, this man (the prisoner) has stabbed me"—I put my hand to my forehead and my shirt was all saturated with blood in an instant—I caught Mm by the wrist in an instant—a knife was in his hand—I said, "What did you do that for?" and I up with my fist and knocked him down in self-defence and wrenched the knife from his hand—I held it up and said, "Here is the knife the man stabbed me with," and gave it to a young man named Roberts—there was a dozen going to catch hold of the knife, and I said, "Mr. Roberts, take this knife, mind it for me"—my brother Held him too, and I said, "We won't leave you till a police constable comes," and then I became unconscious till I found myself in bed in the hospital—this is the knife (produced).

Cross-examined. I never saw the prisoner before—I caught him with the knife in his hand—I said, "You stabbed me"—I called him a rogue and vagabond, or something to that effect—I said, "Joe, this rogue has stabbed me"—the struggle was going on the kerb—I should say there were a dozen or fifteen men there at the time—they were all in a ring round—I did not see the prisoner in the Sea Lion.

JOSEPH COS . I am the brother of the last witness—I live at 8, Great Windmill Street, and am a French polisher—I know the prisoner, and have seen him at the Sea Lion—on the night in question I was fighting with a man and the prisoner wanted me to fight, and said, "Come out
side and we will have a fight"—I said nothing to him—I fought a second man and fell—my brother picked me up—I didn't see what happened then, but I see blood streaming down his face—he called out, "Joe, I am stabbed"—he was standing over the prisoner, and reeled round and fell on the ground—he fainted and was taken to the hospital—I saw a knife in my brother's hand, and he told me he had taken it away from the prisoner—he and I caught hold of the prisoner and gave him to the constable.

Cross-examined. I had had no quarrel with the prisoner—he said to me, "I will have a go with you"—where I was having this fight was not far away from the kerb—there were about fifteen or twenty persons outside—not particular in a ring—some on the pavement and some out of the public-house, and the mates, I expect, of the prisoner also.

FREDERICK JEFFS (Policeman 51 L). I took the prisoner in charge and told him I was taking him for stabbing Cox in the forehead—he said nothing—Cox said nothing in the prisoner's presence—the prisoner was not drunk—he seemed very excited.

WILLIAM HENRY ROBERTS . I live at 19, Collingwood Street, Black
friars—I received a knife from Cox—I handed it to another person stand
ing by.
GEORGE PIKE (Policeman 95 L). I went to the Sea Lion after assisting to take the prisoner to the station—the landlord gave me this knife—it was covered with blood the same as it is now.

WILLIAM HENRY BATTLE . I am house-surgeon at St. Thomas's Hos
pital—Cox was brought in on the night in question—I found a punctured wound over the right side of the forehead—it measured between two and three inches in depth horizontally, and had an entrance of about three-quarters of an inch—it was such a wound as could be caused by this knife—it would require a great amount of force to inflict such a wound—it was not a dangerous wound—the wound has healed—he remained in the hospital from the Saturday till the Monday.

JAMES COX (re-examined). I do not know Henry Darling—I do not remember seeing my brother twisting a handkerchief round the neck of the prisoner and a man saying, "Let him go"—when I was on the ground there was a dozen trying to rescue him from my brother—I was at the police-court—a man said he lent the prisoner a knife—his name was not Darling.

JOSEPH COX (re-examined). I do not know Darling—the prisoner was not in such a condition that he could not speak—he asked me to let him go—a man did not come up and loose his handkerchief—I would not let go of his collar.
HENRY DARLING . I do not know this knife—on Saturday, the 22nd

September, I gave a knife to the prisoner like this at about 6.30, or 6.45—I was not with him the remainder of the day—I went away—when I came back I saw the prisoner lying down in the gutter, and three men and a woman kneeling on him, and Cox holding him—I got my knife back before I got back.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. A young chap asked me to have some beer—I said I didn't mind—these two chaps entered, and pitched on to me; and as to the knife, I never did stab him—it was not my knife at all.

p.hi: The Prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Eighteen Months' Im
prisonment.

780.
JOHAN VOGHT (20)
, Feloniously wounding
Edward Buss, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

EDWARD BUSS (interpreted). I am a sailor on board the San Paulis, which the prisoner also belonged to—one evening, I cannot say the date, I went to a public-house, and the prisoner came in afterwards—he quar
relled—I told him to be quiet, and we left to go to my vessel—when we got near the water-side the prisoner began to quarrel with another man—I said "Be quiet," and then he struck me—I fell to the ground and received several blows on the head and arms—I felt I was cut—I was carried on board ship, and afterwards to the hospital.

Cross-examined. The quarrel in the public-house was between his ship
mates, and the prisoner went between them—I can't say whether to help them fight or not—I only said to the prisoner "Be quiet"—I struck him once while in the public-house with my hand—we had a quarrel before that, and I struck him because he interfered between the, other men—I do not think I am a stronger and bigger man than he—we all went out together to go to the ship—I did not have any row with him on the way, hut he quarrelled with the others—I did not seize him by the collar—I told him to be quiet—I catched hold of him in front by his breast—we were then on the quay—I seized him because I wanted to make him quiet—I don't know what he had bought, but he had a bundle in his hand of different things—he began to strike me—he did not say "Leave me alone"—I have not seen what he struck me with—he struck with his right hand—I cannot say what the bundle was in his left hand; it was too dark to see—I will swear I never struck him only once, when I said—I didn't catch hold of him; I only had my hand like that (describing) against his breast—we had come over in the same ship as shipmates—we were not good friends; he was always at something against me.
Re-examined. I did not try to push the prisoner into the water.

JAMES TRICKER (Inspector of Thames Police). I heard cries of "Police" on this night, and on going to the place I saw a ship's boat—I went to the passage, walked up the steps, and. at the stairs' head at the top of the landing-place, five yards from there, I saw the prosecutor lying on his hack and bleeding from the head—there were seven or eight foreigners round him, all belonging to the same ship—I had the prosecutor taken down to the boat, and the prisoner was taken on board also, and then on to the ship—I found the man had lost much blood, and was very weak—I did not know he had been stabbed, but finding the man was bleeding from the neck, I took this scarf off his neck, and saw a large wound in the
neck—I said "Where is the knife, Johan?"—he said "In the water"—I did not find it.
Cross-examined. The prisoner complained of being struck—I said so before the magistrate.

WM. HUGHES . I am house surgeon at the Poplar Hospital—the prose
cutor was admitted on the 18th September—he had been bleeding very much; his clothes were saturated with blood—he had an incised wound on the left side of his head, on the back of his neck, and on his right forearm—the wound in the neck extended down to the spinal column, about 1 1/2 inches long—I should not like to say whether it penetrated—he had partial paralysis of the left side—he was in danger—the wounds could have been inflicted by a knife—he has not quite recovered from the paralysis—I think he will.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. He kicked me in the stomach, and struck me on the neck—he wouldn't leave me alone—I said "Let me alone," and he wished to throw me in the water—I said "Leave me alone, in the name of the Father and Son"—he wanted to drown me.

GUILTY —
Two Years' Imprisonment

781.
FREDERICK JOHNSTONE (30)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Hawkins, and stealing therein six pairs of boots and two pairs of soles, his property.

WILLIAM HAWKINS . I live at 12, Tufton Street, Westminster—on Friday, the 14th September, I put up the shop shutter as usual before going to bed, between 9 and 9.30—the shutter is fastened by a bar, which can be lifted up by anybody, and a bolt—in the night I heard a noise, as of the breaking of glass—I did not get up—I was sleeping in the room behind the shop—shortly afterwards policeman Beecham called me up, when I found the bar removed, the shutter down, and a pane of glass broken and six pairs of boots and two pairs of soles missing—these (produced) are some of those which were taken from my shop that night.

WILLIAM BEECHAM (Policeman B 377). I was on duty in Tufton Street on the morning of the 15th of last month, and was passing the prose
cutor's shop at about 2 a.m.—I noticed the shutter was down and a pane of glass broken—I called the prosecutor up, and he came to me at once.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. About a quarter of an hour elapsed between the time the place was broken into and your being taken into custody.
Re-examined. I had passed the shop shortly before, and found it quite safe—twenty minutes elapsed between my first going to the shop and my finding it broken open.

WILLIAM WHYBROW (Policeman B 193). I was on duty in Great St. Peter's Street on the morning in question, about three or four minutes' walk from the prosecutor's—I saw the prisoner, who passed me, and I followed him back—I saw something at his side, and I asked him what he had, and he dropped a pair of boots—this is one of the pairs before me—I saw another boot hanging down, which I took from him and took him to the station—when I got there I found three other pairs and two pairs of soles on him—he said a man gave them to him to carry—it was about 2.20 when we got to the station—on my way back, after I had taken him to the station, I met the prosecutor coming to the station.

Cross-examined. I was going towards the prosecutor's—you walked faster than I did—I followed you about two rods behind—you did not attempt to run away—I found three pairs of boots and two pairs of socks on you, and 4d.—you went to the station quietly.
Prisoner's Defence. If I had broken the place open it isn't likely I should be about the place with them boots under my coat—you would naturally think I should try to get away from the place.

GUILTY —
Six Months' Imprisonment.

782.
WILLIAM CUTHBEKTSON (23)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Eliza Newcombe, with intent to murder her.

ELIZA NEWCOMBE . I am nineteen years old, and am now in St. Bartholomew's Hospital—in January this year I left my situation, and went to live with the prisoner—he is a hairdresser's assistant—we lived at 27, Cowper Street, Islington, in July, and I had charge of Mrs. Barth's baby, who lodged in the same house, while she was out all day at her business—the baby was subject to convulsion fits—on 25th July Mrs. Barth wanted me to go and have the baby's likeness taken—I did not tell the prisoner where I was going, but I asked him whether I could go out—I gave him the key in case I did not get back in time—my sister went with me, and on our way home I called where the prisoner was employed, and got the key from him—I went home and prepared tea, and he came home about. six o'clock, and said that I had been rather too long—I said that I had not been longer than I could help, and showed him the baby's photograph—he said that I had no business to have it taken, wasting my money—I said that my sister paid for it—she was not present—we began tea, and in the middle of it he asked to see the picture again, and he deliberately broke it on the corner of a chair, and threw it on the fire, and smacked me in the face once or twice—I think I flew at him, it was in self-defence if I did, and he struck me again in the chest with his fist, I believe—until he smacked my face I had done nothing to provoke him that I am aware of—on the morning of the 26th he went to his work, and came home to breakfast about 10 o'clock, having shaved off his moustache and whiskers—I said "What have you done that for? what a boy you look"—he said "I have had a clean shave to "swing for you in"—I said "I am glad you let me know"—we breakfasted in Mrs. Barth's room that morning because the baby was so ill, but Mrs. Barth was not present, she had gone to her work—as we were sitting down to breakfast the prisoner said to me "If you have got anything to say you had better say it, as you have not much longer to live; you may live another half hour, and you may live till to-morrow"—I said "You have threatened me so often, I take no notice of your threats"—he never said anything for ever so long, and then he got up off his chair and threw himself across the hearthrug—I asked him to get up, but he made no reply—I went downstairs, and came up again, and he was still on the hearthrug—I said "Mr. Pick
ford," that is his employer, "has sent for you, and wants to know if you are going back to your work"—he said that he was never going to do any

more work, and I need not trouble myself—I then asked him to go into our own room, but he made no answer, still lying on the hearthrug—I washed the baby, and it had two fits—I then put the tea things away and went into our own room, and then downstairs and saw Mrs. Oliver the landlady—I then went up to Mrs. Barth's room, and the prisoner—was sitting on a chair—I said "Mrs. Oliver is coming to ask you for the rent" and Mrs. Oliver walked in behind me. and asked him for the rent—this was about 11 o'clock—he said "I will give you a fortnight next Monday"—she said "Very well," and left the room—I asked him why he did not give Mrs. Oliver the rent—he said "Before I give her the rent her house will be in the Police News"—he did not take in the Police News, but I think they sold it, or had it at the shop—I said "We should make two nice pictures for the Police News"—a short time after that I asked him for a penny to get half a pint of beer—he said that I need not trouble myself, I should not want any more pennies for beer out of him—I went and got half a pint of beer with a penny of my own, and brought it back—he drank a very little of it, and I finished it—when he was drinking it he said "My love to you, and I hope you will be better tempered the next time we have a drop more together"—I said "I have no doubt we shall," or something to that effect—I then noticed that the child was in a fit, and went across to it, and as I did so I said to the prisoner "You had better go out for a walk, or else I will"—he said "Next time you go out it will be in a cab to the hospital"—I cannot remember what I said, and I think he went into his own room—I took the child downstairs, and brought it up again, and laid it down—the prisoner was then there, and I said "I wish you would keep in your own room"—I do not think he made any answer—I was sitting at the side of the bed looking at the baby, who was in a fit, and the prisoner shut the door and the window, and came towards me—I said "Bill, look at this child"—he made no more to do, but hit me on the back of my head deliberately with a chopper, which I first saw when it was lifted in his hand to strike—it was Mrs. Barth's chopper, and had been in a corner of that room—I said "Bill, before you hit me again think what you are doing it for, and what excuse you will make"—he said "I will soon find some excuse"—he kept on repeating the blows, and I fell off the side of the bed, and saw him change the chopper into his left hand—I said "Bill, if you hit me once more you will kill me"—he said "That is what I want to do"—how I got up I do not know, but I got to the door—I kept continually screaming, I think, till I lost my senses—just as I got to the top of the steps a person who lives next door came to my assistance—I saw her on the stairs.

Cross-examined. Directly I went to live with him he proposed to marry me, and I think he commenced to save up money for that purpose, and I believe he gave it to his master to keep for him—after which he fell ill, and was for some time in the doctor's hands, and for the time the marriage was spoken of no more—when he broke the likeness and I flew at him I do not think he was smoking a pipe—I do not remember smashing a pipe in his mouth—he usually smoked after tea, but that was in the middle of tea—I flew at him quite in self-defence—I did not kick him—I never used my foot in my life that I can remember to him—I once tried to bite him when he had his hand across my throat; not this time, some time ago—I may have endeavoured to dash the pipe from his mouth—when I

asked him for a penny for beer I did not stamp my foot in front of him, I did not feel so inclined—I never in my life spat in his face—I did not dare him to touch me—I do not remember snatching a pan from the table—there was no pan but one, which I left in my own room on the drawers, clean and quite empty—I did not pass it towards him as if I was going to throw it at him—I washed the baby in Mrs. Barth's room, but I never attempted to throw the pan, that was before the blows were given—I only moved the pan from one chair to another, and he laid on the floor nearly all that time—he struck me with the proper side of the chopper which they chop wood with, but it is not very sharp—the prisoner was sitting near the cupboard where Mrs. Barth keeps her wood, and in which the chopper was kept.

ELIZA OLIVER . I live at 28, Cowper Street, and am a widow—I have the letting of No. 27—I asked the prosecutrix for the rent on 26th July, and the prisoner said that he would pay me two weeks at once on the Monday—I heard no screaming, but the prosecutrix afterwards called me and I went upstairs and saw her with her head bleeding and the prisoner standing by the window with his hands up to his eyes—I ran to fetch a doctor.
Cross-examined. The door of Mrs. Barth's room was open.

BETSY GLADWELL . I am the wife of William Gladwell, of 27, Cowper Street—on 26th July Mrs. Bell called me and I went up to the first land
ing and saw the prisoner standing with his hands over his eyes—I said, "What have you done?"—he made no answer—I asked him a second time, and the prosecutrix said, "I am dying, he has nearly killed me"—she was a few stairs up towards the next floor—I saw that she was wounded, and wiped the blood from her face—she asked me to let her go to my room—I said, "It is too far for you"—she said, "Oh, let me come," and she did go, and she was sent to the hospital—the prisoner said nothing and was locked into his own room till a policeman came.

THOMAS MAYNARD (Police-Inspector G). On 26th July I saw the prose
cutrix in St. Bartholomew's Hospital—I then went to 27, Cowper Street, and found that the prisoner had been taken to the station—the counter
pane, sheets, and the child's white frock were all covered with blood, and in the centre of the bed I found this piece of hair (produced), which appears to have been chopped off somebody's head—it is the same colour as the girl's hair—I found blood stains on the floor, and four marks made by a blunt instrument like this chopper, also several pieces of hair wet with blood, which appeared to have been chopped off, and at the foot of the bed I picked up another piece—the chopper had been taken away—I saw a small pan by the side of the bed with dirty water in it as if somebody had been washing, and some of it was upset on the floor.

WILLIAM LONDON (Policeman G 158). On 26th July about 2.45 I went to a first-floor front room at 27, Cowper Street, and found this chopper (produced) lying near the bed with blood and hair on the blade and handle—I then went into the back room and found the prisoner sitting on the bed—I told him I should take him for violently assaulting his wife and striking her on the head with a chopper—he said, "I am very sorry, I know I have done wrong."
MARIA ANN BARTH . I lived at 27, Cowper Street at this time—this chopper is mine—I kept it in the fireplace to cut wood.
WILLIAM GAMMON ARCHER . I was house-surgeon at St. Bartholomew's

Hospital on 26th July—I admitted Eliza Newcombe that afternoon, and found fifteen wounds on her scalp, some incised and some lacerated—they must have been done with different parts of the same instrument—the blade is rough in some places and smooth in others—there were three fractures of the skull; two of them went completely through and exposed the brain pulsating beneath its membranes—the bone had been chopped through, and four pieces of bone had been chopped off other parts of the skull—there was also a contusion under her eye—she was in a very dangerous condition, and a magistrate came next day to take her depo
sition—I have seen her daily since—she will, I think, recover, but she will always be subject to fainting fits on very slight excitement.

p.hi: The. Prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Twenty Years' Penal Servitude.

783.
ARTHUR EDWARD FREDERICK BOULTON, Feloniously
attempting to discharge a loaded pistol at
Solomon Levy with intent to do—him grievous bodily harm.

SOLOMON LEVY . I am a wholesale clothier, of 38, Upper East Smith-field—on 18th October, about 3 p.m., I was in the billiard-room of the "Woolpack, Minories—the prisoner came in, made a remark upon the manner in which some one made a stroke, and then he said that he would play any one for a half-sovereign or a sovereign—Mr. Arnett answered him in a joking kind of way "All right, I will play you!"—after the game which was being played was over, the prisoner took up a cue and attempted to strike a ball, and Mr. Arnett and the prisoner appeared about to commence—they both made two or three ineffectual strokes, knocking the balls about, and the marker said "I will have none of this nonsense, there are gentlemen waiting to play," and took the cue out of the prisoner's hands—the prisoner then walked across the room to a young man on the opposite side, saying "I will have my half-sovereign I have staked"—to my perfect knowledge, he had never drawn any money out; in fact, the marker said that he would not have any gambling—I am positive he never staked any money—several persons said at once "You never staked any money!"—he then attempted to strike the young man—the marker got between them and said "You shall not fight!"—he attempted to catch the marker by the throat, but he was too quick for him, and caught him by his throat with one hand and by his wrist with the other, and pushed him towards the door—I opened the door, and the marker put him out, and told some one to ring the bell—the potman came up, and the prisoner was put downstairs—hearing that he was making a disturbance downstairs, I saw him outside on the pavement, and some coppers rolling about which were handed to him, he picked some up himself, and from a stooping position he turned towards the door, looked round deliberately at everybody standing there, drew a pistol from behind him, and presented it at my head—I was about two feet from him—I had never spoken to him—I ducked my head to avoid the shot, and the next thing I saw was that Mr. Brown had collared him on one side by the right wrist, and Detective Hutt on the other—the pistol was in his right hand—on the way to the station I saw blood on Mr. Brown's hand, and at the station I saw the inspector draw seven charges from the pistol—the prisoner said to me "I am sorry I did not shoot you, you son of a bitch,
I will give it you when I come out"—he said that over and over again, and he said to the detective "I will give it to you too"—no doubt he had been drinking a little, but he appeared sober.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I could not see whether the revolver was on full cock.

RICHARD BROWN . I live at 3, Devonport Street, Commercial Road, and am a stevedore—on 18th October I was playing at billiards with Mr. Arnett, and saw the prisoner come in—he wanted to play Mr. Arnett for half a sovereign, but Mr. Arnett would not—the prisoner took up a cue and said "This is the way to hit the balls!"—Mr. Arnett took a cue and did not hit the balls—the marker said "I cannot have this nonsense," and took the cue away—the prisoner went up to a young man and said "I demand my half-sovereign I deposited with you"—he said "You deposited no half-sovereign"—the prisoner got into a fighting attitude—the marker got between them, and the prisoner was put out—I was after
wards told that he had a pistol in his possession—I went down, saw a little scuffle in the passage, and the prisoner was shoved out on to the pavement—he got up, put his right hand behind him, and drew a revolver and pointed it at Mr. Levy—I caught him by the hand, and took hold of the revolver, and the nipple came down on my hand; here is the wound it made, so that it must have been at full cock—he was given in custody—I had not seen him give any money to any one.

Cross-examined. I said before the Lord Mayor "There was a tussle, and the hammer came down"—there was little tussle in getting it away—I do not think I could have cocked it in that way—you had a pistol pocket, made for the purpose of carrying a revolver.

WILLIAM COOPER .
