I rent the billiard-room at the Woolpack—on 18th December the prisoner came in about 3 o'clock—four gentlemen were playing at billiards, and he challenged the worst player of the four to play for a half-sovereign, but playing for money is not allowed—he went down and came up with his coat off, and began knocking the balls about—I picked up the balls as he was talking a lot of nonsense, and said "This won't suit me; you had better go somewhere else and play"—he said to a gentleman there "I will take my stake money"—he said "What do you mean?" and the prisoner squared up at him—I went between them—he tried to seize me by the throat, but I was too quick for him, and seized him—I asked a gentleman to ring for the potman, who came up, and I said "Show that gentleman outside"—I did not see the prisoner produce any money.

ALFRED BLACKMAN . I am potman and waiter at the Woolpack—I went upstairs when the bell rang, and they had got the prisoner outside the door—he asked me the marker's name—I said "I will tell you downstairs"—he went down and asked for the bos, meaning the landlord—I said "He is upstairs lying down"—he placed his left hand on my shoulder and his right behind him, pulled out a revolver, and said "My dear boy, I have got a small instrument here which I mean doing some mischief with to those upstairs if I do not get my half-sovereign"—I told him if he had been done out of a half-sovereign I would send for the landlord, and he would go up and try to rectify it, but he laughed at me and would not take any notice—he then said he wanted to see the God d—bos, and if he did not see the bos in less than two minutes he would force his way into the billiard-room—I said "It is 100 to 1 that you don't"—he tried

to go to the staircase, and I called out "John, you go upstairs, you know the gentlemen better than I do; you ask which of them has go this half-sovereign"—two gentlemen then came out of the billiard-room downstairs—the prisoner said that he would not go out until he saw the bos—he was pushed out on to the pavement, and fell on his back, and some coppers fell out of his jacket-pocket—he picked some up, and some people picked up the others and gave them to him—he put them in his pocket, put his hand behind him, and drew out a revolver—I sang out "Here comes the revolver"—he presented it at Mr. Levy's head, and Brown reached over my shoulder and seized his wrist, and took it away—he showed it to me three times inside the house—it was not cocked—the fourth time was outside.

WILLIAM HUTT (City Detective). On 18th October I went to this billiard-room to see a gentleman—I saw the prisoner take a cue up and attempt to strike a ball—the marker saw that the other gentleman did not intend to play, and took the cue out of the prisoner's hand, and said "I will have no nonsense"—the prisoner walked up to a young man, and said "Where is my half sovereign?"—the young man seemed frightened, and said "I have no money of yours"—the marker stepped between them, grasped him by the throat, and he was taken downstairs—afterwards they said that he had a revolver, and I went down behind Mr. Brown—he attempted to stop Mr. Collins, who pushed him out on the pavement—some coppers fell out of his pocket which were picked up—I heard Black
man say "He has got a revolver"—Brown and the potman seized him, and Brown took the revolver from his hand—I seized his right hand, twisted him round, and said "I am a police officer; I shall take you in custody"—he said "D——you, I will shoot you"—I said "I will bet you don't"—I did not see whether the revolver was cocked or not—the charge was drawn at the station—there were seven chambers loaded with bullets—he said that he was very sorry he had not settled some of us, and he would do it, and that he would shoot me—he was perfectly sober, but no doubt he had been drinking.

JOHN EGAN (Police Inspector). The prisoner was brought to Seething Lane station—I read the charge to him, and he said "I wish I had shot somebody"—I drew the charges; these are the bullets (produced).

p.hi: The prisoner in his Defence stated that he had just landed from the United States, where he was in the habit of carrying a pistol, and thought it safer to keep it in his pocket than to leave it on a table, and having taken two or three glasses of stout, which he was not accustomed to, he did not know what occurred, and that the pistol must have got cocked in the struggle.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

784.
JAMES SINCLAIR (37),
GEORGE RYAN (28), and
ISAAC BLED (49)
, Stealing eight bales of wool of the
London and St. Katharine's Dock Company, the masters of Sinclair and Ryan.

JOHN YOUNG . I live at Globe Street, and am in the Company's service—it is my duty to lock up the crescent warehouse at sis at night and unlock it at sis in the morning—none of the men have any right to stop there during the night—before locking up I call "All out"—On the 28th September, when I unlocked at sis o'clock in the morning, I saw Bird, who is an extra labourer—I went straight up to him and asked

"How came you here? Were you drunk? Did you get locked in by accident?"—he said "Oh no, nothing of the sort"—I said "Where did you sleep?"—he said "That is nothing to do with you, you need not trouble yourself about that, I am not alone; we have a man named Jimmy here"—Jimmy is Sinclair—I—went with him and saw Sinclair in what we call the big room—he was sewing up a bale—I said "Hallo Jim, what do you do here? locked yourself up so that the rats don't get in while you are asleep?"—he said "We have got a job on, and we are doing it, it is nothing to do with you"—I left them, but shortly afterwards saw them again, when Bird said "Look here, you run no risk in anything of this sort; if you want anything in the shape of money you can have it"—I said "I do not under
stand it"—I think they said I could have 10s. at once if I liked—I said "No, no; nothing of that sort"—I did not see Ryan at all daring that time—at their request I had some gin-and-milk with them, and then we separated for breakfast—when they came in again I said "Look here, what were you doing of?"—they said "Well now, it is nothing at all to do with you, we have got a job to do; you run no risk, we have got to make up some bales to bring in, and they will be called land carriages: the bales will be brought in, the order will be brought back again from the City, and the order received in the regular way, the bales weighed, brought forward when, required, and there it is; it will pay us well to do so, and if you want a sovereign you can have it"—I informed Mr. Hunt at ten minutes to eight.

THOMAS GRIGG . I am superintendent of the Dock Company's Police—on 28th September I received information and sent for Sinclair and Bird, and saw them separately—I said to-Sinclair "I learn you were at our warehouse last night," and told him it was a serious matter, and cautioned him—he said "It was arranged with foreman Ryan about a month ago that I, Bird, and another man by the name of Carr should be in the warehouse and make up some bales of wool; I and Carr remained in one night, about the 13th, and made up two bales: on the following night we stopped in again and made up two more, making in all four bales, which on the following day were put into the scale; Ryan told us to mark them A. M. and a diamond No. I to 4, which was done"—Sinclair then said he had received about 30s. for that transaction, and afterwards received a few shillings at the time, about 10s. more—he said "Nothing more transpired until the previous day, when Ryan came to Sinclair and said 'You had better stop in again to-night with Bird and Carr and make up four bales more, get them marked A. M. diamond No. 5 to 8,' which we did; the bags were brought to the scale and there they remain ready to be—weighed"—I asked Bird what he had to say, and he said he knew nothing about the wool whatever; that he was working in the wool warehouse on the previous day, and that having left his jacket in the foreman's box he went there to get it, and on his return he found the door locked, and rather than make any bother in reference to his being locked in, he remained there all night; but he admitted having seen Sinclair there about five o'clock in the morning—I afterwards brought them to
gether, and read each other's statements so that they knew what each had said—I then sent for Ryan, and told him what Sinclair had said—Ryan said "It is no good denying facts, it is true; I have done it to make too ends meet"—I said "It is a very serious matter, and whatever you

have to say may be made use of as evidence"—he said "I cannot help it; I may as well say it, and make a clean breast of it"—he said a person of the name of Hammond, about two months ago, asked him to get some bales of wool, and about the 13th September he prepared four bales, got them to the sale, passed them through the sale, and received 27l. as the produce, which he divided between himself, Sinclair, Bird, and Carr—I showed Evan the order (produced) A. M. I to 4, and asked him if he knew anything about it—he said "Yes, I received it from Mr. Hammond and have acted upon it"—he then said he saw Mr. Hammond on the 27th, and arranged to get four bales more—the four bales were marked "A. M. diamond 5 to 8," and they were placed ready for the scale, where I afterwards found them—I then called Bird in the presence of Ryan, and told him that Ryan had said it was arranged for him to re
main in with other men, and Ryan said "No good to be downhearted; tell the truth"—Bird said "Well, it is no good to deny it; I did remain in for one night, about the 13th, and we made up two or three bales then: I remained in last night and we made up four bales more, and we marked them A. M. and a diamond; I do not know whether they went to the scales"—the prisoners had no right to make up those bales, and no right to be in the warehouse at all.

RICHARD HENRY SLOCOMB . I am clerk to Mr. Mellor, who is clerk to the Great Eastern Railway Company—I wrote the order produced marked A—I received a copy from Mr. Hammond in. the presence of Mr. Mellor in the Wool Exchange, addressed to the superintendent of the London Docks—I copied it, and handed it back to Mr. Mellor—I went down to the docks daily during the sales—I saw Ryan and Hammond there—on the 14th September Hammond told me to ask Ryan to let him have the weights of the four bales—he did not say what four bales—I did not know what he meant—I told Ryan, and he said "I will see Mr. Ham
mond in Coleman Street."

JAMES MELLOR . I am an officer of the Great Eastern Railway Com
pany, and acquainted with Mr. Hammond—previous to 12th September he came to me about writing some orders for him, giving me drafts of what he wanted written—I directed Mr. Slocomb to write that of the 15th—I think it is A. M. I to 4—the other I copied myself, and gave the copy to Hammond—I know Ryan as the foreman of the dock warehouse—I sent the documents on to Messrs. Jacomb and Co. at Hammond's direction, and afterwards received this cheque (produced) for 56l. 9s. 1d. from Messrs. Jacomb after the sale on loth September, and paid it to Mr. Hammond—I endorsed it—it is made payable to me.

FREDERICK CHARLES JACOMB . I am a wool-broker of the firm of Jacomb, Son, and Co., of 61, Moorgate Street—I received the order A. M. I to 4, and in consequence placed in my sale of loth September the four bales of wool—they were lotted 17, and the sale effected on that day for 56l. 9s. 1d.—I signed a delivery order for a number of bales, in which those four are included—the goods were delivered to my order from the Dock Com
pany—the cheque produced was given to Mr. Mellor by our firm—there are a great number of purchasers go to the docks when the bales are on show—every bale is shown—they pull out pieces of wool to examine it, and sometimes cut the bale right open and take out half the bale.
FREDERICK WILLETT . I am cheque clerk to the Dock Company, and Ryan is foreman of the wool warehouse—Sinclair is a permanent

labourer, and Bird is an extra labourer—on the 14th of September Evan gave me this order (produced)—it was my duty to see the bales weighed and take the weights, and hand the orders up, for the weights to pass through the books of Company—Ryan simply told me to weigh the bales mentioned in the order, or see them weighed—if for land carriage the foreman would send them out—I saw a cart there—the other order (produced) was also given me by Ryan, and the bales were brought up, and they were weighed in the regular course—none of the labourers have any right to stay there all night, or to touch any of the wool in the packing-room to make up into bales—the wool in the packing-room is used to fill up deficiencies—Ryan is warehouse foreman, not delivery foreman—it was his duty to receive goods coming by land carriage, and see them sent up to me to weigh.
ARCHIBALD ROWAN . I am delivery clerk to the Dock Company—I remember receiving this delivery order of Messrs. Jacomb and Co., and signed it clear for the delivery foreman to deliver by.
MATTHEW BLACKBOROUGH . I am clerk to the Dock Company, and in the course of business received this order (produced), and passed it on to Mr. Potter.
ARTHUR POTTER . I am foreman in the Company's service—I received this order and passed it on to Lowman.

PHILIP LOWMAN . I received the order from the last witness—I packed up the bales described in the order, and found the tickets upon them—these were marked Jacomb and Son's Sale lot 717 A. M. (2, 3, 4)—I issued a pass for them, and delivered them into a van.

p.rs: GUILTY. Recommended to mercy on account of being tools in the hands of Hammond—

div1.p:
785.
WILLIAM POULTON (22), and
THOMAS WILCOX (18)
, Feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Eliza Ann Wood, with intent to steal.

CHARLES BUTCHER (Detective C Division). About twenty minutes to one a.m. on 9th October I was in Jermyn Street—when I got about the second house past Wood's Hotel, which is No. 102, I saw the two prisoners and another man not in custody standing all three together—I went down York Street, and returned in four or five minutes, when I saw they had all shifted—Poulton was against the railings by himself, perhaps thirty-five yards from Wood's Hotel—I watched him for ten minutes, when Cain, another detective officer, came up—Poulton stood facing us on the opposite side, and gave a shrill whistle, loud enough for any one to hear fifty yards off—almost immediately after two men jumped over the rails from Wood's Hotel—Wilcox was one, and the other I have never seen since—there was an area on the other. side of the railings ten or eleven feet deep—Wilcox and the other man walked quietly along Jermya Street, turned up Eagle Place, and when they turned the corner Cain and I ran after them—we lost sight of them—we went into Piccadilly, and could not see them anywhere—Poulton then passed

us into Piccadilly, and we turned and followed him—he turned round Great Windmill Street, and after that we took him into custody—it was perhaps five minutes from the time they left the area railings that we apprehended Poulton—I told him he would be charged with, two others for coming out of Wood's Hotel, Jermyn Street—he said he knew nothing about it—I took him to the station—I then went back to Jermyn Street, and saw Wilcox standing against a post in York Street, about thirty-five yards from Wood's Hotel—I am quite satisfied that the prisoner is the man I previously saw get over the railings—he had a peculiar scarf on, and I noticed him particularly—I asked Wilcox what he was waiting there for—he said he was waiting for a friend—I said "Your friend is at the station in Vine Street"—I then took him to the station, and told him what he would be charged with—I then re
turned to Wood's Hotel and examined the premises—I rang the bell, and the housekeeper came down, and we went into the area—she un
done the inside door with a key and bolts—the chain had been undone—and I then saw the outer door standing open about four inches—a glass had been broken, through which anybody could get at the chain from outside—there was a pair of wooden steps in the area, made on purpose for the area steps—I ascertained they had been laid down in the area, but they were then in their usual place leading up out of the area, so that anybody getting over the railings could slide down, and then put the steps against the wall and get up—I examined the area, and could see somebody had been over the rails and slid down.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Poulton gave me his address, and I went to it and found it right—I made inquiries about him—he would not tell me where he worked—the other did—I saw Poulton's mother—she said she did not know where he worked at the present time—I do not know that he worked at the Horse Shoe Hotel as copper
man under the cook—it was about forty yards from Jermyn Street, along Piccadilly, that I met Poulton—he whistled; not a tune, I am quite sure—it was not one of the other men that whistled—I thought it was to give the other men notice—when I went down York Street and came back Poulton was standing alone—he had passed me so close that I could not fail to recog
nise him as the one I had seen in Jermyn Street—he did not run away—Poulton's mother told me before I asked her that he did not leave there till something after 12 o'clock, and thought he had been drinking—she might have said that he had been out and came in after 12 o'clock—she did not say she had blowed him up for coming in late, and that was why he went out again, but that he had been there after 12, been drinking, and gone out again.

Cross-examined by MR. A. JAMES. The prisoners denied all knowledge of each other when brought together—Wilcox gave me a correct address, and the name of his employer, which was also correct—I did not mention about a scarf before the police magistrate—it was a worsted scarf, with two or three colours in it, blue and white, I think, and violet, and the same pin in it as he is wearing now—there was a street-lamp standing close to where we were—the houses are mostly shops there—there were two private houses where Wood's Hotel is and then a box manufacturer's, and then a newspaper shop—I should say I was twenty-five or thirty yards off when Wilcox came over the area railings—the lamp I refer to is attached to the next house to Wood's Hotel, and is, I should say, four

or five yards from where the men leaped over—Regent Street would be crowded at that time of the morning, and the Haymarket, no doubt—they were a long way from the Haymarket—I said before the magistrate we vent after them—I did not see them run—I have never made a mis
take as to identity—I never had a case in which a man named Bell was charged with sheep-stealing—I made some inquiry as to Wilcox's family—he was not living with his family, but with people he has lived with since he was a boy—they were very respectable—Poulton's address was Edward Street, Wardour Street, Oxford Street—on the very night of this affair I went up to the address of Wilcox—I found no sign of any house-breaking implements either in the house or on his person.

WILLAM CAIN (Detective C Division). At about 1 o'clock on the morn
ing of the 9th October I saw Butcher in Jermyn Street, at the corner of York Street—in consequence of what he told me I stood there with him for a few minutes—I saw Poulton on the opposite side of the way just against the rails of St. James's Church—after staying there a few minutes he gave a shrill whistle, not very loud—then he crossed over to the corner of York Street, and a few minutes after I saw two men jump out of the area from "Wood's Hotel over the rails—I have no doubt that "Wilcox was one—I followed Wilcox and the other man not in custody, and then lost sight of them up Eagle Place—I returned with Butcher and saw Poulton in Piccadilly—we followed him up Piccadilly—he was about 100 yards from the hotel—Sergeant Butcher stopped him and took Mm to the station.

Cross-examined by MR. A. JONES. I made some inquiry about Wilcox—I found he had a very good character for the eight months he had been with his present employers, Novello the music publishers—I also found he had been formerly in the employ of Woodfall's for two and a half years—he has been out on bail.

JANE GOODALL . I am the book-keeper at Wood's Hotel, Jermyn Street—I put the chain up at about twenty-five minutes or a quarter to one on the morning in question—I left the door open to admit air—when the constable aroused me we went down in the area and found the wooden steps up against the railings—when we went to bed they were lying down the side.
Cross-examined by MR. A. JOKESM. I cannot say how far the street lamp is from where the man got over—I think it is not the next house, but I am not certain.

Poulton's Statement before the Magistrate. "I have been keeping company with a young woman for four years, and last night I was at the Oxford Music Hall, and went to Jermyn Street to meet a young chap who used to work with me—I stopped twenty minutes, and could see nothing of him, and turned to go home, and I was stopped in Great Windmill Street—I told him yes I had been in Jermyn Street—I never saw Wilcox in my life." Wilcox says. " At twenty-five minutes to one I was in Crown Street talking to a friend—I went down St. Martin's with him as far as Palace Yard, and came across St. James's Square—I stopped at a post to get a light—this gentleman came up and asked me what I was doing—I said I was only lighting my pipe, and he took me—I don't know this man or this house."
NOT GUILTY .

786.
JOHN GRANT (30)
, Unlawfully conspiring with one
John Draper, not in custody, to rob
Robert Johnson of divers of his moneys.

ROBERT JOHNSON . I live at Lugar, in Ayrshire, and am a surgeon in practice there—on the 16th August I came up to London for a holiday, and on the 24th I went down to Croydon to see the races—when I went on the course Grant, turning to me, asked if I knew the names of the horses walking about—I told him I did not, and immediately after
wards I turned to go away—he came after me and said "I think you are a Scotchman; I am a Scotchman too"—he said "I am here just now for holidays"—he asked me first if I was, and I said "Yes"—he told me his name was Grant—that he belonged to Paisley, his father was a shawl manufacturer there, and that he had a brother in the firm—soon after Draper came up, and Grant turned to me and said "Here is a friend of mine coming who does some betting for me," and he told me he was brother to the great jockey, Cannon—he introduced him to me as "Cannon," and they spoke aside to each other for a minute or two—he turned to go away, and when he had gone eight or ten yards, Grant came after mo and said to him, "You might see what you can do for my friend here"—he turned round and held up his hand and said "All right"—I went on—I turned round to Grant and said "I didn't come here to bet; I am not going to bet at all, I know nothing about it"—a short time afterwards Draper came back, put a ticket for a bet made in the hand of Grant, and handed one to me—I said I didn't authorise him to make any bets for me and refused to take the ticket at first—Draper said "Oh, I understood I was to make a bet for you"—I objected again, and Grant said "Oh, it is all right"—Draper said, when I objected to pay the money, "Oh, but I have paid the money for you"—I think it was 2l.—that having been represented to me, although I had not authorised him to do so, I gave him the money—Draper then went away—I thought I was in duty bound to pay the money—I took them to be gentlemen—Draper came back—I think it was after a race was run—he said there had been a bet on, and that I had won 6l. 10s.—I thought he was going to hand me the money, but he said "I have made another bet for 10l."—I objected again, and Grant said "It is all right"—I was asked for more money—I had only a 5l. note in my pocket at the time, and I was induced to give it him—Draper said I was owing him something for what he had paid for me, I cannot tell how much—the next time he came running back after the next race, and said "Oh, I have lost you 10l.," but before the race finished he had made another bet for me, whereby I had won 40l.—he said he had risked 20l., but won 40l.—I said "I am not going to have any more of this"—I told him I wished to get away—when they saw I was anxious to get away one of them said he would go and see if he could find the bookmaker, and let him come out and see if he could make arrangements for me to go away—he repre
sented that I had won some money—Draper went over to where the crowd was, and came back and said "The bookmaker will be here after the next race to see you"—he went away again and left Grant and myself together, and came back and said that he had backed a horse for 15l. for me—I think I got a ticket twice—it seemed just like a visiting card, with a man's name on it—I objected again to the man betting on

my account—Grant said "Oh, it is all right, you have won more money than you can possibly lose"—the bookmaker was a man rather under the medium height, well built—he came out shortly after the race was run in which they said they had lost 15l. for me—I had one of the racing cards in my hand, and Grant told me to give him my card, and asked for the loan of my pencil, and reckoned up on my card the amount they said they had lost for me, and the amount they said I had won—they said they had lost altogether 35l., exclusive of the 7l. I had given them, and they had won for me 60l.—I said "That being so, you should hand to me 25l."—they were all speaking together—they said that the money I had lost would have to be paid before the money won would be given—I said it was a very strange proceeding; I was going away, and must make some arrangement, and the bookmaker made arrangements with the two others to meet at the Cannon Street Hotel at, I think, about 7 or 7.30 o'clock—they said they would go with me, which they did, and we went out of the racecourse on to Norwood Junction to Victoria, from Victoria to Kennington Park, and then they stopped at a public-house there till I went to my lodgings—I got my pocket-book, and found I had 27l. in it in notes and gold—I went back to the public-house, and found them standing outside—the cab was kept—we drove from there to a place where Grant said he stayed, some hotel in Aldersgate—he got out, and said he would be away for a few minutes; he would go to his hotel for Mb money—he was away about two minutes or so, and when he came back he had in his hand what looked like a bank-note—I did not see the face of it; it was folded up, and what appeared to be some sovereigns on the top—he said he was sorry, he found he had not so much money as he thought; that he would not be able to pay all the money he had lost, but he gave it to Cannon, saying to him "I will give you my money, and you can arrange with, the bookmaker; "and turning to me he said "You had better give him your money also," and I handed the 27l. to him—we were driving to Cannon Street—I might mention that on getting into the cab before that Cannon began speaking to me about his kinship—he told me he knew very little about London; that he was only in London occasionally—we then drove near to Cannon Street Hotel—we had to go down some street to get to it—I went with the prisoner and Draper into the station, on the platform, where we found the young man represented to be the bookmaker—Cannon and he went apart and spoke to one another, and Grant remained with me—after they had spoken aside for a time, they came and said to me ""We will go round to the private bar and we will arrange the matter there"—the bookmaker and Draper went first—Grant kept beside me, and we followed a few yards behind—when we got in, Draper and the bookmaker went to the far side of the private bar and had some conversation there; and Grant remained the other side speaking to me—after they had spoken for a minute or so, they came across, and the bookmaker addressing me said he was sorry that all the money was not forthcoming, but that Mr. Cannon (Draper) had promised to get the rest of the money by the morning, and if we all met at 9 o'clock the next morning at the same place they would pay the money that was alleged to have been won—the bookmaker imme
diately went out, and I, turning to the other two, said "Well, I have not got any money"—Grant asked Draper if he could not give me some—he said he had got some silver, and he took some silver out of his

pocket and held it out in his hand—I said I had nothing to take me home, so I took a florin—that was outside the station—about two minutes afterwards we left the place, and I went one way and they went another—before separating, however, Draper said to me "We had better be here at a quarter to nine in the morning"—I got there at half-past eight the next morning, and stayed till half-past nine—I never saw any of them—I then called at all the hotels in Aldersgate, and gave information to the police—on the afternoon of the 27th August I was walking down the Strand, near Charing Cross Railway station, when I met Grant and Draper with a stranger—when Draper saw me he turned round as if to move away, and I went up and said to him "What have you done with my money?"—"Oh," he said, "you have not kept your appointment"—"Oh yes," I said, I had, but they had not—"Oh," they said, "all right, no fear of that"—I said it was not all right, and that I believed they were a couple of swindlers—then they got indignant, and said they had no time to wait, and Draper began to run, and Grant was going to likewise—I collared him, and called for a policeman who was on the opposite side of the way, and gave him into custody—Draper had walked off quickly—I pointed him out to the policeman, and said "I give that man in charge too"—he told me to go after him, as he saw a policeman a little farther on—I went after him, and saw him go into the post-office—I went in, he turned to go out; I followed him out, and at the door I gave him in charge—they were both taken to the station—I have not seen any of my money since.

Cross-examined. I should think I had not been on the race-course more than a quarter of an hour when I met Grant—I could not say whether he was alone or not at first—there were a number of people standing about looking on—he was not in company with any one; he was alone—I told him I did not know anything about betting—I was fond of seeing races—I think I have been to the races twice during the last twelve years—I did not hear Cannon come up and advise Grant to back a horse called "Wild Suffolk Lad"—I was cross-examined at the Mansion House—I swear I never heard the name of "Suffolk Lad"—Grant gave Cannon some money in my presence, shortly after Cannon came up to him—he went away with that before anything was said about my betting—Grant called out to Cannon and said "You had better do something for my friend here"—I did not give him 2l. on that race to back some horse—I swear I did not bet on any races at all—I gave money twice—there were only three races run all the time I was there—we went before the last race—I cannot tell you whether Cat's-eye ran in that race—I gave 2l. or 3l. on the first race—Cannon was introduced to me as "Mr. Cannon" when he came up first of all to speak to Grant—the first introdution about the betting was Grant saying to Cannon "You had better put something on for my friend"—I did not give him money to back any horses whatever—I gave him money because he came to me representing that the money had been paid away by him on my account, through a misunderstanding between him and Grant—I thought, although I had not commissioned him to do anything, it would be very dishonourable for me to let the man lose the money on my account—I said "I have not come down to the course for the purpose of betting"—Cannon handed a ticket to me—he took it back—he did not go and make another bet on the same race, or on a place bet he did not give me a second ticket on the first race and say he had laid 3

to 2 for the first and second place both for Grant and me—he gave me a second ticket about a second race, I cannot say whether to win or for a place—the bets were not written down by the bookmaker with my pencil at the Cannon Street Hotel, and I do not recollect that they were written down by him at all—I recollect a horse of the name of Lost Sheep—I do not recollect a horse named Meredith—I did not ask Grant whether he was sure Cannon would come back with the money for the first race—Cannon did not come back after the first race and say "I drew your money and laid it out on another horse called Meredith with 8l. more"—he said he had made another bet, but I couldn't say on what horse—I am not aware that he said he had taken 50 to 10 to win, and 10 to 3 for a place with regard to that horse—he told me had backed another horse for 10l.—that is all I remember—I think he mentioned about 8l. that I should have to give him—I cannot say the exact amount—I did not say I had only two sovereigns left—I swear that I had a 5l. note left after I gave him the first 2l.—I had 27l. at home and my lodgings—I did not tell Cannon that if he trusted me with 8l. I had money at home and it—would be all right—I was told the horse lost the race on which the 10l. was put on for me—I didn't know anything about it—I was told I had 15l. on Lost Sheep—I had no ticket given me for it—Grant did not put it down on the race card at that time—it was put down, but I could not understand how much I had lost and won—I was told that the race was lost by Lost Sheep—I said I was a "lost sheep" when I was leaving the course—I was told I had won 40l. at one time—I did not say that I objected to winning 40l.—I had shrewd suspicions at the time that I had been swindled—I had repudiated the bets all along—I did not repudiate tie bet when I was told I had won 40l.—we all left—Grant left the cab and went away for the purpose of getting some money—the bookmaker was not with us in the cab—Grant came back and said he had not sufficient money, but I cannot remember the amount he said—he did not say he was willing to hand over his 14l. to Cannon—I swear that" he handed over some money, but I cannot say how much—he had what appeared to be paper money—I believe he said something to Cannon about it being all he had got, and that he would make it up the nest morning—I recollect the next morning was the 25th August—I recollect the bookmaker said at the Cannon Street Hotel that he should be there in the morning, but at all events he should be on the race
course—a part of the next morning was wet—it was raining in the morning when I went to Cannon Street Hotel; not pouring in torrents—it was not a day I should enjoy being on Croydon race-course—I went to Croydon to see if Grant or Cannon were there—I said that at the police-court—Cannon said when I met him that I had not kept my appointment—he did not say I ought—to have waited till ten—I left Charing Cross for the race-course on the 25th by about one o'clock.

JOHN BUSHELL (Policeman 294 E). I was on duty on the 27th August outside Charing Cross station when the last witness pointed out to me a man named Draper outside the post-office and gave him into my custody—I took him to the station and saw him searched—he had on him 5l." in gold, 2s. in silver, and 7d. in bronze, jockey passes for the grand stand, a duplicate for a gold watch pawned for 5l., a dummy watch and a metal chain—he was bailed out subsequently.
ALEXANDER HCTCHINSON (Policeman 328 E). I was on duty in the

Strand on the 27th August when I saw the prosecutor, who called my attention to Grant and Draper, and said "These men have swindled me out of 27l.," and I took hold of Grant and the other walked away—they were afterwards charged at the station—Grant said horse-racing was a thing he did not understand, and he lost more money than the prosecutor did—a gold watch and chain were found on Grant, together with 12s. in silver and 5d. in bronze.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi:
There was another
indictment against the prisoner for larceny, upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

787.
HILTON P. BARRAUD () and
JAMES HENEY J. CRUIKSHANK
(), Obtaining by means of false pretences from
Jules Huesschen an order for payment of 6,250 francs. No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

788.
WILLIAM FRANCE (18)
, Stealing 36 rabbit skins of the goods of
Joseph Coulden and another his masters, and
FREDERICK WILLIAM CAIN (18) and
ELIZABETH SHENSTONE
receiving the same know
ing them to be stolen.

FRANCE and CAIN
PLEADED GUILTY .
MESSRS. THORNE, COLE, and DOUGLAS METCALFE conducted the Prosecution; and MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE and MR. CHARLES MATHEWS defended SHEXSTONE.

GEORGE WESTWOOD (City Detective). On the 11th inst. I went, in company with constables Osborne and Maroni and Mr. Coulden, the prosecutor, to Shenstone's shop, 83, Goswell Road—I went in alone—I should call it an ordinary manufacturing fur-shop—I saw Mrs. Shen
stone there, and afterwards the others came in—I said to Cain, in the presence of Shenstone, "Is this the person to whom you" sold the skins?"—he said "Yes"—I then said to Shenstone "Have you bought any skins of this lad?"—she said "Yes"—I said "How many?"—she said "It might be two or three dozen"—I said "How much did you give for them?"—she said "1s. each"—she pointed to a shelf in the shop, and a person in the shop fetched down a large quantity of prepared skins, some of these (produced)—she and her son sorted out three dozen—she said "There they are; I don't know whether they are all Mr. Coulden's"—I then said "Do you know this lad?" (pointing to Cain)—she said "No"—I afterwards said "Don't you know what he is?"—she said "No; a furrier, I thought," or "I think," I won't be sure which—I said "Have you bought any more?"—she said "No"—I said "I want two dozen and nine more"—she said "I have not bought any more"—I said "We are going to take these away (Referring to the three dozen skins), and you will be charged with receiving them knowing them to be stolen"—she said "Oh, the vaga
bond! I wish I had never seen them"—she said to Mr. Coulden "How many are there, how much are they?"—he said "I cannot have any
thing to do with it"—she then went to the back of the shop with the other officer, Osborne—I afterwards searched the shop, and brought away another ten dozen skins similar to these.

Cross-examined. I should think Shenstone went to the back of the shop with Osborne to put her shawl and bonnet on, and to see that she did not run away—they were out of my sight—I have no idea whether they were alone together—it was she who mentioned Mr. Coulden's name—I had not mentioned it, I am quite sure—Mr. Coulden was in the shop all the time.

WM. OSBOENE (City Detective). About three o'clock on the 11th October I went with detectives Maroni and Westwood to the warehouse of Messrs. Coulden and Son, 44, Gresham Street, where we saw the prisoner France—I took him into custody, and he was conveyed with Cain to the police station—from information we received from France and Cain, Westwood, Maroni, and myself went to Shenstone's shop in the Goswell Road on the same day, the 11th—she expressed a wish to go to the back yard, and I went with her—she went for a certain pur
pose, and then washed her hands—she said "I am sorry I bought them, bat you know what it is when things like that are offered by a boy; it is a great temptation, and you want to get them as cheap as you can, I suppose it is only a leaden penalty," which expression was accompanied by her putting her hand under her apron and rattling something like money—at that time one of the G Division Metro
politan Police came into the shop—we had sent for him—we generally make it a practice of doing so—Shenstone said "What does that police
man want"—I said "You have denied buying any more skins—I believe you have two dozen and nine more, and we are going to search the place for them"—her son then came to her, and she pointed to a shelf and said "You will find them there"—and there was a number produced from the shelf—Mrs. Shenstone and her son selected two dozen and nine—she said she thought they were them, and pointed to the lad Cain, and said she gave a shilling each for them, the same as she did for the others—she was then taken to the station and the charge read over to her—she said "I admit buying the five dozen and nine of the boy, but those are mine," pointing to a bundle of ten dozen.

Cross-examined. That bundle is here—what I have related was her own statement without any questions from me—there was a remand in the case—I was examined on the first occasion, and gave part of my evidence, not the whole, because it was taken by the Court to affect each prisoner—I gave evidence, and Mr. Vesey informed the Court that he should have to recall me—I gave evidence against Mrs. Shenstone on the second occasion—she was in the dock on the first occasion, and my giving evidence against her was, with Mr. Wontner's concurrence, left till the next remand—I do not mean that I suppressed or kept back evidence with Mr. Wontner's concurrence—I did not say on the first occasion anything about Shenstone going into the back premises, but I was prepared to say it—it was a very busy day at Guildhall—Mr. Pratt opened the case, and I gave evidence, and left the box without saying a word about this supposed conversation—I said I had other evidence to give personally—I spoke of the appre
hension of Cain, and what he said in answer to the charge; and I was then about to commence about Mrs. Shenstone, when Mr. Pratt said to Mr. Martin there was evidence, but proposed to take the next fitness, and Mr. Martin, the Chief Clerk, concurred—she was taken into custody by Westwood.

Re-examined. The first evidence I gave was only in reference to Cain and France—the other two officers, Westwood and Maroni, gave their evidence upon the first occasion—Mr. Pratt was the solicitor for the prosecution at that time—he said in open Court before the Alderman that Osborne would give further evidence with respect to Mrs. Shenstone, and
the Chief Clerk consulted with the Alderman, and they thought there was sufficient evidence for a remand.

JOSEPH COULDEN . I am a furrier, carrying on business at 44, Gresham street, in partnership with my son—France was in my employ as a porter—I went with him to the house of Mrs. Shenstone, in the Goswell Road, on the 11th October—she has never been a customer of mine—the three dozen skins found at her house are my property—their value is 30s. per dozen, 2s. 6d. each, wholesale price—I also identify the two dozen and nine skins as my property—they are of the same value—I had last seen all those skins in my warehouse—France had no authority whatever to remove them—I deal very largely in this business, especially in this article—this particular parcel was 1,500 dozen—we never sell skins.

STEPHEN MARONI (Detective G Division). On the 11th October I went to a warehouse in Charterhouse Buildings where Cain was employed, and took him into custody, and in consequence of information received I went with the other officers to Mrs. Shenstone's shop.
NOT GUILTY .

The other two prisoners were recommended to mercy. FRANCE—
Fifteen Months' Imprisonment.
CAIN—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

p.hi:
There was
another indictment against the prisoners on which no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

789.
JAMES ROSE (27)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Hearn, and stealing therein 9s., a pencil-case, six postage stamps, six receipt labels, and other articles, his property.
MR. PURCELL conducted the Prosecution; and MR. FULTON the Defence.

FREDERICK LEICESTER (Policeman E 121). I was in Gray's Inn Road on 28th September at about 2.15 a.m., about four yards from No. 347, and saw the prisoner chuck the grating back and come up out of it, and run away—I was near enough for him to see me—I was in uniform—I followed him, and came up with him in about 100 yards, and laid hold of him—he struck me with a jemmy across the helmet, got out of my hands, and tried to get over a fence of the Great Northern Railway—I never lost sight of him—I got him down, and he bit my arm—I took the jemmy from him, and placed it in my coat pocket—I could not have mistaken a jemmy for an umbrella—I have not the jemmy now—I called out for assistance, and two porters and two or three other men came up—he said he had been quarrelling with, a young woman, that she hit him in the mouth, and he hit her and then ran away—I found on him 7s., some bronze, a key, a knife, a silver match-box, and an almanac.

Cross-examined. I was standing on the kerb when I saw the man get out of the grating on the same side of the road, about four yards off—the pavement is quite four yards wide—it was rather a misty night—a cab
man was outside on the pavement, close to the place where the prisoner came out—he is not here, he gave no evidence at Bow Street—I think he was nearer the prisoner than I—another man was standing farther off, but in the road—the cabman was trying to get into his own house—I believe he saw the prisoner—I have been to the place again, and find It is not more than 100 yards that I ran—I kept him in sight all the time, in spite of the mist—I might have seen farther than ten yards—I think I should have seen him fifteen yards off—I was never as much as fifteen yards from him—I am positive it was a jemmy he hit me with, because

I bad it in my hand, and put it in my pocket, and what became of it I don't know—he did not say "What are you stopping me for?"—the key is not such as you generally find on persons breaking into a house.

GILBERT MAUNDER . I live at 18, College Street, Camden Town, and am a signalman on the Metropolitan Railway—I was at the corner of St. Pancras Road—a constable called for assistance—he was struggling with the prisoner over a jemmy—I know what a jemmy is—the constable put it in his pocket—my mate came up at that time—somebody eke came up as if to assist the police, and the prisoner handed him something, and he asked the prisoner if he had got the hammer and chisel—I cannot say what became of the jemmy after the constable took it—the man came behind the constable, I am certain—at the station I heard the prisoner say that he had been quarrelling with a young woman, and she hit him, and he hit him, and had run away.

Cross-examined. I was with Butcher—we assisted to take the prisoner in custody, but not the other man, we had quite enough to hold the prisoner—we were intent on keeping him—I spoke of the hammer and chisel before the magistrate, and I said that I saw the jemmy—I have seen dozens—we use them sometimes—it was rather a foggy night—I should not mistake an umbrella for a jemmy.
JOSEPH BUTCHER . I am employed on the Metropolitan Railway, and was with Maunder—I have heard his evidence—it is right.

Cross-examined. I was not the third man who was standing by—I was assisting the others—I heard some conversation about what I took to be a chisel and hammer—we did not secure the other man, because we were occupied in holding the prisoner—he was rather slippery—I saw the consta
ble take the jemmy from him and put it in his coat pocket—I did not take it out of his pocket—I know a jemmy when I see one—the man was behind the constable for about a minute—it was a scuffle.

GEORGE HEARN . I am a grocer, of 347, Gray's Inn Road—I was called up about a quarter past two on the morning of the 28th—I went down, examined the house, and found the top lock of the shop door picked, and the bottom lock forced—it could have been forced by a jemmy—the top lock had to be repaired—everything was in disorder—a cab-mau's carriage candle was on the counter, warm, just having been put out—the till was picked to pieces—my desk was forced open, and 7s. Taken from it, 2s. 6d. in bronze, and a gold pencil case—the grating is ordinarily fastened by a chain from the inside-a person getting in at the door could come out at the grating.

Cross-examined. The front door leading into the street was broken open, and anybody could get in or out—it had been locked so as to lock the cabman out, who had been trying to get into my house, and the cellar door had been forced to enable the prisoner to get up into the street—I think two were engaged, as the candles are peculiar, and would want another person to hold them—I count my money every night—I was disturbed by a noise—the cabman's wife knocked me up—they live on the top floor.

GUILTY *—
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

790.
WILLIAM LLOYD (19) and
THOMAS BROWN (21)
, Burg
lariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard John Coltman, and stealing therein twenty-four cigars and other articles his goods.

LLOYD
PLEADED GUILTY .

SAMUEL NEWMAN . I am in the service of Mr. Coltman, who keeps the Old George public-house, Bethnal Green Road—when I went to bed at about 1.30 a.m. on 21st September everything was all right—I left in the bar 2l. in silver, 4s. in copper, and 2l. 15s. in coppers sealed up in 5s. packets, and some cigars—at five o'clock I was called up, went downstairs, and missed all the money and the cigars, some grocery, 10s. in small money in a purse, a pair of shoes, nearly new, and a newspaper, which were on the sofa the night before—I found two pairs of old shoes in the yard, which were not there the night before, and I missed one pair of shoes of another man's—these are my boots (produced)—I saw them on the prisoner's feet at the station—there were four tiles off the back kitchen, which is a lower roof, and that would give access from one room to another—I gave information to the police.

ALFRED DYKE (Policeman K 343). At about 2.30 on the morning in question I was in Blyth Street, at the top of which is the prosecutor's house—I saw the two prisoners go from 47, Blyth Street, in the direction of the George public-house—I was about four yards from them then—I saw them again about three-quarters of an hour afterwards, coming from the George public-house to 47, Blyth Street, where they lived—I asked them what they were doing at that time in the morning—Brown said "We are late"—about five o'clock prosecutor made a communication to me, and I went to 47, Blyth Street with another constable—the landlord called the prisoners, and they came down—Brown was wearing these boots, and Lloyd these others (produced)—I asked Brown where he got his boots from—he said "I bought them this morning"—I asked Lloyd where he got his—he said that he bought them three weeks ago—I took them to the station, and on Brown I found 10s. in silver, and 14 1/2 d. in bronze—on Lloyd four postage cards, a cigar case, three cigars, and a key (produced).
SAMUEL NEWMAN (re-examined). All these articles are mine but the postcards.

JAMES GULLIVER (Policeman K 9). I went to 47, Blyth Street with Dyke, and saw the prisoners wearing the boots—I went up to their room—Brown wanted to go up; I prevented him—under the bed I found 30s. in silver tied up in a piece of old flannel—they lodge in that house, and occupy the same room—Brown's sister lives in the same house—I searched the two bedrooms all 'over—I found no rolls of copper coin—I watched the house from 6 till about 7.30, and then searched.
Brown's Defence. This is the first time I have ever done anything '—I have a very good character, and want to get some work when I get out of this.

BROWN—
GUILTY —
Six Months' Imprisonment each.

791.
JOHN LENTWYLER (20)
PLEADED GUILTY
to breaking and entering the house of
James Noad and stealing two candlesticks, a pair of opera glasses, and other goods his property.—
Judgment Respited. (See half-yearly Index.)

792.
WILLIAM WALLACE (19) and
JAMES WALLACE (25)
, Stealing four pieces of paper of
Augustus May Soule, the master of
William Wallace. Second count—receiving.

AUGUSTUS MAY SOULE . I am a broker, of 8, Union Court, Great Broad Street—William Wallace was in my employ about twelve months—he left on 14th September—on the 17th I missed four cheques and the counterfoils—these cheques for 5l. 5s., 10l., and 10l. are three of them—the signature is "F. Horn and Co."—I did business with that firm—William Wallace's duty was to send out the weekly circulars—I do not know the other prisoner.
Cross-examined by WILLIAM WALLACE. You had other opportunities of stealing my cheques—you bore a good character.
Cross-examined by James Wallace. You described my office accurately at Guildhall—I did not always leave my cheque-book out.
Re-examined. The office is not left unattended.

FREDERICK CASELEY . I am employed in Mr. Soule's office—the prisoner William left on 14th Sept. in the afternoon without permission, and re
turned about 4.45—he did not come the next day.
Cross-examined by WILLIAM WALLACE. You frequently came late on a Saturday.

ELLEN SLOMAN . I keep the Ship Hotel, Woolwich—on 14th Sept. I found the prisoners at my bar—James said "How do you do, Mrs. Slo
man; do you remember me?"—I said "I remember you of the 5th"—he said "I have left the 5th," and showed me a parchment—I did not read it, but gave it back—he then asked me to cash this cheque for 5l. 5s.—I said I had sent my money to the bank and could not do it—I subsequently gave him 3l. and promised him the remainder—he wrote" James Watson" on the cheque—the other prisoner was near him—James said "This is my brother."
Cross-examined by JAMES WALLACE. I have known you as a customer—I employ no one named "Emma"—you were not skylarking with the barmaid—I did not know what you were.
JOHN FAULKNER . I am a printer of Woolwich—I was at this bar and saw the prisoners—Mrs. Sloman showed me a cheque for 5l.—William sat on a table—they asked me to drink—William paid for it.
WILLIAM EDWARD WILSON HAWES . I am a clerk in Barclay, Bevan, and Co's. bank in Lombard Street—this cheque for 5l. 5s. came out of this cheque book—we have no customer named Horn and Co.

DENIS BLANG CAZAUX . I am a member of the firm of F. Horn and Co., of Philpot Lane—we receive weekly market reports from Soule and Co.—these cheques are not signed by our firm or by my authority—we do not bank there.
Cross-examined by JAMES WALLACE. The name "Horn and Co." is in the Directory.

HENRY HANDALL (City Detective). I obtained a warrant against the prisoners on the 28th Sept., and with Detective Trafford apprehended them for stealing cheques and for forgery—James said "I stole the cheques and filled them up, William does not know anything about it"—William said nothing—James afterwards said "I made a mess of the fourth cheque and I burnt it"—I found nothing on them.
Cross-examined by JAMES WALLACE. You wore performing at a theatre—the name of Wallace was on the hill.

WILLIAM WALLACE—
NOT GUILTY .

JAMES WALLACE—
GUILTY .* He also PLEADED GUILTY to having been convicted of felony at this Court in January, 1874—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

793.
ROBERT ASTON (28)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Cramer, with intent to steal.

ALFRED POTTER (Policeman X 383). On the 22nd Sept. I was in Shel
don Street, Bishop's Road—I saw the prisoner and two men go to the front entranco of the Prince of Wales public-house at the corner of Bishop's Road—I was about thirteen yards off—they raised the shutter and the prisoner got in; the shutter was then shut down by the two remaining men, who stood with their backs towards it—one came towards me and I took him into custody, but some companions rescued him—I went back to the Prince of Wales Hotel and found the shutter open about a foot—I raised it and wont in, and found the prisoner inside at the right-hand side in front of the bar—I asked him what he was doing there—he said "Nothing"—we struggled—I succeeded in getting him down when he was partly in the street—I searched him at the station and found three keys, a penny, and a halfpenny—on examining the shutter I found the stone so much worn that there is room to get one's hand in and raise it.

Cross-examined by MR. COLE. The time was about 1.15—the house is closed at twelve—I found no skeleton keys or jemmy on the prisoner or in the house—the shutters are revolving shutters and easily moved—I do not know of anything having been removed from the premises.

GEORGE TAYLOR . I am manager to Thomas Cramer, of the Prince of Wales Tavern in Eastbourne Terrace—I saw the house shut up on the 22nd, and the shutter put down—I was the last person up—I cannot say whether there was a catch to the shutter then—there is now—any one pulling up the shutter could get into the bar.

GUILTY .* He also
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell in January, 1867, in the name of
William Jennings —
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

794.
GEORGE STEWART (21), and
WALTER ELLIS (22)
, Stealing two books, the property of
John Miles, the master of Stewart, to which Stewart
PLEADED GUILTY .

CHARLES TORRY . I am in the employ of John Miles, who trades as Hamilton, Adams, and Co., at 3, Paternoster Row—Stewart was their porter—on 8th October, about one o'clock, I was in the packing room, and saw Stewart at the end of the counter near the door, rolling up his bag—I could see that, it contained something—ho put it outside and left—I called Foale and Drummond, and was examined the bag and found two volumes of "Curtis's Greek Etymology"—that book was in stock—

the books were placed back in the bag in the same position—I communi
cated with my employers, and when I returned the bag was gone.
ROBERT FOALE . I am a clerk in the same firm—on 8th October Tony spoke to me, and I found two books in a bag—I cannot say whether these are them—I put it back, and Mr. Drummond watched it.

THOMAS DRUMMOND . I am a clerk to the same firm—I saw Mr. Torry examine the bag—I watched it, and saw Stewart stand opposite it about two minutes—I then went to my desk, and heard him go out—I then, looked, and the bug was gone—he was away ten or fifteen minutes, long enough to go to Messrs. Ascher's, but not long enough to go there and back—I then saw him pass through the room; he had nothing in his hands then.

JOHN CRUNDELL . I am in the service of Messrs. Ascher, publishers, of Bedford Street, Covent Garden—Ellis was their collector—Stewart was in their employ some time ago, but not at the same time as Ellis—this is Eliis's collecting-book—here is an entry in it: "8th October, Curtis's Principles of Greek Etymology, 2 vols. price 30s., 1l. 2s. 6d."—that 1l. 2s. 6d. is in Eliis's writing; he put it down after he took the books—I had given him—5l. or 10l. to buy books that day—11s. 6d. was not a proper price to pay for those two books, 1l. 2s. 6d. was the price—I saw aim when he came back, and he charged 1l. 2s. 6d. for them.

Cross-examined. Messrs. Ascher have not prosecuted him for embezzling the money—they made no complaint—they had every satisfaction from him while in their employment—from 5l. to 30l. passed through his hands every day—lie had ten years' character when he came—he was allowed to go to any house in Paternoster Row for books.

JAMES AUSTIN (City Policeman 261). On 11th October I went to Messrs. Ascher and Co., 13, Bedford Street, Strand—I had a conversation with Mr. Ascher, and afterwards saw Ellis—I told him I should take him in custody for feloniously receiving two volumes of "Curtis's Greek Ety
mology" from the warehouse of Adams and Co., 32, Paternoster Row—he said "I bought the books, but did not know they were stolen"—I took him to the station, and found 9d. on him—going to the police court next morning he said "I bought the books of George Stewart, and paid 11s. 3d. for them, which was half the value"—he repeated that he did not know they were stolen.

ELLIS received a pod character—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi:
recom
mended to mercy by the Jury—
Three Months' Imprisonment.

div1.p:
795.
WALTER ELLIS was again indicted
for stealing 1l. 2s. 6d. of Messrs. Ascher and Co., his masters; upon which MR. A. METCALFE
offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

796.
EMILY MOORE ,
Stealing one watch of
Charles Tatton from his person.

CHARLES TATTON . I keep the King's Arms, Bishopsgate Street—on 19th September, at 12.15, I was closing my house—there is another compartment facing Acorn Street, in which there were three men and three women—the prisoner is one of the women—I opened the door and said "This way out, please"—the throe men passed me, and one of the women, the second woman, made a rude remark, and I told her to pass on—the prisoner then laid hold of my whiskers—I told her to keep her

hands off and go out, but she pushed me against two of the men who wore standing at the door—I put my hand on my watch, which was inside my pocket, but the men laid hold of my arm and forced it away—the prisoner then snatched my watch from my pocket, which was fastened to a chain—I put my other hand on hers, and felt my watch there, but could not take it from her, and it was passed to one of the others—I called out "My watch is gone"—they tried to force the prisoner from me, and by pulling her pulled me out into the street—a scuffle took place, and they forced her from me—I followed her, and the potman caught her running about forty yards off—I took her back and gave her in custody—the bow of the watch was then picked up in the bar—the men left a hat and an umbrella behind them outside the house.

Cross-examined. The gas was turned down but not put out—I lad taken a glass or two, and I had had two bottles of soda-water at different places—I took another woman, who was at the station-house door, into the station, and told her I thought she belonged to the party, but when I came to look at her I did not charge her—the Alderman at Guildhall said that she ought to have been detained, as she might have had the watch, or something of that sort.
ARTHUR BARTON (City Policeman 889). About a quarter to one on the morning of 19th September Mr. Tatton spoke to me, and I went into one of the compartments and found the bow of a watch (produced).
Cross-examined. The prosecutor says that it is his—it is hall-marked.

JOHN MINES . I am the prosecutor's potman—I asked some people to leave the compartment about 12.30, but they did not, and my master went to them—I saw him dragged into the street, holding the prisoner—I heard him say that he had lost his watch—I ran for a policeman, and as 1 came back I saw the prisoner running and stopped her—my master gave her in charge.
CHARLES KING (City Policeman 933). I took the prisoner—the charge was read to her at the station, and she said "I know nothing about the watch—I never had it."
GUILTY . She was further charged with a previous conviction of a like offence in Jane, 1876, to which she

PLEADED GUILTY—
Eighteen Months' Imprison
ment.

797.
EUGENE JOHNSON ,
Stealing 18s. 7d., the moneys of the
churchwardens of St. Ann's Church, "Westminster, and afterwards break
ing out of the church.

RICHARD WILEY (Policeman C 250). On Saturday morning, 22nd Sep
tember, I was in Dean Street, and saw the prisoner come out of St. Ann's Church, close the door after him, and walk away—I followed him and he ran—I ran after him—he got twenty yards in advance of me—I sprang my rattle, and another constable came towards me—before I got up to the prisoner he threw away this piece of steel (produced)—I took him in custody, and at the station he tried to throw away this other piece of steel—both pieces have some sticky substance still attached to them—he said that he picked the steel up on the church steps—I found on him six florins, six shillings, a sixpence, and two halfpence—they have a sticky substance on them, and have evidently been wiped with this duster, which I found on him.

SAMUEL WEBB . I am churchwarden of St. Ann's, Westminster—several weeks before September 22nd I opened the money-boxes in the church and found some sticky stuff where the money is put in, and the slits were very much marked—there was also a good deal of sticky stuff adhering to the bottoms of the boxes—here is a specimen of it (produced)—on the morning of the 22nd I went with the policeman and unlocked all the boxes—the prisoner had then been taken to the station.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. It is impossible to say how much money had been in the boxes.

Prisoner's Defence. I was not coming out of the church—I was on the steps, and I passed the policeman—he examined the church and found the door open—I had no keys and no tools to break in or break out—the doors must have been left open—they were both open right and left.

SAMUEL WEBB (re-examined). This was Saturday morning—unfor
tunately the church had been left open—there had been a choir practice over night at 10 or 10.30, and whether the prisoner got in then and con
cealed himself I cannot say, but it was palpably plain that the boxes had been tampered with.

GUILTY —
Six Months' Imprisonment.

798.
THOMAS SMITH (24)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Walker, and stealing therein two sheets and two pillow-cases, his property.

HENRY FEAT (Policeman G 325). On 9th October, shortly before twelve o'clock, I saw two men in Compton Street loitering by a low wall—I crossed the road and watched them, and saw a bundle fall over the wall, and a man came down and ran away, and then the prisoner came over the wall—I stopped him and took him to a house which is at the end of the wall, and some persons came out and said that they had seen them loitering about—I took the prisoner in custody—he struggled—the bundle contained two sheets and two pillow-cases.

ALFRED GILLHAM (Policeman G 11). I examined this wall—it is seven feet high—there were marks where a person had got over—there is a closet at the back of a public-house which joins a window, one of the panes of which was broken, and the sash was hanging by the cord—it is an empty beerhouse—I went upstairs and saw two small ladders, one on the ceiling and one on the roof—I got on the roof and saw that some person had gone over several tiles and slid down—the outer skylight had been taken off and the inner one broken, and a trap-door in the ceiling removed, so that access could be got to the landing.

HARRIET WALKER . I live with my husband at 57, Northampton street, Clerkenwell—on" 9th October, a little after ten p.m., I heard glass break and called my husband—I went downstairs—I did not feel satisfied, but I went to bed about eleven o'clock—I was afterwards called by the police, and heard people on the roof calling out "Hold him tight"—I found the trap-door open—I had left these sheets hanging on the landing.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate'. I was coming down Compton Street, and saw the things lying, and was going to pick them up when the constable seized me—I was never on the house or wall, or in the beershop—I have been in it when it was open, but not since.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the bundle, and the policeman came round the corner and seized me, and tore my shirt—I asked him before
the magistrate if he saw me come over the wall, and he said "No"—the magistrate told him to be very careful, and then he said that he did see me come over.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

799.
HENRY INGRAM (44), and
ELIZA JOHNSON (34)
, Stealing fifty-seven yards of silk-bordered regina, of
William Bond Skerton. Second count—receiving the same.

WILLIAM BOND SKERTON . I am a commission agent, and reside at 6, Russia Court, Milk Street—I employed a licensed messenger to take a number of parcels to Monkwell Street—he left my premises shortly after nine a.m.—among the parcels was fifty-seven yards of silk-bordered regina, that is umbrella silk, worth 7d. a yard—this (produced) is it—I followed with the invoice, and arrived there after he had taken a certain number of bundles upstairs—I saw some lying in the passage, and this bundle was among them.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. I identify this bundle by the ticket and the quantity—it is one of my tickets from which I enter the goods.

STEPHEN CLARK . I am a licensed messenger—I was employed to take twenty-three parcels in a hand-barrow to Monkwell Street—I took some upstairs, leaving the others in the passage—when I came down one was missing—this was a little after nine.

STEPHEN MERINAY (Policeman G). On 11th September, about 12.15 in the day, I followed the two prisoners—they were walking together—the female had something bulky under her shawl—I stopped them, told them I belonged to the police, and asked what she had got there—she said "It don't belong to me, it belongs to——"and then she stopped—Ingram turned round and looked at her at the time—she then threw the bundle down and said "Oh, I found it"—on the way to the station she said "I will tell you the truth; I found this morning about half-past eight in Old Street"—Ingram said at the time I stopped them, "I don't know anything of this woman"—he gave his address—I knew it—John
son gave no address.
WM. OSBORN (City Policeman). I have seen the prisoners together before 11th September.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I have known Johnson for years as a prostitute—she bears an honest character for anything I know—there are rumours.
HERBERT BUSWELL (Policman T R 13). I saw the prisoners together on 10th September in Bunhill Row, near Ingrain's house.
GUILTY .
Ingram also PLEADED GUILTY to a previous conviction in March, 1871.

INGRAM**—
Ten Tears' Penal Servitude.
JOHNSON—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

div0.p:
NEW COURT.—Saturday, October 27th, 1877. before
Robert Malcolm Kerr, Esq.

div1.p:
800.
NOVELLO BREWER (25),
CHARLES GARDNER , and
WILLIAM LAWSON (56),
Stealing 500 feathers, the property of
Myer Salaman and others. Second count—receiving the same.

THE COURT being of opinion that there was no case against Gardner and Law
son , MR. F. H. LEWIS, for the Prosecution, withdrew the case as against Brewer, and the jury returned a verdict of.
NOT GUILTY .

801.
HENRY KIRKE SWANN (38)
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences from
Timothy Arthur Symonds, an order for the payment of 100l., with intent to cheat and defraud.

TIMOTHY ARTHUR SYMOUDS . I am a booksellers' assistant—I saw an advertisement in the Daily Telegraph on September 12th, and I wrote to "C. A., Post Office, West Bromwich"—I saw the prisoner at my lodgings in Stanley Street, Pimlico, on Saturday, 15th September—he said he was the gentleman who had advertised—(Read: "Cashier and clerk wanted in the office of an established country newspaper: salary 30s. to commence, security 100l., apply C. L., "West Bromwich, near Birmingham")—he also said he was the proprietor and editor of the Lichfield Chronicle, and that it was being carried on in partnership with Mr. Brown, who did the printing and publishing; that a disagreement had arisen, and a dis
solution of partnership had been drawn up, and he was going to carry on the paper alone—he said he should want some one to do general office work, and to act as cashier, and he would give me 2s. 6d. more than the salary advertised—ultimately I accepted the terms, and I was to com
mence at once, but I was to draw up an agreement on the Saturday, and forward it to him, and he would let me know on the Monday, which I did—I did not hear from him that week, but on the following Friday I received a post-card from Mr. Swann, and on Saturday the 22nd I had this telegram "Meet me at Charing Cross Hotel at 2.30, if not there, shall drive to Pimlico"—I did not go to Charing Cross—it was 2.30 when I got to Pimlico—I waited for the prisoner till four o'clock, but did not see him—I then started to Pulbourne, near Cambridge—I re
ceived a letter from Mr. Swann the following morning—(This letter was dated 22nd September, 1877, Charing Cross Hotel, and stated that it was absolutely necessary to arrange with the prisoner or someone else at once, as the arrangements had been made for publishing)—in answer to that letter I sent this telegram—""Will come to you on Tuesday next to settle agreement on Wednesday"—the prisoner came to me at Pulbourne on Monday the 24th, and said the matter must be settled at once, and he was considerably put about—we came back to London, and at the Charing Cross Hotel he told me that all was ready; that I had good security; that his wife's relations were worth 30,000l.; that he was well acquainted with Messrs. Swindle and Collis, great coal-mine proprietors; that he would settle at once, and I could have a week's holiday, and commence on the next Monday—I believed his representations, and handed him the cheque—he gave me this receipt "24th September, 1877, received the sum of 100l. deposited with me this day by Timothy Arthur Symonds, to be held as security during his engagement with me, and at the termination of the said engagement to be returned to him. Notice of the termination of the said engagement to be given in writing one month previously: interest on the amount at 5 per cent per annum to be paid by me during

such time as the deposit remains in my hands; Henry Swann"—I went to Lichfield on Saturday the 29th to secure lodgings—I tried to buy a copy of the paper, but found it had not been brought out—I went to the offices and found them closed, and no signs of business—I then made inquiries, in consequence of which I got a warrant on Monday the 1st October—I afterwards received a letter dated 30th September, 1877—(This letter was signed by the prisoner, and stated that he was compelled to give up the idea of carrying on the Chronicle, but that he would pay the prosecutor a month's salary in lieu of notice, and that he would write again more fully).

Cross-examined. I found the offices of the Lichfield Chronicle. Henry Maxwell. I live at Elm Hurst Hall, near Lichfield—I saw the prisoner on the 25th September, and asked him if he had the money for the haystack he had bought—he said yes, and gave me a cheque for 100l.—I paid it into the National Provincial Bank—55l. to go to my employer's account, and kept 3l. for a small account the prisoner owed me, and returned the balance to the prisoner.

WILLIAM NORMAN . I carry on business at Lichfield—I know the prisoner as steward for a Mr. Fox—he rented a house of my son as an office in Fore Street—I went there on 4th October, and found an office table, four chairs, a small book-case, and a small counter, the value of which would be about 25s.—I went over the house, and found nothing else, except some loose papers.

Cross-examined. The prisoner had had the offices about two months—the Lichfield Chronicle was bought as a local paper would be—I do not know what the circulation was—most of my friends took it—about four or five of them.

WILLIAM HERNMAN . I am the superintendent of the Lichfield police—the last number of the Lichfield Chronicle in circulation was that of the 21st September—the office was in Birt Street—I have seen the prisoner in Fore Street, but not since the 24th of September—I arrested him in Birmingham—he said "It is a most abominable proceeding—I was going to pay the young man to-morrow—I have written to him for that purpose"—I have seen a paper advertising a sale of furniture.

Cross-examined. I had known the prisoner in connection with the Lichfield Chronicle, and he has since held a respectable situation—I was not present at the sale—I have seen bills announcing that the paper would be continued.

FREDERICK BROWN . I am a printer carrying on business at Lichfield—I entered into partnership with the prisoner on the 15th March, and continued till the 21st September, when the partnership was dissolved—the offices were in Birt Street—the machinery and plant and furniture belonged to myself—the prisoner was only entitled to an equal share of the profit—on the dissolution, this statement of account was made out, which showed that 4l. 2s. 10d. was due to each partner—I was not present at the sale of household furniture.
Cross-examined. I gave the prisoner notice to dissolve the partnership—I determined to start a fresh paper—as far as I know the prisoner has Dot seen this balance sheet.
Re-examined. The prisoner has received his share—I did not hand it to him—I had no connection with the Lichfield Chronicle after the dissolution.
ARTHUR WRIGHT . I am one of the firm of Wright and Marshall,
solicitors, of Birmingham—I received a letter from the prisoner on 26th September—I was not present at the sale of the prisoner's furniture.

GUILTY —
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

802.
GEORGE DOUGLAS (24)
, Stealing a purse, ear drops, and other articles, property of
Thomas Daniel Grayston.

FANNY GRAYSTON . I am the wife of Thomas Daniel Grayston, and live at 78, Belmont Street, Chalk Farm and let furnished apartments—on the morning of 10th October the prisoner called and asked for a furnished bedroom with a single bed—I showed him a room—he asked to wash his hands—he had said he would take the rooms and had gone for his luggage and come back without it—he went into the bedroom and then came down and talked to me about my baby—I went to the room and missed a ring and gold pencil—the prisoner was quietly leaving the house—I said he could not without leaving a deposit—he said he had no change—I said I would go with him to get change, and I went with him to get change, and to Chalk Farm station to get his luggage—it was not there—he said that was the wrong station—I said "It must have been the Prince of Wales Road station"—I saw the prisoner drop this gold pendant on the way to the station—it is my property, and so are these, the purse, four studs, silver watch, jewellery case and pin—they were in different drawers in the bedroom.
JOHN MANNING (Policeman Y 195). I took the prisoner—he made no reply when he was charged—I found nothing on him.

p.hi: The prisoner put in a written statement that he had come from Scotland and could not obtain employment, and had had nothing to eat for four days when he was charged with this crime; that he was innocent, but had no funds to obtain legal advice.

div1.p:
GUILTY —
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

803.
JOHN HAZEL (27)
, Unlawfully assaulting
John Cummings and occasioning him actual bodily harm.
MR. HUMPHREYS conducted the Prosecution; and MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS the Defence.

JOHN CUMMINGS . I and the prisoner are seamen of the ship "Wood-bourne, which is lying in the south West India dock—about twelve on the night of September 1st I was on the look-out when the prisoner came and called me a nasty name—I told him my mother was as clean as he was—he struck me in the face and caught my leg and shoved me partly over the rail—two men took him off me—I forget what I then said.

Cross-examined. I gave him no provocation—I cannot say whether he said anything about my walking over his head—I was sober—I had no coat on—I did not quarrel—I was not hurt—I was compelled to remain on duty and I did—this happened off the Cape of Good Hope.

CHARLES BLAKE . I am a seaman on this ship—I heard a cry on the forecastle—I saw Cummings half way overboard, and Hazel was shoving him over—I and the second mate pulled the prisoner off—the prisoner challenged me to fight—I said I didn't come to fight, but to do my duty—the second mate said "If you fight anybody, you shall fight me; the man must do his duty"—and he soon put all quiet.
Cross-examined. I do not know that any complaint was made to the master.
JAMES MASTERS . I was a seaman on this ship—I saw a row on the forecastle, and Cummings was hanging over—I caught hold of him—the prisoner wanted to fight Cummings.
Cross-examined. I do not know how the row began.

ROSS WATTON .
