The bootmaking business is carried on in the same shop and at the same counter as the Post Office work—I have cast up the columns myself—the sheets returned by the prisoner are correct—he left on the 22nd of March, and the mistake was discovered about the 15th of April—after he had left he offered to come back into my service, and I refused because he had left without notice—I know Mr. William Argent, of 61, Gracechurch Street—I instructed him to write a letter for me to the prisoner's mother—I never saw the letter before it went—I did not tell Mr. Argent to say that out of respect to his parents I did not wish to proceed to extreme measures, provided the 10l. which I had to pay were made good to me; nothing of that sort—I made no such pro
position as that I would be obliged if the mother would at once write, saying what proposal she was prepared to make with a view to a speedy settlement—I did not tell Mr. Argent to say failing the repayment I would place the matter in legal hands—I proposed writing in a measure to know where he was and what had become of him, but did not make any such proposition as to make a debt of it—I do not know that I told Mr. Argent of anything beyond what he knew of the circumstances—I left him to write what he chose—I did care what he wrote—I did not give instructions what he was to write—I had a copy of the letter sent to me, and have read it, but I forget it now—I have not got a copy—it has become waste paper—I did not write to Mr. Argent to repudiate what he had done.
Re-examined. I never received 10l. in one day in the boot business.
HENRY STAPLES . I am employed in the General Post Office—I produce

the daily sheets of the 12th to the 26th of March of the Leytonstone Post Office, of which Robert Watts was postmaster—the sheets are the same documents submitted by him—the returns to the General Post Office are correct, 150l. balance, whereas in the daily account book it shows 140l., and by that false addition the balance is 339l. instead of 349l.

GEORGE BLANK (Detective Officer). The case was entrusted to me to take prisoner into custody on 12th of June, and from 12th of June to 20th of October I was not able to see the prisoner—I found him enlisted in the Royal Engineers at Brompton Barracks, Chatham—he said "All right, I can soon square that little matter up."
Cross-examined. I have not before been asked what the prisoner said, and I have not stated it before.

GUILTY —
Six Months' Imprisonment.

807.
THOMAS HYSLOPE (19) and
JAMES DINHAM (19)
, Highway robbery on
William Henry Hodgson, and stealing 17l. and a piece of paper his property.

WILLIAM HENRY HODGSON . I am assistant-solicitor to the Treasury and live at 10, Granville Park, Lewisham—on 28th May last I had been, visiting some friends at Woolwich—at 9.30 in the evening I started to return home in a hired fly, accompanied by two ladies—I don't know the driver's name—we drove along the Dartford Road until we came on to Blackheath—when we got near the Ranger's house we turned to the left across the top of the heath—there is a long, empty gravel pit along the side of the road there for about 150 yards, and when the carriage was about the middle of the gravel pit, on the road side, it suddenly stopped—I was on the point of looking out to see what the cause of the stoppage was when my attention was drawn to the off-side window, which was closed, and I there saw a man standing at the window—it was then about ten minutes to ten; the moon had not risen—the man had a mask on the upper part of his face and a pistol in his hand, which he pointed into the carriage, and I heard him say "Your money, or I'll fire"—he repeated this once or twice, perhaps three times—I thought it was some drunken man, and I said "Go away," and I called out at the same time to the driver "Drive on"—he made no reply, the carriage did not move, so I again said "Drive on "more loudly—he said "I can't"—at that moment, to my surprise, at the window where I was sitting, which was partially open, another man appeared—he had a piece of crape across the lower. part of his face, and a pistol in his hand, which he pointed into the carriage, and said "Your money, or I'll fire instantly"—he repeated this two or three times as I hesitated to do anything—I then put my hand in my pocket and took out some loose silver, I believe 3s., which I handed to him—he took it in his left hand, still holding the pistol into the carriage towards me—he then said "This won't do for me, you have got more than that, you have got a purse; I'll have your purse, be quick"—I attempted to get my head out of the way of the pistol, which he continued

to point at me, and in doing so I leant back into the corner of the carriage—he then pulled the door open with his left hand and presented the pistol at my head and said "Your purse instantly, or I'll fire"—this he repeated, and said "Ill blow your brains out if you don't give it me immediately"—under the circumstances I then took my purse out of my pocket and handed it to the man—he took it in his left hand, as he had done the silver, and I saw him weigh it apparently for a moment in his hand—he then said "There are more of you," looking towards the ladies—I said "You have got all I have"—he then shut the door to and said "Go on"—at the time he pulled the door open I saw the other man standing about a yard behind him on the side of the road, which is about a foot higher than the roadway—he held in his hand a pistol, about a yard from me—in a very short time the carriage was driven on—I did not see the driver or hear him—I could not see what became of the men—I was driven to my house; I got the ladies out and immediately drove on to the police station and gave information—one of the men, the first I saw, had on a light overcoat, I can't say anything more than that—the other had a dark coat, and both had low-crowned hats—I did not notice the pistols suffi
ciently to say whether they were revolvers or not, but I distinctly saw the gleam of the barrel of the one that was pointed at me in the carriage, and I should gather from that that it only had one barrel—I have seen the revolver produced—it might have been one of those I saw—my purse contained two 5l. notes and seven sovereigns, two blank cheques and some postage stamps—I had drawn a cheque for 15l. at my bankers, Messrs. Fuller, of Lombard Street, that morning, and I went the next moraine and got the numbers of the notes (notes produced)—I don't know that I can identify them—these are the numbers the bankers gave me—I went direct to the Bank of England and stopped the notes—I saw the faces of the men, but they were disguised, I could not tell their features at all—I should say both were slim men—I think the height of one would be about the height of the tallest of the prisoners (Dinham)—it so struck me, but I could not form a very good judgment of their height, because I was sitting in the carriage and just saw them over the window.

By THE COURT. I heard both of them speak; one I heard speak re
peatedly—I have not had an opportunity of hearing either of the prisoners speak since they have been taken.

WILLIAM ROGERS . I am in the employment of Mr. Smith, a fly pro
prietor, of Woolwich Common—on 28th May I was engaged by Mr. Hodgson to drive him home—when I got on to Blackheath, near the Ranger's house, I was stopped—one man from one side of the road and one on the other got hold of the horse and pulled him down all of a sudden and knocked the trappings off—they got hold of the reins and pulled him down on his haunches, and before he could get up they un
buckled the reins—I said "What the devil are you trying to do?"—they said "If you don't sit still and hold your noise we will blow your brains out"—each of them had a pistol, which they presented on each side of my head—that was all they said—they then went to the carriage window and said "Either life or money"—I am sure the word "life" was used—the gentleman gave them some silver—I saw that—I was on the box—they said "This won't do, we want either life or money," and the gentle
man gave them his purse, and they went away as soon as they got the purse and never looked in it—they went towards Greenwich, the Banger's

way—I then got down, put the reins on, and drove on to Granville Park—it was a one-horse fly—this occurred about a mile and a half from Green
wich Hospital.
By THE COURT. I did not attempt to get down—I thought I had better bide where I was.

HENRY STOCKEE . I am chief cashier at Messrs. Fuller and Co.'s, bankers, Lombard Street—Mr. Hodgson keeps an account there—on 28th May I cashed a cheque of his for 15l. with two 5l. Bank of England notes, Nos. 90749 and 90750, dated 22nd Dec, 1876—these are the two notes.

CHARLES JOHN WILLIAMS . I am a clerk in the Bank-note Department of the Bank of England—I produce two 5l. notes—the one numbered 19749 was paid in on the 19th of June last at the London and South Western Bank, and the one numbered 9750 on the 7th of June at the Portsmouth Branch of the Bank of England.

MRS. PALLANT. I am the wife of Charles Pallant, a watchmaker and jeweller, of 267, Mile End Road—between seven and eight one summer evening a man came and bought a wedding-ring and keeper—I cannot give the date—it came to 1l. 19s. 6d.—he offered a 5l. note in pay
ment—I could not give him change, and he said he would call in the morning—I said if I had any one to send I would send to get it changed—he then offered to go if I would tell him where to go—I told him to go to the King Harry public-house, which is near my shop and opposite Mr. Yates'—he then went away—he came back again in about five minutes, and asked me to sign my name—I signed the note numbered 90749, and the man signed "J. Compton, Russell Street," in my presence—he then went away and did not return—on the 10th September I was fetched to Portsmouth and shown into a room where there were about a dozen men, and I pointed out Hyslope as the man who tendered the 5l. note—I have do doubt he is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I do not remember when I was first spoken to about this, but it was a week or two before I went to. Ports
mouth when Mr. Shaw spoke to me—I said at the police court it was six or seven weeks before I gave my evidence—I have reason to believe I made a mistake—I cannot now be sure of the date—I told Mr. Shaw I had made a mistake—Shaw "was not with me in the room when I identi
Hyslope—I did not see him there—Shaw travelled in the same carriage from London with me—we had very little conversation, none about this case—he had told me what he was taking me to Portsmouth for—he said he suspected some man, but he did not tell me what kind of man he was—I know Chief-Constable Jarvis and Mr. Bidgood—I did not observe them in the room—I stood in the centre of the room, no one stood near me—the man I picked out was not quite in the centre—I looked round first—I cannot swear to Mr. Hyslope, sen., being in the room—I could not identify him—I did not see any one taking notes, I was paying attention to the men—Mr. Shaw went to the police station with me—I was shown into the room where the prisoners were at once—I pointed out Hyslope with my umbrella—I do not remember Shaw saying anything to me there—he might have said "You must not say anything here," but I do not recollect it—to the best of my belief he was outside—I never used the words "It strikes me forcibly that he is the one"—I was sure Hyslope was the man—I cannot swear I never used those words.

HENRY RICHARD YATES, JUN . I am the son of Richard Yates, who keeps the King Harry public-house in the Mile End Road—one summer evening a man came and asked me to change a 5l. note—I took the note to my lather, who sent it back to Mrs. Pallant—I did not notice any name on it.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I went to Portsmouth with Inspector Shaw and Mrs. Pallant to identify—Mr. Shaw stood at the door of the room—I looked at the twelve men in the room—I shook my head, and Mr. Shaw said "Have another look"—he was then in the passage—I did not see Mrs. Pallant identify Hyslope—I would not swear that Mr. Shaw did not go into the room.
Re-examined. Beyond the suggestion "Have another look," nothing was said by Mr. Shaw to make me identify any particular person.
HENRY RICHARD YATES, SEN . I keep the King Harry public-house, Mile End Road—I changed this bank-note, but I cannot recollect the date—I paid the note away to my brother.

WILLIAM HOLLOWAY . I am a baker and beerhouse keeper, of 23, York Street, Southsea—prior to Sunday, the 20th May last, Dinham had been in my employ as an assistant in the bakehouse, for about eighteen months at 6s. a—week—he lived and slept at home, but I occasionally fed him—I believe his parents live in Portsmouth—he did not come to work on the Monday—he had given me no notice of his going away—on the Tuesday his sister came to make inquiries—I noticed something written up in the bakehouse on the Tuesday—I do not know the writing—Sunday was the last day Dinham worked for me—no wages were due, as his parents took his wages in bread—I never knew him to have a sum like 5l. in his pos
session—on Sunday, the 17th of June, about 6 o'clock, a stranger came to my shop—Hyslope is a good imitation of him, I believe he is the matt—he asked for change for a 5l. note—I refused at first, but he said "Mr. Bartlett. the grocer, is my uncle," and I gave him change—he also said he had come from London, and was going back in the evening, and is rather awkward to get change for a 5l. note at a railway-station"—I then gave him 4l. in gold and 1l. of silver—I did not notice the note or see any name written on it—I paid the note to Mr. Browning, my brewer and landlord—on the 18th June I heard that Dinham had returned, and on the following Thursday I saw him at his father's house—I said "How are you getting on, John?"—he said "All right; how are you getting on?"—I said "All right, thank you, John"—he did not tell me any more till he returned to my employ, a fortnight after, when he had been away about six weeks; then he told me he had been to London and to Greenwich with Hyslope—on the 31st of July my cash box was stolen and some watches—the loss was about 32l.—I was afterwards shown that cash box by the superintendent of the Portsmouth police, and identified it.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Mr. Shaw took me to see where Hyslope worked—he did not say anything—I know Hyslope's father—he called upon me before I went to see Hyslope—I did not say I did not know Hyslope, or that Mr. Shaw was going to take me to the man who passed the note—I do not remember doing so—I cannot swear I did not.
Re-examined. MR. HYSLOPE said "Do you know my son?"—I said "I don't know that I do"—that was all that was said—he then went
away—it might have been a week after Mr. Hyslope's visit that I went with Mr. Shaw—prior to Mr. Hyslope coming, Mr. Shaw had been and inquired about the note.

JOHN WILLIAM BROWNING . I am a brewer of Portsmouth—the last witness is my teuant—I called fur his monthly account on the 19th June, and he paid me 13l. 8s., amongst which was the 5l. note with "Compton "endorsed on it and numbered 90750—I spoke to Mr. Holloway about it—I paid it into the North "Wilts Bank on the 21st June.

JOHN CLEGG . I am a clerk in the Portsmouth branch of the North Wilts Bank—Mr. Browning keeps an account there—the 5l. note num
bered 90750 was paid in on the 21st of June last, and was passed to the Portsmouth branch of the Bank of England.

WILLIAM WEIGHT . I am a clerk in the Portsmouth branch of the Bank of England—on the 25th June the note 90750 was paid in to the North Wilts Bank and passed on to the Bank of England the following day.
JAMES BARTLETT . I am a grocer of York Street, Southsea—I did not send any one on the 17th June to Mr. Holloway to get change for a 5l. note—the prisoner Hyslope is not my nephew—I know Dinham.

THOMAS BARTLETT . I live at 42, Turner Street, Commercial Road, London, and am the nephew of the last witness—I was not at Portsmouth on the 17th June—I have never been to Mr. Holloway's to get change for a 5l. note.

MARY WESLEY . I am a single woman, residing at 6, Romsey Terrace, King William Street, Greenwich—I have a servant named Sarah Dobson—on the 24th May the prisoners and a young woman named Harrington came to hire some apartments I had to let—I thought Harrington was married to Hyslope, they slept together—the rooms were engaged for a week or a fortnight—they stopped 3 weeks and 3 days—on the Saturday prior to their leaving they dined early, and Dinham and Hyslope went away and were absent on the Sunday—Hyslope came back on the Monday morning about 5—I never saw Dinham again—I let Hyslope in and went to Led again—he was alone—he and the young woman breakfasted between 8 and 9 and left about 9.30—I was paid by them down to the following Thursday—Hyslope gave no reason for leaving—they used to go out—I retired to bed about 11—I cannot say if they were out after 11—I always considered they were in—they had the drawing-room floor and the parlour bedroom, two bedrooms and a sitting-room—I slept downstairs—I had got the topfloor let at the time.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I did not say at the police-court about the young men going away on the Saturday and Hyslope coming back alone—I think I was not asked—I do not recollect who brought it to my mind—I had several conversations with Mr. Shaw—I said at the police-court that they came home about 11, that was the fact—I might have said—they stayed about a month, they paid me for a month—I do not think Mr. Shaw called on me more than twice—we talked about this case—I do not think it was he who asked me whether the prisoners had left town for any time—I do not recollect it—he told me Hyslope lived at Portsmouth; that was after I gave my evidence I think, but I cannot recollect—I do not recollect Mr. Shaw, my servant, and myself having a conversation in the parlour—Mr. Shaw saw my servant without my presence; he was not a long time talking to her—the prisoners' absence from London I think
was mentioned to my servant, and of course she would name it to me—neither my servant nor I were asked about it at the police-court.

Re-examined. MR. WONTNER'S clerk saw me before giving evidence to-day—he took down my statement in writing—I think Mr. Shaw came prior to my giving my evidence at the police-court—he has not seen me since.

SARAH DOBSON . I was servant to Miss "Wesley—the prisoners and a young woman came on the 24th May, and occupied one bedroom and a sitting-room on the drawing-room floor, and one bedroom on the dining-room floor—Hyslope and the young woman occupied the drawing-room—I sat with Mrs. Hyslope in the evening; Miss Wesley went to bed before eleven—the prisoners remained about three weeks—they went out in the evening occasionally and came home at one o'clock and after—I could not say how often that happened; I used to sit up and let them in—Hyslope wore a pepper-and-salt pair of trousers and a black coat and around, hard hat with a low crown—Dinham had a black pair of trousers and a light coat and a hat like the one worn by Hyslope—Mrs. Hyslope remained at home when they stayed out late, and I used to keep her company—on the Saturday before the Monday that they left Mrs. Hyslope said she wanted dinner early that day because they had to go to Ports
mouth to see Hyslope's uncle, and would catch the quarter to three train—they had dinner about half-past two—on the Sunday night I slept with Mrs. Hyslope, and on Monday morning, about five, Hyslope returned, and I went to my own bedroom—Dinham did not come back—they left about nine o'clock—Hyslope said his uncle was very ill.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I did not state this at the police-court—I have seen Inspector Shaw at my mistress's house once—I went once to the police-court at Greenwich—Mr. Shaw's visit was before that; he has not been since—he saw my missus as well as myself—that was after the men were in custody—I let Mr. Shaw in and called the missus—he saw us together in the drawing-room—I did not say anything at the police-court about the journey on the Sunday—I was not asked.

HENRY BUDD . I live at Portsmouth—I recollect being at the Green
wich police-court—about two months before that I was by the canal and found a cash-box, and a revolver with six chambers—four were loaded—the cash-box was broken open; this (produced) is it, and this is the revolver—I gave them to the police the same day.
Cross-examined by MR. MATHEWS. I don't know how long ago it was that I found them, whether it was two months or seven weeks—I don't know what month it was, I did not take any notice.

JAMES JARVIS . I am chief-constable of the Portsmouth police—on 1st July I received a communication from Scotland Yard, in consequence of which I made some investigations about a bank-note, No. 90750, both at the Portsmouth branch of the Bank of England and at the Hants and North "Wilts Bank—on 31st August, in consequence of information about a robbery at Mr. Holloway's, I had Dinham sent for; I had on 26th received the cash-box and revolver from Constable Carter—I showed them to Dinham, and said "This is your master's cash-box that has been found in a field broken open, with this revolver alongside of it." He said he new nothing of it—I told him I would send an officer with him to search his box—I asked him to produce what he had in his pockets, and he produced several books and pamphlets, one called "Claude Duval, the

Dashing Highwayman," and the others "The Boys' Standard" and "Young Briton"—they are weekly periodicals for boys—I then sent him away with Inspector Bidgood—in a short time they returned, and Bid-good handed me a second revolver and a number of cartridges, which he said he had found in the prisoner's box—I then asked Dinham what account he could give of the possession of this revolver—he said he bought it in the Strand for 3l. 10s. when he was in London; the name of Newn
ham is on it; there is a gunsmith of that name at Landport—I tried the cartridges to the revolver and they would not fit—I then tried them to the first revolver, and they fitted exactly—I then said to him "Where did you get the cartridges?"—he said "I bought them at a shop near the Tower"—he said he bought another pistol in London for 30s. from a man in the street whom he did not know, and sold it again for a sovereign to a man in the street he did not know—I asked when he went to London, and who with—he said "I and young Hyslope left Portsmouth on Whit. Monday, the 21st May—we went to London and stayed two nights at an eating-house in a street leading down to the Houses of Parliament; "that two days after they arrived Hyslope was married to a young woman from Portsmouth—I don't know that he said she went with them from Ports
mouth—they then took lodgings in King William Street, Greenwich—he said they were away from Portsmouth about four weeks—I then said the day or the day following they arrived in Portsmouth a 5l. Bank of England note, which had been stolen with other money from the person of Mr. Hodgson, on Blackheath, on 28th May, had been passed at the shop where he was employed—he said "I know nothing about it"—I did not detain him at that time, but I communicated the information I had obtained to the metropolitan police the same day, and on 4th Sep
tember Inspector Shaw came down to Portsmouth—Dinham was again sent for to the station, and Shaw saw him in my presence—on 10th Sep
tember Shaw came again, accompanied by Mrs. Pallant and young Tates—I went with Shaw to Hyslope's place in Lake Road, Landport—Shaw said to him "I have seen your handwriting in the register, the signa
ture you made when you were married, and an endorsement on a Bank of England note which has been stolen from Mr. Hodgson on Black-heath on 28th May, and in my opinion they are identical." Hyslope replied, "I did not have a note in my possession, and I shall be very glad to have it cleared up, as the boys in the street point me out as one of the highwaymen." He was told he would have to go and put on the clothes he wore when in London—he did so and he was then taken to landport station—he remarked before going that the clothing he had on then was exactly the same as he had in London,-even to the necktie—Mrs. Pallant and Tates were left at the hotel near the station—I told the inspector to get six or seven men as like the prisoner as possible in dress and height, and when they were ready in the reserve room one of the constables fetched Mrs. Pallant and Yates—Mrs. Pallant was shown into the reserve room, and immediately she got in she put up her umbrella and pointed to Hyslope—no suggestions had been made to her to pick him out—I then went into my office with Shaw; I did not see Yates go in, I saw him afterwards; he did not identify any one—the prisoners were then charged with this offence—they made no reply—I had pre
vionsly been to the shop where Hyslope was employed, and there received this leaf of a book—I showed it to Hyslope—he said "Where did you

get that?" I said "From Miss Fitzpatrick, where you are employed." He said "It is a leaf out of my book that I keep showing the delivers of the bread. I enter the names first, and afterwards the quantity, as I deliver the bread."

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. After Mrs. Pallant went in Shaw went with mo to my private office—I don't think he went out again until Mrs. Pallant came in—Yates went in while we were in my office—Shaw and I were standing together in the passage when Mrs. Pallant went in—I should think she could see Shaw—she had her back to him when she got into the room—the men were facing her, in a line in the middle of the room—she made two steps towards them and immediately pointed—I did not hear her say anything, I did not remain long enough, I went into my office—I will swear I did not see Yates go in—I did not see him shake his head in a negative manner, nor did I hear Shaw say "Have another look"—Hyslope's father was there, I think he stood next to his son, he was not placed there, I allowed him to go in with his son, it was his own wish
Sergeant Bidgood was in the room or the passae—Mrs. Pallant went in a second time.

Cross-examined by MR. MATHEWS. I did not mention before the Magis
trate that Dinham said he bought the second pistol from a man in the street for 80s.—I did not caution the prisoners, when this conversation took place, they were not prisoners then—Dinham was the only one I had conversation with.

Re-examined. Mrs. Pallant went back to the room probably a minute after she came out—I said to her "Have you identified the person that passed the note to you?"—she said "I feel certain that that is the man, but I should like to have another look at his eyes "and I said "You can go back and see them again"—she did so, and then said "I am certain that is the man."

CHARLES BIDGOOD (Inspector of the Detective Department, Portsmouth On 31st August I accompanied Dinham to his father's residence—I went upstairs, and in the bedroom found this little box with some cartridges in it, also this revolver—I asked him how he accounted for the possession of the revolver—he said "I bought it in London"—I said "What did you give for it?"—he said "3l. 10s."—I took one of the cartridges and put it to thw-point of the revolver, at the same time saying "These cartridges are too large"—he replied "That is not the way to load it, let me have it, I will show you"—I declined—I put them the other way and found they were too large—I said "I shall take possession of them, and take them to the station," which I did, and he also—I heard him say there that he had bought a second revolver for 30s. of a man in the street, and that he had sold it for 1l. to a man in the street, whom he did not know—he said that he had 5l. when he went away—I said "It took the whole of your money"—I was at the station on 10th September when the identification by Mrs. Pallant took place, I was standing in the lobby at the time.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I saw Mrs. Pallant go in—Mr. Hyslope was in the room, one of the inspectors, and a constable or two—Shaw was in the lobby, standing alongside Mr. Jarvis—Mrs. Pallant went in, looked round the men, and then pointed her umbrella direct to Hyslope—she did not say anything that I heard, she left the room and went into the super
intendent's office—I then went into the detective's office and remained—she remained in the superintendent's office some time, and when I went

out of the station I met her coming from the reserve room again, she had apparently been in a second time; that was about two minutes after she first went into the superintendent's office—I was not examined before the Magistrate.

JOHN SHAW (Police Inspector). I instituted some inquiries at Ports
mouth on 4th September—about nine or ten that night I saw Dinham at the police-station—I told him I was an officer, and he was suspected of being concerned in a highway robbery with pistols on Blackheath, on 28th May—he replied that he knew nothing at all about it—Mr. Jams pro
the revolver, and I said to Dinham that it seemed strange for him to be in possession of such things as those—he said he bought it in the Strand in London, and gave 3l. 10s. for it—he said he had never seen the other revolver—he said that Hyslope himself and Hyalope's young woman left Portsmouth on Monday, the Bank Holiday, which was 21st May; that they went to London, and stayed for a night or two at Knight's coffee-house, near the Houses of Parliament; that they then went to King William Street, Greenwich, where they stayed about four weeks—after that conversation I allowed him to go—next day, the 5th, I went to a shop kept by a man named Fitzpatrick; it is a general shop, a baker's, and they sell beer as well—I found Hyslope there—I told him I was an officer, and that I heard he was suspected of being concerned with Dinham in stopping a carriage on Blackheath, on 28th May, where a gentle had been robbed of a purse containing two 5l. notes and seven
man sovereigns—he said he knew nothing at all about it—on 10th September Iwent again to Portsmouth and saw Hyslope—I told him that since I had seen him last I had seen the writing on the two notes, and the signa
ture to the marriage register; that I thought the writing very much alike, and I should be glad of some further information, as there was suspicion against him—he said he knew nothing of the notes, he had no notes during the time he was in London—I told him that J. Compton, Leslie Street, was written on one of the notes, and J. Compton on the other; that one had been passed in the Mile-end Road to a Mrs. Pallant, and the other to a person named Holloway, somewhere in Portsmouth, but I did not know exactly where—he said he should be very glad if it could be cleared up, because he was pointed at by boys in the street as a person suspected of highway robbery—I said it would be materially in his favour if he could give me a satisfactory account of where he was on the night of 28th May, provided he had not committed the offence—he said he thought he was at the Alhambra, that he went there, I think he said three times—I ultimately took him to the station, and Mrs. Pallant was brought in—Dinham was brought in afterwards—they were put with some other persons in a room—prior to Mrs. Pallant identifying Hyslope I had not communicated to her anything about his appearance, dress, or any
thing to lead her to identify him.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I have only known the man Holloway since this case—I took him to the shop where Hyslope was at work stand
ing outside the door—I had arranged with Hyslope to bring him—I did not tell Holloway that I would show him the man who had passed the 5l. note; if he says so it is false—I went three times to Mrs. Pallant's—I have seen Miss Westley once at her house, after the prisoners were in cus
tody; I was there about three minutes, in the passage, I think; she took me into a room, the back parlour; I did not go upstairs to the drawing-room

—when Mrs. Pallant went into the room to identify Hyslope I was in the passage—she walked in, looked round, pointed with her umbrella, and came out—I did not hear her say anything—I believe Jarvis was in the passage by my side—we went with Mrs. Pallant into the inspector's room for a minute or two—she said he was the man, but she wanted to see him again, because there was something peculiar about his eyes—Jarvis sent her back again—I saw Yates go into the room; I did not see him shake his head in a negative kind of way—I may have told him to another look, I can't say—I did not caution Hyslope—I just put the ques
tions to see if he could explain the matter—he told me that when he went to London he had 8l. or 9l. that he had saved up—I think he said 19l. or 29l., but he had no 5l. note.

ALEXANDER FRASER . I am verger of the parish church of St. John's, Waterloo Road—on 22nd May I was present at a marriage between the prisoner Hyslope and Ellen Sarah Budd—I saw Hyslope sign the register—I produce it—I signed after him as a witness.

CHARLES CHABOT . I am an expert in handwriting, of Red Lion Square—I have for nearly twenty-five years given my attention to the study of handwriting—my attention has been called to certain documents in this case, the page of a book, the signature to the register, and the name " J. Compton" on the two bank notes—in my opinion they are all written by the same person; if necessary I can point out the similarities I rely upon.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I was first asked to give evidence on Thursday last—I then saw and compared the documents in Mr. Wontner's office—I did not see any other writing—I think I knew it had reference to this case—I have been many times a witness—on one or two occasions I believe the jury have given a verdict against my evidence; I believe you allude to the case of "Davis v. Davis," but in that case I did not give a speculative opinion; I merely said I could not identify the testator's handwriting—I gave evidence in Fullager's case, and he was acquitted—in this case I go by the general character of the writing, as well as by the special peculiarities.
MR. HOLLOWAY (re-examined). This is my cash box.

MARY WESLEY (re-examined). The prisoners paid me 30s. a week for the month they were with me—they took their meals at home—they lived as ordinary lodgers would live—I suppose their board would amount to about 30s. a week; altogether they paid about 3l. a week—Mrs. Hyslope paid me.

GUILTY —
Seven Years' Penal Servitude each.

808.
THOMAS FENNELL (47),
WILLIAM THOMAS CLARKE (37), and
THOMAS DOUGLAS (48), were indicted, with
HENRY PORTER (29) (who did not at first surrender),
for stealing 12 tons 18 cwt. of iron of
John Penn, the master of Clarke. Second Count charging Douglas with receiving.

MESSRS. STRAIGHT and GILL conducted the Prosecution; MR. SIMS ap
peared for Clarke, and MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE, MR. BESLEY, and MR. M. WILLIAMS for Douglas.

HENRY JAMES MARSHALL (Police Sergeant). On the afternoon of 16th July I went to Messrs. Penn's works at Greenwich with a warrant for Fennell's apprehension—Fennell was sent for into a private room, where.

MR. NOTLEY, the manager, was—I read the warrant to him, and Mr. Notley explained the charge—Fennell said that he wanted to see Mr. John Penn—he also said "I have received money from Porter, but I do not know what for." I took him into custody—on the way to the station he again said that he should like to see Mr. John Penn—he said "The fact of it is I have received a sovereign or two from Porter; I met him when I was in straitened circumstances, and he has sent me money for more iron than—I could get, over what was booked to him; for the lot for which you have got me, Porter sent me 5l.; this is what I want to tell Mr. John Peun, with a good deal more." (Henry Porter "here surrendered, but MR. SERJEANT. Ballantine objected to his being now put on his trial with the other prisoners, such a thing never having been done before, and if done it might cause evidence to be given which would prejudice the other prisoners. MR. BESLEY, who appeared for Porter, stated that the delay in his surrendering was caused by his having a consultation with his solicitor at the time the case was called on. THE COURT ordered Porter to be given in charge to the Jury, the witness re-sworn, and the evidence already given to be read over.)

H. J. MARSHALL (continued). Fennell also said "I arranged with Clark that the weights in the receiving house should show as usual," and that he had done that because Porter had asked him to get the iron in—he said "Now I suppose he wants me to suffer for the lot, but I shall tell the Magistrate in open court all about it." I told Clarke who I was—Sergeant Andrews was there—the warrant was read over, and Mr. Notley ex
plained what the charge was against him—I afterwards assisted in appre
hending Porter.
Cross-examined by Fennell. I asked you about 5l. on the way to Black-heath—I did not ask you about 100l.—I knew nothing about it.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMS. I did not hear Clarke say that he knew nothing about it—I did not take him in custody—I went away with Fennell.

WALTER ANDREWS (Dectective Sergeant). On the 16th July I was at Messrs. Penn's works—-Clarke was brought into the office—the charge was read to him, and he said "All I know about it is Porter said it was a dirty lot, and he must have some allowance for dirt; that he had some overweight always allowed him for dirt, 2 or 3 cwt., I think he said." I took him to the station, and the same evening about 11 o'clock I went to Porter's house, 5, St. George's Terrace, Lewisham—I posted four men round the house—I had great difficulty in getting in—I searched the house, and Porter was found in a cupboard in the scullery by Sergeant Marshall on my presence—he was very violent, and I put handcuffs on him—I was about to read tthe warrant to him—he said "Do not do that, I know all about it: I knew at 11 o'clock to-day that the warrant was out against me, and that Penn's man and Douglas were in custody," or were locked up—I told him he was all on the spiring to steal and with stealing—he said "Well they may talk about conspiracy, I shall be able to prove that the difference—they will have to prove it, and if they say that I gave Peun's men money they will have to prove that too, and it will take you and them all your time. I should have given myself up to you, but I did not want to be locked up all night. I went over the garden wall to my mother's house at the

back, and you would not have had me now if it had not been for the policeman you placed under the wall." He got on top of the policeman's back, I believe, as he slipped down—he also said "I cannot under
stand what Douglas is in custody for, he did not buy the iron, he only had part of the profit, which I gave him." His brother was charged with assaulting me, and referring to that he said "I am sorry my brother struck you, he did it out of love for me, I hope you will not be too hard upon him." He was then taken to the station—on the same day, about 10 o'clock, I took Douglas at Green Bank, Lewisham—he was in bed, but dressed—I told him who I was, and that I was going to arrest him on a warrant for stealing a quan
tity of iron in April last belonging to Messrs. Penn—I took out the warrant to read to him—he said "Pray don't do that, I know all about it, and have been expecting these proceedings, and I am sur
prised that Messrs. Penn should take the steps they have for a sum of about 30l. I know the Penn family, and we are to a certain extent intimate." He offered every facility to my searching—his brother came in, and being surprised to see two detectives there, asked me what it meant—I said that I was there to arrest his brother, and he said "Now, Thomas, if there is anything you can tell the officers about this business do so." Thomas said "Well, all I know about it is this: I bid for Peiin's iron, and Porter heard of it. Porter saw me, and said 'What do you want to bid for Porter's iron for, I have had it so long; let me have it this time, I can get some overweight and you shall have part, or half of what I make,' and he afterwards gave me some money, 8l. or 10l., I don't know which. I do not think there was anything wrong about taking that money, as I advanced him part of the money to pay for the iron, and, of course, I ran a certain risk." He said that he was not fit to be removed—I saw his medical man, and he was left there with an officer in charge of him.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I understood him to say "I cannot account for the deficiency in the weight," or it may have been "forany deficiency"—he did not tell me that he had seen Whitling—I had been watching outside for a long time—he said that he had gone over the garden want to his mother's so that I should not see him, as he did not want to be locked up that night.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT. Ballantine. I believe Douglas is a wharfinger—I believe other officers have been to his wharf to make in
quiries—I only went to his house—he might have learnt that proceedings were going on—there were four or five remands—I was present at all—ths Magistrate did not say on the last remand that there was no case against Douglas—he did not intimate his intention to discharge Douglas or any
thing to that effect—I think it was on the last hearing that Whitling was produced—the Magistrate had given an intimation about Douglas case on the previous hearing, and then Wickling was produced for the first time, but not in consequence of what the Magistrate said—he was going to be a witness, that was understood, and he was there at each hearing, but his evidence was not given until the Magistrate had given an intimation—he had sworn information.

ALPHONSE NOTLEY . I am chief clerk to Messrs. Penn and Son, of Greenwich—Fennell was their foreman of labourers, and Clarke gate
keeper at the weigh-bridge—it was Clarke's duty to weigh materials there

which were going out—he was supplied with a slate and a book—he entered the weights on a slate first if he wanted to do it quickly, and afterwards into the book, which went to a clerk named Neville, as it was called for—it was Fennell's duty to superintend the loading of all heavy materials—he would give me a memorandum of the weights of scrap-iron, but not others—that memorandum would be checked by the entry in Clarke's book and the delivery order would be made out, and the amount then entered in the day-book—for some time prior to April of this year the firm had been in the habit of selling scrap-iron to Porter—scrap-iron was delivered to him on 17th, 18th, and 19th, and its delivery note (produced) was handed to Nevill, in fact he would make it out from the counterpart—in the ordinary course iron would be de
livered on that note—I received a memorandum from Fennell in refer
ence to that order, which was torn out as soon as the entry was made—that memorandum was compared with the gate-book and corre
sponded—it also corresponded with the delivery order, and the entry was made in the day-book in accordance with those documents—Porter paid only upon those amounts—Mr. Freeth called on me about May and made certain inquiries, and I gave him a memorandum with the transactions of the 17th, 18th, and 19th.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Fennell had been many years in the service—scrap iron and heavy iron are mixed, and there are cast borings and iron turnings—I gave a special memorandum of each—the actual weights would be put on the gate slate; that was Clarke's duty, but if he was not there somebody else would do it—it is very rarely that he was absent—I did not see any one make an entry on the slate on the 17th—I cannot say when the elate entry was obliterated—I know nothing about the weights on the slate on those three days—I see some of the iron was 3l. a ton, but the average price in Porter's contract was 2l. including turnings and borings—an allowance of 7s. 6d. was made to Porter—Porter has been under contract with Penn's more than seven years—he carries on the business of an iron merchant—there may be a few cwt. given over to make up for exceedingly dirty lots—I never called on Porter in reference to this matter, I never knew where he was—I know that he was in liquidation some years ago.

Cross-examined by Fennell. You must have given me a direct memorandum, you would not give it to Neville—I always took the memorandum the same as Mr. Neville—you would possibly hand me a memorandum when the sale took place, and when the iron was taken away.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMS. Clarke was about two years in the prose
cutor's employ as a labourer, always under Fennell—he was afterwards promoted to be gatekeeper—there are other gates, but he is the only gatekeeper.
Re-examined. Iron taken by Porter would go out at Clarke's gate in the ordinary course of business.

Cross-examined by MR. WILLIAMS. I said before the Magistrate the trans
actions with Porter were on Porter's account—I always dealt with Porter and Douglas as two distinct persons.
HENRY WILLIAM NEVILLE . I am a clerk to Messrs. Penn—it is my duty to keep the gate book—this (produced) is Clarke's gate book—I prepared this delivery-note from the gate-slate which ought

to have been kept by Clarke—it is not for the purpose of the delivery-note being prepared—the note was sent through Fennell and returned to me signed—I cannot recollect whether I gave it to him, but it was returned to me with others signed "H. Porter and Co."—I do not know Clarke's writing, I never saw it.

Cross—examined by MR. BESLEY. The gate-slate was in sometimes fourteen days before I saw it—it was generally sent up the same day—I saw it on 10th April, the same day as I made the entry—the entry is an accumula
tion of three days' entries—I have in other oases given delivery-notes on the faith of representations made verbally, before seeing the slate at all, but not in this case.

ROBERT SHARPE . I am in Messrs. Penn's service—I know Clarke's writing, I have seen him write several times—to the best of my belief this is his writing—I have seen him write more than twice—when I have sent for the book he has entered things in it—I have seen him making the entries over and over again—I find here on the 18th and 19th in Clarke's writing in reference to Porter "llcwt. 2qr. 31b. of iron borings"—I do not see the gate book. (The entries were here read.)

HENRY WILLIAM NEVILLE (re-examined). These are the entries in the gate book—they correspond with those on the same date in the day book; 11 cart-loads of iron turnings llton lcwt. 61b., and four loads of heavy scrap 5 tons 8 cwt. 81b., four loads light ditto 4 tons 4 cwt. lqr. 201b. on the 17th, and on the 18th nine loads of cast iron borings 11 tons 8 cwt. 2qr. 101b.; adding those together the heavy iron makes 5 tons 8 cwt. 8lb., and the scrap iron 4 tons 10qr. 201b., and the rest weighs 11 tons 19qr. 101b—the entries correspond with those of the day book.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I cannot account for these irregularities in the gate book, all I know is that the slate was sent to me—the gate book is copied by the gatekeeper—I suppose he keeps the slate—the iron turnings would not be spread all over the factory that I am aware of—I have nothing to do with the outside department.

JOHN JAMES OVERHILL . I am a carman in my mother's service—in April last I was employed by the man named Brown for Mr. Penn at Evelyn Wharf—we were there I believe three days, I helped to load—two of Mr. Porter's men were there on two days, and one man on one day—Fennell was not there—this is my signature to my deposition. (This stated: "I was employed there three days, I saw Fennell present when it was loaded.") I did say that—it is true, but I can't remember seeing him—I recollect that the iron was weighed—I saw Clarke there then with a slate in his hand—we took the iron down to Evelyn Wharf and shot it into a barge there—I recollect it because one of the horses fell into the barge—two carts were employed—I was employed by Mr. Porter.
Cross-examined by Fennell. I saw you about the premises when the loading was going on, but I did not see you watching the loading.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMS. I had been to Mr. Penn's place before, but not with an order—I was the carman—there was another, his name was Brown—he was with me on those three occasions—there was nothing to strike my attention as to what was going on—the detective asked me at the Greenwich Police-court whether I saw anybody with a state?

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I was sixteen years old last March—I drive one of my mother's horses—I can take a ton and half in a load, but sometimes only a ton—this was the first time I have taken orders

or Porter—my mother is not here—the carts have to be weighed to take off the weight from the iron—we can make half a ton difference by the horse standing on the weigh-bridge—if the horse does not stand on the weigh-bridge it does not show the right amount.

WILLIAM ANDERSON . I am in Messrs. Penn's employ, and have charge of Evelyn Wharf, Deptford—in April Fennell told me that Mr. Notley had given Porter permission to lay a barge alongside the Evelyn Wharf to load, and the barge was loaded with iron on 17th, 18th, and 19th April—I saw Porter at the wharf two or three times during that time, and I saw Douglas once—they were on the quay close to the edge of the wharf while the loading was going on.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. The iron is weighed in the factory—they sometimes weigh the cart and the iron without the horse, and in a great many cases they weigh the cart and the iron—I remember the 19th of April, because on the 18th the horse fell into the barge—I did not see Porter there after that that I remember—he only remained a few minutes.

SAMUEL FREETH . I was in partnership with Mr. Whitling—I was manager to the Phoenix Iron Works at that time—prior to April I knew Porter, and had been in the habit of buying scrap iron of him—on 21st April he said he had a cargo coming from Messrs. Penn's, consisting of lump iron, cast iron, iron borings, and wrought iron turnings—on the evening of 19th April he brought a barge, called the Andrew, alongside with the metal as I had arranged—we commenced unloading on the 21st—many men were engaged in it under Verrall's superintendence—a man named Andrews was in Douglas's employ, and was present at the unload
ing—it was Verrall's duty to see the cargo as it came from the barge and enter it in the landing-book—I observed a conversation going on between Verrall and Andrews, and afterwards saw Porter come to the wharf—I had a conversation with him, and he gave me this invoice. (This was dated 24th April, 1877, charging iron of different kinds and amounts, making a total of 104l. 16s. 11d. less 10 per cent., 103l. 16s., credit 90l., balance 13l. 16s. by the large, Andrew, settled by cash 13l. 16s. H. Porter and Co., 1st May, 1877.) I afterwards got the landing-book from Mr. Verrall, compared the weights, and found that they corresponded—I only paid 90l. on account when the invoice was given me, on account of my suspicion about the weights, but he said that those were the weights which he had already charged—I told him the weight was considerably less than was in the barge, but he said the full weight was there—I said that I should require to see Penn's invoice before I paid the balance, and he said he would bring it the next morning, which he did, and turned down a portion of it where it should be receipted—after he left me I went to the Phoenix Wharf and had the load of iron reweighed, and found out that the weights came out in correspondence with this paper (produced)—I then paid the balance, and on, I think, the 2nd of May I wrote a letter to Porter—I wrote three or four letters to him, and about May 7th he called upon me, and I saw him—I also saw him at the works on 15th May—I said there were 12 tons 18 cwt. short in that barge—he said "The weight is all right; you have got the full weight," and I believe he said "You have made the overweight at Penn's"—he then asked if I would take a bill for the difference, 32l. 12s. 5d.—I said that I had paid him cash, and he must refund the money, which he promised to do next day—he came the

next day, and said that his mother banked at Deptford, and he had not brought the cash, and made another appointment—he came again on the 15th, and said that Douglas, his partner, was going halves in the trans
action, and he would see him and get half the amount from him—he also said "I understand you have written to Penn's, or seen Penn's upon the subject of the short weights"—I do not know what was said further—I saw him after that, and he said that the weights had been checked ready, and asked me if I would write to Penn's, and tell Mr. Penn that the mistake was our own, which I refused to do, and said that if the short weight was known to Mr. Penn the man would be discharged.

Cross-examined by Fennell. I said at the police-court that I could tell by looking at the draught of water what the barge held—it would not hold so much as was represented—I weighed the iron out in barrels.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Mr. Parsonage, whose private residence I do not know, represents the Phoenix Iron Works—he was the sole person who represented them up to 29th September—he was also the person who came in after I was a liquidating debtor—I undertook to pay 7s. 6d. in the pound—I have not paid the last two instalments—my partner is not in prison—I think you are on the wrong tack—I suppose he is at home—complaints have not been made against me from different people that I am aware of—I am not aware of complaints of our weigh-bridge until I heard of it at the police-court—I have had no disputes as to over
charging—Mr. Bowman has not charged me with getting money out of him for weights which were false—I know him—he may have had a dispute with my partner, Mr. Whitling—I did not owe Bowman anything when I compounded—we have passed this concern over to Mr. Parsonage—Whitling and I are still managing it—I had not paid the 90l. when the invoice was brought to me—I think the invoice shows that it was paid on the 19th—no; I suppose it was paid a week or nine days before, but that was not before the invoice was brought—the 90l. was paid on account of the balance afterwards—our works are at Millwall—I never saw the barge till the day before the invoice was brought—it was alongside the wharf on the 19th—I never pay by cheque; always in cash—we have no bank
ing account—we weighed the cast iron turnings, the weight tallied, and then we paid the amount—I never knew that Porter was getting a profit out of us—I was present on the 15th, when he admitted that there was a balance to come to us for insufficient weights, but on the 28th he again said that the weights were correct—he said so all along, but yet he agreed to pay the difference—I believed on the 28th that we had been robbed all through—there had been only from four to six transactions between us and Porter before—I have not sworn that there were only three—I did swear "I have had two or three transactions with Porter"—the last was two or three months ago, about May last, but that meant since our failure, since Mr. Parsonage was introduced—we failed two years ago, and I think we have had two transactions with Porter since.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT. Ballantine. Mr. Whitling is the City manager, I am not over him—we are joint managers—Mr. Parsonage finds the money, I suppose we are his servants—we are not his partners—we do not call ourselves partners—he has the lease of the works—my wages are 10l. a week, and Mr. Whitling's the same—sometimes we take it weekly and sometimes monthly; we have no regular account—we go through our accounts at 60, Gracechurch Street—I have not the wages-book here,

it is at the works—our wages are entered in it; I swear that 10l. a week is entered to me and to Whitling, I saw it this morning—it is my business to look over it—these thirteen tons of iron were invoiced from Penn's and delivered to me—we paid for thirteen tons more than we ought, and the 32l. from Porter was for the difference of weight—we had the iron, but we thought we had been robbed of it, until Fennell confessed about it—when Fennell confessed he did not send us the 23l.

HENRY VERRALL . In April last I was employed at the Phoenix Iron Works—I remember some iron coming in the barge Andrew by this entry—my duty was to weigh it as it came in from the barge—I did so, and made entries in this landing-book (produced).
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. The barge came on the 3rd of April.

EDMUND VICTOR WHITLING . I am the City manager to the Phoenix Iron Works Co., at 60, Gracechurch Street—on Saturday, 28th April, Porter called there for payment of his account, and I paid him 90l.—I said that Mr. Freeth was not at all satisfied with the weights of the iron delivered, and he intended going over to Messrs. Penn to see if the amount charged was correct—he said, "For God's sake don't do that, telegraph to Mr. Freeth to see me before he goes"—I declined to tele
graph and Mr. Freeth came up—before that I told Porter that Mr. Freeth had sent Andrews and Mr. Verrall together, and he thought the weights were not correct—later on the same day Mr. Freeth came in—on 1st May Porter called again for payment of his balance, and I ultimately paid him—I said that we believed we had been robbed in conjunction with Andrews and Verrall—he said, "So help me God, I have only charged you the same weight as Penn's have charged me"—I produced an invoice, turning down a part and showing the weights only—after looking at that I was satisfied—he said, "These are the weights, perhaps you will now be satisfied"—we discharged Verrall—shortly after Porter left I saw Mr. Freeth, who showed me a paper—after that I saw Porter at the wharf—I believe we had then made a claim upon him for 32l. 12s. 8d., the difference between the weight Penn's gave to Mr. Freeth and the weight that Porter had charged us—I said I was very much sur
prised after a man taking his solemn oath that he had given it, that there was such a discrepancy, because I considered that he had shown us the original invoice—he said that we should not lose any
thing, or some incoherent statement; but of course I did not believe a word he said after that—he said that I should have to get half of the amount back from Mr. Douglas—he called on me four or five days later at the City office, and promised to pay the 32l. the next day at twelve o'clock—the last day of May, or early in June, I was in the Lombard dining rooms and saw Douglas—I said, "Porter has not paid that money yet"—he fell into a great temper, and seeing he was getting very boisterous I left him sitting where he was, and went into the innerroom—he came after me and sat down by me and said, "Don't you think you are going to frighten Harry Porter out of that 32l.?"—I said that I did not want to frighten any one, I only wanted what was right—he said, "You have had your fair weights, you have not been robbed"—I said "If we have not been robbed, who has been robbed"—he said "Penn and Sons have, and they have been for years"—I said, "Well, if Penn and Sons have been robbed, pay them back the money, we only want what is right"—he said." What good would it do you if I paid them to-morrow?"—I said, "What harm would

it do you?"—he said "It would get three of Penn's men the sack; I will tell you what I will do, I will pay what I have received into any asylum you like to name"—I said that I had nothing to do with asylums, and advised him to see about it at once, as the receiver was as bad as the thief—he said he would go and see John Penn himself in the morning and tell him all about it, as he was on intimate terms with him, and used to ride with him in his carriage to the works very often of a morning—he mentioned the gate-keeper, the foreman of the labourers, and some other person at Penn's wharf—he said that he had not received 10l., as after paying Penn's men there was only 8l. received, which was interest on the money he lent Porter—I think he said he considered it only a fair profit upon the risk of lending Porter the money.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. When I first spoke to him he said he would see me damned before we should have a farthing of the money—I think he did not exactly know what he was saying—he did not suggest that I was a thief, but he said he would not touch Mr. Freeth with a barge pole—I went into the inner room because he made so much noise—he followed me, and confessed that he was a party to the robber)', but I do not think he knew what he was saying, he told me so many lies—I have known him many years—I do not think he had the knowledge that it was a robbery—I do not think he looked upon it in that light—hesaid the 8l. he received was interest—I had no business with the 32l. 12s. 8d., but I wanted it for the iron delivered short at our works—I do not know whether we received the full amount for which we paid—I only have to do with the City office—I knew there had been a dispute about the amount, and instructions were sent to me to collect it—we went into liquidation two years ago, and Mr. Parsonage bought the works and arranged with us to carry them on and take a salary of 500l. a year, and according to the letters we were to take it off his salary—his profits were to be 10 per cent on the little money that he had lent us from time to time—he was acting as a dummy to enable us to trade—he purchased three parts of the works—we considered ourselves his servants—we had 10l. a week regularly, which is entered in the wages book.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. I was a commission agent before this—I took capital into the concern—no one has spoken to me outside since Freeth was cross-examined, or said anything about the 10l. a week—not a soul has spoken to me, and the policeman knows it—I did not try to get the 32l. 14s. 10d. out of Porter or Douglas—I did not go after Porter—he came to me—I did demand the money two or three days after the 1st of May, and I went on demanding it till the 1st of June, when I saw Douglas—I never saw Porter at the Lombard—he has not complained of our weights to my knowledge—some one may have—it is one of the best weighing machines in London—it has been there nine or ten years—I told Porter that there was a warrant out against him—I cannot say when. Porter and Clarke received good characters.

FENNELL and CLARKE—
GUILTY— The Jury and Prosecutor strongly recommended them to mercy—
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment each.

PORTER—
GUILTY —
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

DOUGLAS—
NOT GUILTY .

809.
ELIZABETH COLUMBELL (35)
, Feloniously killing and slay
ing her female child.

ELIZABETH JULIA COLUMBELL . I am the prisoner's daughter—my father's name is Christopher Columbell—we live at Bursidge Grove, Plumstead—on Saturday, 6th Oct., I went out in the morning with my little brother Tommy, leaving my brother and the baby in the house—before I went out I fetched a quartern of gin for my mother, it came to sixpence—it was about nine o'clock—I afterwards fetched three half-pints of beer for her—there was no one else in the house—I did not see her drink it—I went out to play with my brother—we came back about twelve—I found my mother sitting there with the baby in her arms—the baby was a month old—mother cooked some fish for dinner—she sent me out for a pint of beer—I did not see her drink it—father was not at home—after dinner I went out again to play, leaving my mother and the baby in the room—I returned about four or half-past—mother was then lying on the bed, and the baby beside her, and father was there sitting on a chair—he went out soon after—some time after I noticed that the baby's legs and feet looked very white—I felt them and they were cold—my mother was asleep—I tried to waken her and could not—I called Mrs. Welsh, the landlady—she came and looked at the baby and I went and fetched father.

ELLEN WELSH . The prisoner and her husband lodged in my house—on the afternoon in question the little-girl called me—I went with her up to the prisoner's room, and found her lying on the bed asleep—I con
sidered her very much intoxicated—she had her hand on the child's head and chest as if cuddling it—I felt the child and found that it was dead—I did not wake the prisoner till her husband came—I had seen her about mine in the morning—she was then about half drunk—she was a very good woman when sober, but very violent when in drink—she had been drinking the night before.

WILLIAM WARMAN COLMAN . I am a surgeon at Woolwich—on 6th Oct., about twenty minutes to sis, I met the prisoner's husband and went with him to his lodging—I found the prisoner lying on the bed—the baby was in the centre of the bed, and the prisoner was lying completely over it, except the two feet and one leg—I pulled her off the bed and took up the child and examined it—it was dead—I afterwards made a post-mortem examination—it was a fine, well-nourished child—the death was caused entirely by suffocation—the prisoner was helplessly intoxicated.
Prisoner's Defence. I would not hurt a hair of my children's head—I was always good to them—it is very hard to be punished so long as I have been, and kept away from my children.

p.rs: GUILTY—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury—

div1.p:
810.
JOHN SWEETING (33), was indicted
for b—y.

GUILTY —
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

811.
CHARLOTTE MARTIN (29)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
George Breeze. She was also charged on the coroner's inquisition with the like offence.
JOHN PEARSON . I am a fly-driver for Mrs. Pawley, of the Rose and Crown, Tunbridge—on Sunday, 21st Sept., between six and seven o'clock

in the evening, I was at the South Eastern Hotel, Tunbridge, which was kept by George Breeze, the deceased—the prisoner was in the house, and her husband, or a man I knew as her husband—I have known him from a boy, and have known her some time—she was the worse for liquor—they were in the house when I went in—a quarrel commenced between her and her husband—Mr. Breeze was in the bar—the prisoner's husband went out and she threw a pint pot out of the door at him, upon which Mr. Breeze came round the bar and attempted to put her out—he asked her to go out, but I did not hear what she said—he then came round the bar and attempted to put her out, and she fell down by the door—I mean that he took hold of her and she fell on the ground and put her arms round his legs and then bit his right leg inside just below the knee—he had trousers on—she went away afterwards—he said "Oh, you have bitten my leg"—after she had gone out he turned up his trousers and showed me his leg, and the blood was running down—I did not see him again till next day when I went into the bar, and he said that his leg was very painful—he was managing his business—I never saw him after
wards—he had been there five or six months—I do not know what aged man he was, but by the paper he appears to have been thirty-seven—he was not an old man—I do not know much about his habits as to drink—I know he used to drink, but I never saw him drunk.

RICHARD GAINSFORD . I am a fly-driver of Tunbridge—I was at the South Eastern Hotel on the evening of the 21st September—the prisoner and the man who passes as her husband were there—I have heard the account given by the last witness, and confirm it in every respect—I saw the whole occurrence.

JOHN WALKER . I am a printer and live at Baden Road, Tunbridge—I was at the South Eastern Hotel on the 27th September—I was not there when the prisoner was turned out, it was an hour and a half after
wards—the deceased told me that a woman had bitten his leg, and he showed me his leg—it was bleeding a very little then—I saw him the next evening, Friday, when his leg looked a little worse; it looked mortified; at least, it looked more inflamed than it was before—I did not see him on the Saturday—I saw him on the Sunday, in bed; he was then very ill, and he said he was suffering from his leg—I saw his leg that day about 12 o'clock, it was more inflamed than it was on the Friday—he was not in the habit of lying in bed on Sundays, but he was com
plaining of his leg, and I sent for a doctor, Mr. Irving, who came on the Sunday afternoon, and I never left the deceased, except for refreshment, till "Wednesday morning at 3 o'clock, when he died—on the Monday morning his leg was a little swollen, and on the Tuesday it was about half as big again as the other leg—I also noticed something else the matter with him, he looked mad—he was delirious—he began to be delirious on the Tuesday morning about 3.30; he was seeing visions, and he said that he saw dogs—that was the first time I saw any symptoms of delirium—that continued till about three hours before he died—he fancied he saw objects before him—he could speak, but not sensibly—I could understand what he said—he was quite sensible before he died, the delerium went off three hours before he died—I have known him intimately for the last five months, but not more than as visiting the house—I have heard people say that he did drink a good deal, but I have never seen him the worse for drink.
By THE COURT. Some people say that he had the reputation of being a

drunken man, but I never saw him the worse for drink—I believe he drank a good deal, but as far as I know he did not drink so much lately, that is that his widow told me—I never saw him drinking much—I have been in the house almost every day, but never saw him drunk.
By MR. H. AVORY. He had a fit on the Friday, but I was not there.
By THE JURY. He did not drink much after his leg was bitten; he had some port wine and some ginger beer, but very little, about a couple of glasses a day.

CHARLES IRVING . I am a Member of the Royal College of Surgeons and a Licentiate of the College of Physicians—I practise at Tunbridge—on Sunday, 30th September, I was called to see the deceased, George Breeze, and I went at 5 o'clock in the evening—he was in his bedroom on the bed, but not quite undressed—he was suffering from the effects of a wound on the inner side of the knee, a little. above the knee, and from the commencement of delirium tremem—I saw the wound, it was inflamed all up the thigh to the groin—he was partially delirious then—he would rest for a moment, but every second or third question he would answer irrationally—I ascribed that to delirium tremens, and prepared for an attack of delirium tremens, as those are the beginning of the symptoms, and I also treated his leg—I had never seen him before in my life—I noticed nothing else at that time but the delirium and the inflammation of his leg—I next saw him on the following morning, Monday; his condition was then worse in every respect—I had pre
scribed for him on the Sunday—I treated him with narcotics to try and induce sleep and endeavoued to cut off his alcohol, but it was not cut off—it is common for persons to be afraid of carrying out the doctor's orders—by degrees I stopped it altogether—my orders were slightly disobeyed,' I found that he had whisky or port wine, but not in any large quantity—on the Monday the symptoms of delirium tremens were more marked—I saw him next on the Tuesday morning, when his condition was worse in every respect—his leg was decidedly much worse, there was a great deal of swelling and inflammation—I was with him more than an hour on the night he died, which was early on the "Wednesday morning, and I had also seen him on the Tuesday evening earlier—I was not with him when he actually died, but I was within an hour of his death—he was simply comatose and moribund when I last saw him—I was called in to give a certificate of his death, and my first certificate was delirium tremens simply; I afterwards added to that that the exciting cause of the delirium tremens was a wound on the leg—I express my opinion now that the delirium tremens was caused by the wound.

By THE COURT. I think the delirium tremens would not have come on at all if it had not been for the wound—the wound provoked the delirium tremens, and but for that he would not have died—I am able to say that the alcohol he took afterwards did not aggravate the symptoms—he took—very little. Q. If you were able to say that but for what he took himself after the wound he would not have had debirium tremens that would make a great difference?—A. I believe it was very slight, and it would have very little effect, notwithstanding the little he took after my instructions—if he had not taken that he would still have died from delirium tremens—it was certainly not that that caused the delirium tremens—a bite like that, I believe, is not a dangerous thing, in a healthy person it would produce
no result at all—I do not think there would be any danger of erysipelas from it in a healthy person.
By MR. H. AVORY. I have said "The man was saturated with alcohol," but that condition is quite possible without his ever being drunk.

HENRY KEWELL . I am superintendent of the Tunbridge police—on Sunday morning, 17th October, the prisoner was brought to the police-station on a warrant—she was charged with manslaughter, killing and slaying George Breeze—on 27th September she said "The landlord was putting me out and I bit his leg, but I did not think it was going to kill him."

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I was going back to the hotel after going to the station, when Mr. Breeze said 'You know what you have done.' I said that I was very sorry if I had done any
thing to hurt. He said as long as I would apologise I need not think any more about it."

FREDERICK RANDALL . I am a constable of the Kent county constabu
lary—I apprehended the prisoner on Sunday morning, 7th October, at Tunbiidge railway-station in a carriage—I asked her her name, she gave the name of "Martin"—I told her I had a warrant for her in that name—she first denied all knowledge of being known in Tunbridge, and said that she did not know anything about the offence—I got into the carriage and told her the charge, she again denied all knowledge of it—I took her to the station, and she then said that she did bite the land
lord, and he forgave at the time, and afterwards drew her half-a-pint of rum in a ginger-beer bottle.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking very heavily, and I did not know anything that occurred till after I went back into the house again, and then he said that I had bitten his leg—I asked him to draw me half-a-pint of rum—he said "I suppose you know what you have done?"—I said "No"—he told me, and I said that I was very sorry—he said "So long as you apologise I shall not think any more about it."

GUILTY .** The officer stated that the prisoner had been taken in custody for being drunk and riotous in 1876, on which occasion she bit the hand in two places of an engine-driver who the constable called to his assistance, and also assaulted the constable.—
Six Months' Imprisonment.

812.
CHARLES GURR (25) was indicted
for b——Y.

GUILTY —
Ten years' Penal Servitude.

813.
HENRY EDWARD PELHAM BUTLER (33),
PLEADED GUILTY
to Feloniously Marrying
Fanny Hendrick, his wife
Emily being alive—
Three Months' Imprisonment.

814.
JOHN VINCENT (33)
, Unlawfully selling indecent photo
graphs.

GUILTY —
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

815.
THOMAS KELLY (24)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Brunt, and stealing therein a parrot.

EMILY BRUNT . I am the wife of Wm. Brunt, of 2, Calthorpe Court, High. Street, Chatham—on Tuesday, the 7th August, at about 12.30 in the morning, I went upstairs with my husband, having latched the front door—I had heard him come in—about a quarter of an hour afterwards I heard a noise downstairs and the noise of the parrot, and my husband went down directly and followed him—the parrot was gone, and a few feathers and my hat and jacket were on the doorstep—I had left them on a chair covered up in the same room with the parrot—I gave information to the police, and went to the Marine barracks next morning, when Edwin Rate showed me the parrot, and I paid him 1s. 4d. for it.
Crose-examined by the Prisoner. Of course I didn't see you about house—I heard somebody—I didn't say I see you.

SAMUEL PERCY . I am a corporal of the Royal Marines stationed at Chatham—I was on guard at the barracks gate on the morning of the 7th August when the prisoner came in about 1.35—he handed me a pass—I did not notice whether he had a parrot about him—his pass was up to 5.30 a.m.

EDWIN RATE . I am a private in the Marines stationed at Chatham—on the morning in question I saw the prisoner at 5.30 in his room sitting on his bed with this parrot, not with the cage—the prisoner went down bathing, and he gave it to the cook till we came back—he said he was going to sell it for 1s.—I said "I will give you 1s. for it"—afterwards he told me he found it on the Chatham lines—when I—found the parrot belonged to Mrs. Brunt I sent for her, and gave it to her, and she gave me my shilling back and fourpence for my trouble.

FREDERICK RAYNER (61 Kent Constabulary). I am stationed at Chatham—I received information about this house being broken into, and went to the barracks on the morning of the 7th, at about 5 p.m.—I charged the prisoner with breaking into the room of the prosecutor, and stealing a parrot and hat and jacket—he said he picked up the parrot near the Military Road at 5 o'clock, and he afterwards said he picked it up in High Street—the Military Road is about 400 yards from the prosecutor's house.
MRS. BRUNT (re-examined). I only lost the parrot—the other things were found outside on the door-step.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. " I have nothing to say—I call no witnesses."
Prisoner's Defence. I was on pass that night and had been to Stroud, and about 11.30 or 12, I can't say which, I caught a parrot flying about in the High Street.
MRS. BRUNT (re-examined). The door was only on the latch—they could open it from outside.

The Prisoner. Mrs. Brunt told Rate that the cat had got it next door. Witness. My neighbour went up with me, and she said that she thought.—it was their cat at first, but I knew it was not—I heard a man go past the door.
NOT GUILTY .

816.
THOMAS BROWNE (25)
, Burglary in dwelling-house of
John Ford, and stealing therein 170 cigars.
JOHN FORD . I am the landlord of the Railway Inn, St. Mildred's parish, Canterbury—on the night of the 14th October I noticed the

prisoner in my house at ten o'clock, at which time I cleared the house of customers and closed it, and secured my doors and windows, and went to bed about 10.30—I got up next morning at 5.55, and found the kitchen door open, and a pane of glass in the back kitchen window broken, the hasp broken, and the window raised sufficiently to allow a man's body to pass through—the kitchen door had been opened from inside, as if the party had come in at the window and gone out by the door—I went upstairs and acquainted my missus, and I afterwards missed 170 cigars, 100 of which had been in one box, and 70 in another, and a portion of brandy from a decanter—I gave information—these cigars were afterwards shown to me, and correspond with what I lost (produced)—the wholesale price is 9s. per 100.

THOMAS HAYWOOD (Police Sergeant).
