On the morning of the 15th I received information from the prosecntor, and went to the prisoner—I told him the Railway Inn had been broken into, and that he was strongly suspected of committing the robbery—he said he knew nothing about it—I searched his jacket, and in the pocket I found ten cigars, and in what is termed the long bag, part of the kit, I found some more broken, about the same quantity—I asked him how he accounted for the possession of the cigars—he said he bought them at some shop, he could not say where—85 cigars were afterwards handed to me in this handkerchief (produced)—they were found secreted in different parts of the room—they were given to me in the room in the presence of the prisoner by the sergeant of the regiment—I think he said he found them in the coal-box, near the fire in his room—the prisoner admitted that was his hankerchief they were tied up in.

ROBERT PARSON DAVIS (Superintendent of Police, Canterbury). The prisoner was given into my custody on the morning of the 16th—seeing he was a young soldier, I asked him what service he had, and he told me—I asked him if he was aware of the nature of the charge, and if he was properly charged and cautioned, and he made some evasive answer; "but," he said, "I never took the cigar, sir; they were given to me out of the front door after closing hours on the Sunday night. When in the house on the Sunday morning I asked the landlady to give me some cigars, as I was going out to India. After the house was closed on Sunday night I came and threw a small pebble at the window, and the landlady came down and handed me the cigars"—I then said to him "But you have written a letter to the landlord, asking him to forgive you," and he admitted to me that he had—here is the letter written by him to the landlord, and signed by him—I got it from the landlord. (The Court was of opinion that as there was no evidence of the handwriting the letter could not be read.) I was at the hearing before the Magistrate—there was a remand, at which I was also present—the wife of the prosecutor and the servant were there by my order, and the prisoner declined to question them.

Prisoner's Defence. About ten o'clock on the morning of the 14th Oct. I went to the Railway Inn public-house—I knocked at the front door and was admitted by the landlady—I stayed there until about three o'clock in the afternoon, during which I had a conversation with the landlady, and told her I was going to India and should like a few cigars to smoke on the road—she asked me for a handkerchief, which I gave her, and she told me to go there about 10.30, and she would give them me unknown to her

husband—I went there and threw a stone at the window and she gave me the cigars, and I went home—she told me her husband had thrown something at the back kitchen window and broken it—assuming the house had been broken into, I sent a letter down—I have not seen the letter yet. (The letter produced was handed to the Prisoner.) That is not the letter that I wrote.

GUILTY —
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

817.
WALTER PATEMAN (19) and
THOS. REYNOLDS (18)
, Robbery with violence on
Thos. Schofield, and stealing a hat, some veal, and other goods.

THOS. SOHOFIELD . I am an engine-driver in the London, Chatham, and Dover Railway Company's employ—on Saturday, the 14th July last, I took down an engine to fetch a train from Swanley Junction—I had some refreshment that evening at the Bull public-house, near Birchwood Corner—it is kept by a Mr. Hutton—I left that house, a little before nine o'clock, to return to the station—I was not due to leave the station till eleven o'clock—I took a parcel of food from the Bull for my fireman—as I was going along the road to the station I saw two men come towards me on donkeys—I was then about half a mile on my way—I made way for them to pass, and just as I thought they had passed I received a blow on the back of the head; I stumbled forward, and as soon as I could recover myself I turned to look who it was—I saw the faces of both men—one was on a donkey, and the other standing then—they were quite close to me, and I made the remark that it was cowardly for two men to attack a little man like me, and the one on the donkey (Pateman) said "That's the b——y Yorkshireman"—with that they both fell to beating me with sticks and kicking me about the body and head, Pateman having got off the donkey—I was in the road, and they kicked me when I was standing up and when I was down—my hat was lost—they continued to kick and beat me—one of them said "What have you under your coat?" and I told them it was food for my mate—one of them pulled open my coat and took the parcel from me, and by some means or other I managed to get up—as I was running away I received three blows on the side of my head with a stick—the third blow knocked me down again—when I recovered I saw the men going up the hill in front of me—I followed them as well as I could to the Bull—just before they got to the Bull they turned down a lane to the right—that is a lane leaning towards Dartford—one donkey was a lightish one, and the others were more of a brown, darkish—there were three donkeys, but two men—Mr. Hutton took care of me, and had me washed and drove me back afterwards to the station, and I went up to town with my fireman on the engine—I went to Dartford the nest day and lodged a complaint.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. The next morning, driving over the Heath, Mr. Hutton pointed out a man named Gordon, who I said strikingly resembled one of the persons—I did not say "I will swear he is one of the men"—I say now the two prisoners are the men—they were—in the police-station when I identified them—a third man was with them, a brother of Reynolds—he was afterwards discharged—the policeman. was at the station when I got there, and he said he had three men in. custody, and I went in and picked these two out of the three—it was on a Tuesday—after I had seen Gordon on the Heath I went to the superin
tendent,

and told him I had seen a man strongly resembling one of them—I have not seen Gordon since to my knowledge—I had never known either of these two men before—it was a rainy night, not very dark then—I could see them coming—I had never been that road until that night—I had never been to the Bull before—I know where Swanley Junction station is—I know there is a beerhouse or public-house down the lane the men turned called the Alma—there is a roadway farther on from where this happened, going to Swanley Junction, on the right from the Bull—I had my watch and chain with me in my under-jacket—they were not touched, and my jacket was not unbuttoned—the parcel of bread and meat I carried under my coat, I never saw that again—the hat was brought back.

JOHN HUTTON . I am the landlord of the Bull at Birchwood Corner—on Saturday evening, the 14th July, the last witness came to my house and had some refreshment, and left my house a little before nine o'clock—he took some bread and veal and ham wrapped up in a paper—he returned about 9.30, very much excited—he had been knocked about and complained very much—I had him attended to, and drove him to the station—he was quite sober—I know both the prisoners—they are donkey-drivers.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I have known them between seven and eight years—their father had my pleasure grounds—I have known nothing against them—they have been hard-working and industrious. (The witness explained the bearings of the locality with reference to the scene of attack on a plan.) The Reynoldses keep their vans or house-carts here during the summer—the spot where the scuffle took place has been pointed out to me, and I have measured the distance from there to the road lead
ing up to the house-carts—it is 100 yards from the mile-stone, about 150 yards from that place—this roadway is a private road leading to Heath-field Farm—on the day in question there was a party of excursionists down, and there were a great many at my place, 500 or 600—there was a quarrel between some of them and the donkey-drivers, not my party there might be six, eight, or ten donkey-drivers at my place, and there might be a dozen at the Lullington Hotel—this squabble was about four o'clock—the prosecutor recovered, and I took him back that night, and he went up with his train to London—he came to the station the next morning, and I drove him over the Heath—we met a man named Gor
don going over the Heath—I have known him as a donkey-driver for a long time—I said to Schofield "Is that the man?" and he said "I will swear he is one of the men"—I went with him to the Superintendent that Sunday morning, and he told the Superintendent that was one of the men, and he made a statement to him of how he had been knocked about—I cannot swear whether I told the Superintendent the man's name—Gordon was not taken into custody to my knowledge.

By THE COURT. Gordon was half way across Dartford Heath when we saw him—I should say three miles from my house, and one mile from the police-station at Dartford—he got out of the roadway on to the footpath to allow my horse and trap to go by—we met him—I would not stop him without a constable, because I knew where he could be found—Schofield had a fair opportunity of seeing his face and figure—I know now that he identifies two other men—there is a likeness between Gordon and Reynolds, they are the same stamp of man.

WALTER WILLIAM MILLS . I am a farmer at Farningham—I remember, on the evening of the 14th July, perfectly well, seeing some men on don
keys pass my farm at eight minutes before nine—I was in the garden close to the road—it was light enough for me to see the faces of the men—there were two, at first the younger prisoner Reynolds and his brother, and there were five donkeys—then another man followed with three don
keys—I cannot recognise him—they joined company together—shortly after that I was standing in the main road, just off the farm, when I observed, about 200 yards off, a scuffle between the men, and, as I sup
posed, the donkeys—I went the other way to The Bull, and saw no more—while I was there Schofield came in—I examined his head, and found a bruise as large as an orange—I went to the exact spot the next morning, where I had seen the scuffle, and there I found the prosecutor's hat secreted in the hedge—it is between half and three-quarters of a mile from there to The Bull.

Cross-examined by MR. EIBTON. I know the London and Maidstone Road—there is a pathway before you come to the turning to the station—I was standing here when I saw the men pass (referring to the plan)—the way they were going would lead them to the Lullington Castle Hotel—I don't know much about the donkey-drivers—I don't like them, nor would you if you lived where I do—I crossed before the orchard, and crossed the heath and out on to the road, and I saw the scuffle when I was on the brow of the hill—it was eleven minutes past nine by my watch when I started to go to The Bull—I don't know whether the men came into The Bull—I know it has been proved that they turned round to the right towards the beerhouse called The Alma—I know The Alma a perfectly well—it was a mizzling night—not darkish when I saw the prisoners, as I thought, dividing their donkeys, but, as it turned out, they were knocking a man about—there is a house called Beenham's Farm, a little lower down, and a public-house called The Woodman a little lower down on the other side of the way—the road under your thumb would be the nearest way to Swanley Junction (referring to the plan)—there is another road—I know nothing of Pateman—there is a house-cart there belonging to Pate
man—I did not hear of the row between the excursionists and the donkey-drivers, because I was in London.

CHABLES FREAD (Superintendent of the Kentish Constabulary), On Sunday morning, the 15th July, the prosecutor was brought to me by Mr. Hutton—his face bore various black marks on it, and there were several bumps ahout his head—he made a complaint.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. He did not tell me who the man was—he said he had seen a man on Dartford Heath who very much resembled him—he did not say he could swear to him—I did not take down what he said—he did not tell me the man's name—I believe Hutton mentioned a man's name whom they stated they passed on the heath—I know Gordon well—I did not take him up—the two prisoners were taken up on the"' following day, the Monday—if the prosecutor had positively identified Gordon I should have thought it my duty to have him arrested—he told me the circumstances under which he met him, and that he very much resem
bled the man—I ultimately gave directions to a constable and sergeant to investigate the whole matter, and left it to them.
EDWAED LANGRIDGE FISHER (Sergeant of the Kent Constabulary). On Monday, the 16th July, in consequence of information I received, I went

in search of Pateman and Reynolds—I found Pateman at about 12.30 in the day, at the "Holly" beerhouse, near Birchwood—I said to him "I shall apprehend you for a highway robbery with violence on an engine-driver, between Birchwood and the junction, about nine o'clock on Satur
day night last, in company with a man named Reynolds"—he said "I was not with any of the Reynoldses on Saturday night last; and when I came from Swanley Club on Saturday night I did not come that way, I went round home by Hextable"—I then took him to the Birchwood public-house, where Reynolds was in custody of police-constable Terry—that is "The Bull," about 150 yards from the beerhouse—I then, in the presence of Reynolds, repeated the charge against them both, and they made no reply.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Before that Pateman had said he had gone round by Hextable, and had not seen Reynolds, who was then, or shortly afterwards, in custody—I don't know that he made any statement to Terry—I recognise the main road, "The Bull," and the station on plan, which are correctly described—here is the "Lullington Castle," and the road leading down to Mills' house—Pateman's father lives here, where the vans are—in going round by Hextable Pateman would go this road round that turning is what we call "Five Wents" (describing on the plan)—if he went this way he would say "I went round by the "Five Wents."

GEORGE TERRY (257 Kentish Constabulary). On Monday, the 16th July last, I apprehended Reynolds at "The Bull," Birchwood—I told him I should charge him with highway robbery with violence on an engine-driver, between Birchwood Corner and Swanley Junction, last Saturday night, about nine o'clock, in company with Walter Pateman—he said "I know nothing about it, I was not with Walter Pateman last Saturday night, and I didn't see him till Sunday morning"—I afterwards heard Sergeant Fisher tell him the charge when they were both together, and they made no reply.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Swanley Bottom is about a mile from Swanley Junction—I recognise the main road and the road leading down to Mills' shown on the plan—Pateman's father's house is where the carts are—he would not go that way by Swanley Bottom—the nearest way would be from Swanley Junction straight up the turnpike road—I appre
hended one of the Reynoldses, Thomas—the other Reynolds was taken into custody by Sergeant Fisher, and was in custody till Tuesday morning, when he was discharged—I do not know why.

E. L. FISHEE (re-examined). I took George Reynolds and Terry took Thomas—George was locked up till Tuesday morning, when Mr. Miller, the Magistrate, discharged him—the three prisoners were shown to the prosecutor, when he picked out one of the Reynoldses and the other prisoner.

HENRY TURNER . My father keeps "The Woodman" beerhouse, near Swanley—the two prisoners were at our house on Saturday evening, the 14th July, and tow others were with them, one of whom I know as George Reynolds—they left, as nigh as I can say, at about twenty minutes to nine.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I am sure that Pateman was one of the men, and that Reynolds was one of them, and the third man the other Reynolds—I don't know that the fourth was named Bilsby—I saw them

divide their money, and all four go up the road together towards Swanley Junction—I know nothing more about it—I did not give any information to the police—I was subpœnaed here—I don't know where Pateman lives—there is a road called Swanley Bottom.

Pateman's Statement before the Magistrate. " On Saturday night I went to Turner's house with three more, and I tied one donkey to his scraper—when I went out I got on the donkey and went up the road, when my saddle slipped off, and I jumped, off, ran forward, and turned back the other two donkeys and buckled my saddle up, and went back towards Turner's house, and turned to the left, went to Swanley Bottom, and went home."

Reynolds's Statement. After I left Turner's house, me and my brother got up on a donkey a piece, and galloped along past Beenham's house—we stopped there to see if Pateman was coming, and we then went home, tied the donkeys up, had our supper, and went to bed—I didn't see Pate
man till Sunday morning between eight and nine."

p.hi: The following witnesses were called for the Defence.

div1.p: GEORGE REYNOLDS . I am the brother of the prisoner Thomas—I am also a donkey proprietor and driver, and live near Bromley—it is the custom of myself and brother to go to Swanley Junction with our carts—I did so last summer—on the 14th July I was with Walter Pateman, and we went to the White Hart at Orpington at about 9 a.m., and remained there till 5 p.m.—Orpington is the next station below Chisle hurst, and about three and a half miles from Lullington Castle—when we left at five, we went to Birchwood; we had four donkeys with us—we then went to Swanley, where a society called the Swanley Club meets—it met that night, and we went to the meeting—my brother was at the Club; we met him not much past six—I suppose we left the club at 8.10—the two prisoners, myself, and a man named Bilsby, and we went to the Woodman (Mr. Turner's)—we did not stop there long; we had one pot of beer—we divided our donkey money and went home, straight along that road to the Lullington Castle (showing on the plan)—we did not go in—we left Pateman behind us, between Mr. Beenham's farm and Mr. Mill's, I remaining with my brother—Bilsby remained with us till we turned into our road, which leads the Heathfield farm—we went to the house-carts, to my mother's first—we told Bilsby to take the donkeys to Swanley—he turned to go; we never turned to see—I suppose it was not quite nine o'clock—it was 8.45 when we came out of Mr. Turner's house, and we had a very short distance to go—we are just at the top of the railway—if trains pass by we could hear them—a train came in soon after we got home, I suppose what they call the 5 to 9 train—when we got to my mother's house there was William Pateman at home, the prisoner's brother, who is married to one of my sisters—my brother stepped indoors—we remained the night—I came out to go and tie my pony up—my brother was up in the van dressed—presently I came back again, and my brother-was still there, and then we stopped all night—my mother was left in the van when I went to tie up the pony—when we first got to the house-cart, Mary Reynolds, my wife, was there, William Pateman, his wife, my sister—I was present when Terry arrested, my brother—some little time after Terry called upon me—Sergeant Fisher was there, and I was arrested, and was handcuffed to my brother and Pateman—I was discharged on Tuesday.

CHARLOTTE REYNOLDS . I am the mother of the prisoner Thomas—we have our house-carts up this little roadway leading out of the public road—I heard of the assault on the prosecutor—my two sons came home together a few minutes before the five minutes to nine train came in—they never went out again that night; they never went out of my van—I first heard of the assault on the Monday morning—William Pateman was at home when my sons came home—he is married to my daughter—Mary Reynolds was there, the wife of my son George, and Mary Pate
man, who is married to the prisoner's brother.

WILLIAM PATEMAN . I am a donkey driver, and am brother to the prisoner, and married one of the sisters of Reynolds, and live with the mother up this road—I remember hearing of the assault on the engine-driver—my brother Thomas and Reynolds came home with the donkeys, and I see them unsaddle them just as the five minutes to nine train came in—I followed them up to the van and stood on the steps, and some con
versation took place—I am sure they never left again that night—I am sure the train was in time that night—I have a clock in my van, and I take that train two or three times a week to go shopping.

MARY REYNOLDS . I am the wife of George Reynolds—I heard of the assault the next day, Sunday—my husband and his brother came home a few minutes before the nine o'clock train came in—I am in the habit of hearing that train, and regulate my time by it—they went out to tie up their donkeys—my husband never went away all night, and I saw his brother go into the next van to me.

MARY PATEMAN . I heard of the assault on the Monday—on the night of the occurrence the prisoner Reynolds came home with his brother George a few minutes before the five minutes to nine train came in—he never went out again—William Pateman is my husband—Rey
nolds went into the next van to me.

ROBEET PATEMAN . I heard of the assault on the Monday after—I see my son, the prisoner, in Mr. Prescott's beershop, The Alma, at about ten minutes past nine—I heard him come to my house before he went there, but I never see him, and he went away directly to the public-house, and I soon followed him—I saw the donkeys tied up, his boy always does that—there was a lot of fruiting people working round in the neighbour
hood—I'did not see any other donkey drivers there—I went into the tap-room—they might come forty times into the bar without my seeing them—I was with them until ten o'clock, when they shut up—he went to Birch
wood Corner after that because they shut Up at eleven.

THOMAS PRESCOTT . I kept the Alma at the time in question—on the night of the assault I saw the prisoner Pateman at my house at five minutes to a quarter past nine, I think—there were two more donkey men in the house together drinking—Thomas Reynolds was not in my house at all that night—I have known the two prisoners for twelve years, I should think, and I have never heard anything against them—they are hard-working respectable men in their line of life—I was asked by the police to give evidence on the Tuesday, I think, as they were taken on the Monday—they sent then to tell me not to come—they thought they could do without me—I didn't want to go at all.
By THE COURT. The men had their donkeys with them—I cannot answer for their having sticks—the donkeys were there till I shut up my house
—then I recollected them and turned them up the lane—the men had gone to their houses.

ALBERT SMITH . I remember the night in question and I know the prisoner Pateman—I remember his coming home that night, but cannot say the time exactly—I see no clock near me all day—he had his donkeys with him—he told me to unsaddle them and tie them up, and go to bed, which. I did—he went to the Alma public house.

THOMAS GORDON . There was a row about four o'clock in the afternoon of the day of the assault on the prosecutor between some of the donkey drivers and the excursionists—it happened between Lullington Castle and Birchwood Corner near to the Bull—I was there and saw some of the blows exchanged—the donkey drivers got the worst of it—Bilsby was not there—I did not hear anything about a Yorkshireman—I took no part in this assault—I was passing over the Heath on Sunday morning, and saw the landlord of the Bull go by with somebody, but I cannot tell who; they drove by without stopping, and I saw them come back.
NOT GUILTY .

818.
THOMAS NEIGHBOUR (28)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Farmer with intent to steal.

SAMUEL COE (14 Borough of Gravesend Police). At about three o'clock on Sunday morning, the 8th July, I was at the Canal when I saw two men in the attitude of getting into Mr. Farmer's window—another man stood by—I was about ten yards, I should think, from the two men, and they were about this far into the window (pointing to his waist). It was a sash window—as soon as they saw me they ran away, and I gave chase and followed them as far as Mr. Brown's wharf—I had a clear view of their faces—then they went into Mr. Butcher's wharf, and I lost sight of them—I ran outside of Mr. Butcher's wharf—I looked over the" fence and saw the prisoner and the other men coming alongside—I climbed over Mr. Butcher's fence, and chased them back to Mr. Brown's and to Mr. Farmer's, where they started from—they ran away again, and I saw two of the men going away in a boat, and I caught the prisoner, who was running when I arrested him—I told him I should take him into custody for attempting to break into the house of Mr. Farmer—he told me he had had a "shove down" in a sand barge, and he was going to Clap-creek, where he had some friends, and he was going back to London that tide—I went in company with another constable and roused the inmates of Mr. Farmer's house, the Shades, and found that the glass of the window was broken round the catch so that it had been unfastened—this blind was five or six feet outside the window—it had been inside—the sash was up as I had first seen it—I searched the prisoner, and found;' on him four bargeman's keys, a box, a lighterman's licence, and 3s. 9d. in money—I am positive the prisoner is the man I saw.

Cross-examined. I was ten yards off when I saw the two men. in the window and the one man standing by—it was 3.30 a.m. The prisoner was one of those getting into the window—he had his back turned to me—almost immediately after that the three scampered off, and I chased them, I should say for a quarter of an hour before I caught the prisoner—I only lost sight of them once for six or seven minutes—I

was not prepared to take anybody into custody I saw running—he had taken a circle right round by the wharf—I had to run him round twice—I took the prisoner into custody on the other side of the Canal to that he started from—not far from the original spot they started from—it was the other side of Mr. Butcher's foundry—I could see the other two men, but not so as to identify them.

Re-examined. When I lost sight of the men all three ran into Mr. Brown's wharf first, and from there into Mr. Butcher's—then I went outside—they went inside, and I looked over the fence and saw the prisoner and the other men coming up inside—I climbed the fence, and chased the prisoner till I captured him.

WILLIAM FARMER . I keep the Albion Shades—I locked up the house the night before the occurrence in question, and saw that it was secure—about four o'clock on the Sunday morning I was aroused by a police-constable stating the house was broken into, or rather the window in the basement at the side of the house was open—it had been closed the night before—there is a small passage at the side of the house—the glass was cut the size of a penny to admit anything to uncatch the window—the inside blind was broken, and was outside in the street—there were none of my goods removed—I do not know the prisoner.
Cross-examined. I lost nothing.
NOT GUILTY .

819.
THOMAS WATSON (35)
, Stealing a pony and cart and set of harness, the property of
William Hackett.
MR. FRITH, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

820.
JAMES TURNER (41)
, Stealing a chest of tea, the property—of
Henry Hailey and another.

EDWARD FERN . I live at 229 Linton Road, Bermondsey, and am a commercial traveller—on Saturday the 26th August, 1876, I was driving along the Lower Road, Rotherhithe—I saw the prisoner walking behind the van, which was laden with tea—he took a chest of tea off the tail of my van and put it on another van, and put a low tarpauling over it, and the driver of the other van drove away—I saw the prisoner get down—I followed the van and gave the other man into custody—he was tried, and sentenced to nine months at this Court—I next saw the prisoner at Green
wich police-court, on the 11th October, and identified him—I am sure he is the man who took the tea.

JAMES WHEAL . I live at 70, Greenfield Street, Whitechapel—on Aug. 26th, 1876, I was driving a van along the Lower Road, Rotherhithe, of thirty-six chests of tea, for the victualling yard, Deptford—when I got down a chest of tea was missing.

WILLIAM HUNT (City Detective 795). On Tuesday, 10th October, I apprehended the prisoner in Gracehcurch Street, for stealing a chest of tea a twelvemonth ago—he said "Middleton told me that was all settled—I said I should take him to Rotherhithe to make further inquiries—the charge was read over to him at the station—he said nothing.
ELIZABETH ANSTIE . The prisoner was staying with me from the middle of last August till February, at Twickenham—I went to the fete on the 18th August—he was at work on the 20th August.

HARRIET "WEST . About the middle of last August the prisoner, who is my brother, came to me and said, as he was out of work, he was going to Twickenham to seek employment, and also because of his wife's ill-treat
ment.
Prisoner. I was not there—I am innocent.
NOT GUILTY .

821.
JOSEPH JONES (21),
PLEADED GUILTY
to feloniously breaking and entering St. John the Baptist District Church, Kingston, and stealing a rug and other articles—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

822.
WALTER CHARLES STAFFORD (25)
, Embezzling the sum of 43l. 2s. 6d., 1821. 10s., and 42l. 10s., of
George Pimm, his master, upon which MR. HORACE AVORY, for the Prosecution, offered, no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

823.
JOHN TIMINGS (44) was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.

HARRY TITTERTON . I am second clerk at Southwark police-court—on 10th September I was present at the hearing of this summons (pro
duced)—it is against William Timmings for unlawfully causing the steam barge Swift to be navigated without having a licensed man on board—the defendant appeared and called the present defendant as a witness on his behalf—he was sworn, and I produce my notes of his evidence. (These being read, stated that the defendant swore that he was on board the barge Swift during her passage up the Thames on 22nd August, 1877; that he was not navigating the said barge, but was on board the barge Willey, which was being towed by the Swift, and that Benjamin Elliott, the complainant, never came near him or spoke to him on that day.) The question about Blackfriars Bridge was repeated several times by the Magistrate in my hearing, but the prisoner adhered to his statement that Elliott never came near.

Cross-examined. Before the prisoner was examined the Magistrate made some observation about his apparent state—I noticed that his manner in the witness-box was peculiar, as if he had been drinking—I cannot say that the Magistrate was somewhat—exacting in his manner of putting questions—his strangeness did not diminish under the Magistrate's questions, but I cannot say that it increased under them.

BENJAMIN ELLIOTT . I am a licensed waterman and lighterman, of Duke Street, Stamford Street—on Wednesday, August 22nd, I was in a skiff near Cherry Garden pier, and saw the steam barge Swift, belonging to William Timmings, going up the river towards London Bridge, towing the barge Willey with a line—they passed quite close to me, within afew feet, and I saw the prisoner on board the steam barge steering with the wheel—William Timmings, the owner, was also on board, and the engine-driver was at the door of the engine-room—I knew the prisoner and his brother well up and down the river, and knew that William Tim
mings

was a licensed waterman, but that the prisoner was unlicensed—in consequence of that I hailed the prisoner but he would not tab notice—he turned his face and spoke to the engine-driver—I could not hear what he said, but the engine-driver went in, and by the difference of the steam from the funnel and the speed she went at I conclude that he put on more steam—I rowed up as close as I could to him and asked him to give me a turn with my headfast, but it was only momentary, for the steam barge dashed by, and I was only rowing a small boat—they steamed away and I followed—they pulled up just before they got to Blackfriars Bridge, and I overtook them—they moored the Willey along
side a barge of coal to have some coal put into her, and I rowed along
side the Swift—the prisoner was still on board, and I said to him "Are you aware you are breaking the law, Mr. Timmings, and he said "Get out of it, you scamp, you ought to be ashamed of yourself to be rowing about preventing honest men from earning their living"—I said that he, a non-freeman, was robbing us of our rights and privileges—he made use of a beastly expression and abused me—I said if he used such language I should summons him—he used another expression and told me to go and see his brother, I should find him at the Old Barge House public-house—I afterwards summoned William Timmings, as under the bye-law the owner of the barge is liable, and it came on for hearing on the 12th September at the police-court, and the prisoner was called as a witness for his brother—I have heard read to-day the evidence which he then gave, and it is correct—prisoner was greatly excited, and I believe he had been drinking.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner and his brother by sight two or three years—they work right through to Beading—I did not hear it stated before the Magistrate that the prisoner had received an injury to his head by a fall in a barge ten years ago.

WM. SMITH HITNTER . I am a licensed lighterman and waterman, of Hatfield Street, Stamford Street—on Wednesday, 22nd August, I was on the river in a barge and saw the steam barge Swift below Cherry Garden Pier with the barge Willey astern—the prisoner was steering the Swift and his brother William was on board the Willey—I know them both "wel—I spoke to the prisoner as he passed about a job I had done for him and he answered me.
Cross-examined. I have known them by sight two years—I saw them on the river during July and August—I know nothing about the prisoner meeting with an accident.

JAMES BRUCE . I am a lighterman and waterman—on 22nd August I was on the river with a barge and saw the prisoner steering the steam barge Swift, which was towing the Willey, which had his brother William on board—I saw Elliott run within 5 yards of them, he tried to catch the steamer but fell alongside the barge—he was trying to speak to the prisoner—I saw the engineer go down and then I could hear that the Swift was going faster.
Cross-examined. I have known the brothers three or four years—they have been in the same public house as me—I never heard of the prisoner having a fall on his head.
JOHN ABBOTT . I am a licensed waterman—on 22nd August I was on board a moored craft at Davis Roads, and saw the Swift towing the Willey—the prisoner was steering the Swift through Blaekfriars Bridge,

and his brother was on board the Willey—they rounded at the Roads and Elliott rowed up and went alongside the Swift—the prisoner was still on board—I saw Elliott speaking to him, but could not hear the words—the conversation lasted about three minutes—Elliott then came and took me ashore.

Cross-examined. I saw their mouths moving—I have known the prisoner two years and have had a glass of ale with him—I never heard till this morning that he suffered from a severe fall on his head—I do not think Mr. Benson, the Magistrate, was excited; on the other hand, I think the prisoner was excited and strange in his manner—the Magistrate did not put his questions in a way likely to frighten a poor man.
Re-examined. I should imagine that the prisoner had had a little drink—the Magistrate did not frighten him, there "was nothing in his manner to frighten anybody.

WILLIAM FOSTER (Police Inspector L) (Cross-examined). I was before the Magistrate the whole time, but did not see the prisoner before he was in the witness-box—while he was there I thought his manner was strange.

THOMAS RICHRED GREEN . I am a waterman—I have known the prisoner twenty-two years—he bears the character of a very honest and truthful man—he had a very heavy fall on his head about fourteen years ago, and ever since that, when he takes a little beer he always goes off.

p.hi: The prisoner received an excellent character.

p.rs: GUILTY— Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury—

div1.p:
824.
RICHARD MULLINS (20), and
WILLIAM HAY (18),
PLEADED GUILTY
to breaking and entering a church, and stealing therein two apples, three pears, two bunches of grapes, property of
George Stores; also to breaking and entering a school-house and stealing a tuning-fork, knife and fork, and other goods the property of
Allen Thomas Edwards (having been convicted at this Court in October, 1876). MULLINS—
Two Years Imprisonment.
HAY—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

825.
THOMAS WATSON (21) (a soldier) was indicted
for bestiality.

GUILTY —
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

826.
FREDERICK ANDEEWS (55)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Stephen Whettem, with intent to steal.

STEPHEN WHETTEM . I keep the Antelope public-house at St. Albans—on the night of the 3rd Oct. last I closed my house at about eleven o'clock—at twenty minutes to two I was awakened by some gravel being thrown up at my chamber window—I looked out and saw a policeman standing below—he turned his bull's-eye on and I went down and opened the street door, and the policeman called my attention to the fact of the cellar shutter being lifted up about five inches, and asked me what it meant—I went down in the cellar and there I found the prisoner standing up in the corner—I did not notice whether he had anything in his hand, because the light I had in my hand was very small and the cellar was dark—I said "What are you doing here?"—he made no reply, nor did he move—I then called up the cellar stairs to the policeman—he came down and said "How is it you are down here?" or something to that effect, and his reply was "I came down for a night's lodging"—he appeared to be quite sober—he is a stranger to me.

CHARLES WEEDS . I am a constable at St. Albans—at about twenty minutes to two on the night in question I noticed the cellar-flap at the Antelope had been lifted a few inches since I last passed—I threw some gravel at the window and eventually I went in the cellar with the last witness—he went down first and I followed a few minutes after and found the prisoner crouched down in the corner and had his shoes in his hand—I asked him what he was doing down there—he said he came down after a rest—I took him in charge—I had seen him that evening previously about 11.15—he asked me if I could direct him to a place where he could get lodgings—I told him to go to the Goat Inn, a lodging-house, but he said he should not go without I went with him—he had had a little to drink, I think.

WILLIAM JAMES PIKE (Supt. of the St. Allans Police). On the night of the 3rd Oct., at about five minutes to eleven, the prisoner came to the police-office and wanted some accommodation—I told him there was no accommodation there for him, and he had better go away—he said "Well, if I walk the streets the police will interfere and take me up"—I said "The police won't interfere with you if you don't commit yourself in any way"—I saw nothing more of him until the following morning on this charge.

Prisoner's Defence. On the day this happened I had walked some twenty-nine miles, and when I got to St. Albans it was late and I could not find any lodgings, and I went direct to the police-station to see if they would allow me to sleep in a cell, or find me some place so that I need not be out all night—the inspector told me he could not accommo
date me—I afterwards met this policeman who has been here, and he told me to go to the Goat—I told him I should not go to the Goat unless he went with me, as being after shutting-up time they would not let me in unless I went with him—on passing by this house I never noticed whether it was a public-house or not—I lifted up the flap and went in and took my shoes off, my feet being blistered—I had no intention of stealing anything—the fact of my not fastening the cellar-flap shows I had no intention of staying there to take things out of the house—I had not the slightest intention of taking anything out, as God is my judge.
NOT GUILTY .

827.
FREDERICK PARKER (14) was indicted
for bestiality.

p.rs: GUILTY— Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth.—

div1.p:
828.
WILLIAM SHARP (25),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing, whilst in the employment of the Post Office, a post letter containing seven Bank of England notes, the property of the
Postmaster-General.—
Five Years Penal Servitude.

829
FREDERICK EDWARD LYSTER (29),
Unlawfully making a false declaration, and thereby obtaining a marriage licence, upon which
